questions.text: Which is the reflex that causes tachycardia when the right atrium is distended?
questions.solution:
Bainbridge reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension.
The Bainbridge Reflex, also known as the atrial reflex, controls heart rate by raising atrial pressure, which can sometimes raise heart rate by up to 75%. A tiny portion of this increase is due to the stretched sinus node as a direct result of the increased atrial volume; this direct stretch can raise heart rate by as much as 15%.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 581

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Duke's Criteria for Infectious Endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Splenomegaly
 
Splenomegaly is not included in Duke's Criteria for Infectious Endocarditis.

* [Extra Edge]: Modified Duke Criteria



• Definitive diagnosis: Two major criteria or one major and three minor criteria or five minor criteria.
• Possible diagnosis: One major and one minor criterion or three minor criteria.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 564.

questions.text: Pick the option that does not cause edema.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Digoxin

Digoxin is used to treat CHF so it helps to treat volume overload .It does not cause edema

* Other options: -
1. Amlodipine causes lower limb edema by pre-capillary dilatation
3. Estrogen causes edema by salt and water retention
4. Cyclosporine also increases chances of edema

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 565.

questions.text: To identify distinct heart sounds, an ECG is captured with a phonocardiogram. In the following diagram, where will the second heart sound appear?
questions.solution:
• The phonocardiogram displays the heart sounds, with S2 being the second sound heard during each cardiac cycle.
  • The ECG waveform normally indicates the electrical activity of the heart, with distinct segments and peaks reflecting different phases of the cardiac cycle.
  • Usually, the ECG's T wave is followed immediately by the second heart sound (S2). So, Point C corresponds to Second heart sound.
  • Ventricular repolarization is represented by the T wave, and S2 happens at the conclusion of ventricular systole, immediately following the closing of the aortic and pulmonic valves.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1817.

questions.text: Which point in the following diagram indicates that the left ventricular pressure is equivalent to the diastolic blood pressure?
questions.solution:
The AV valve closes at the start of ventricular systole. Initial contraction of the ventricular muscle is only modest, but intraventricular pressure quickly increases, this is during this period of isovolumetric contraction that the pressure inside left ventricle reaches to that of diastolic blood pressure of aorta and semilunar valves open.


Reference :Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition page no 121,122

questions.text: Which one of the following does not exhibit hyperdynamic circulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Cor pulmonale
 
  • Hyperdynamic circulation is seen in anemia, beriberi & AV fistula, but not in Cor pulmonale.
  • Cor pulmonale has a depressed ejection fraction (<40%). 
* [Extra Edge]: 
  • In acute cor pulmonale there is marked dilation of the right ventricle without hypertrophy. On cross-section, the normal crescent shape of the right ventricle chamber is transformed to a dilated ovoid.
  • In chronic cor pulmonale, the right ventricular wall thickens, sometimes up to 1.0 cm or more. More subtle right ventricular hypertrophy may take the form of thickening of the muscle bundles in the outflow tract, immediately below the pulmonary valve, or thickening of the moderator band, the muscle bundle that connects the ventricular septum to the anterior right ventricular papillary muscle. Sometimes, the hypertrophied right ventricle compresses the left ventricular chamber or leads to regurgitation and fibrous thickening of the tricuspid valve.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 556.

questions.text: Because ___________, nitroglycerin works well as a sublingual medicine.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Nonionic and highly lipid soluble

Because it is non-ionic and highly lipid soluble, nitroglycerin is beneficial as a sublingual drug also it bypasses the first pass metabolism and causes quick and near ​​total systemic absorption.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 588.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with NYHA class III heart failure with dyspnea, pedal edema, K+ levels of 5.5 mEq/L, and creatinine 2.5 mg%. She is currently taking medication for hypertension and psychiatric disease. Which of the following medications should be avoided?
questions.solution:
• Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist. It helps in managing heart failure by reducing fluid retention, but it can also increase potassium levels (hyperkalemia). Given that the patient already has elevated potassium levels (5.5 mEq/L) and impaired renal function (elevated creatinine), spironolactone could further worsen hyperkalemia and compromise kidney function.
 
  • Spironolactone is the most commonly utilized agent in this class based on efficacy demonstrated in the Randomized Aldactone Evaluation Study (RALES) in patients with HFrEF and NYHA class III–IV symptoms.
 
  • Hyperkalemia and worsening renal function are concerns, especially in patients with underlying chronic kidney disease, and renal function and serum potassium levels must be closely monitored.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1947.

questions.text: Below is a comparison of two vessels. What will the flow across vessel 1 be compared to vessel 2 assuming linear flow and constant pressure along both vessels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 8 times

Poiseuille Hagen formula   
                         
                          

     Here radius and length is increased 2x.
     The change in flow will be 8x.


Reference: Ganong’s review of medical physiology 26 th edition page no 563

questions.text: During a football game, a 29-year-old male athlete passed away after abruptly collapsing. The following discovery was made during a gross inspection at the autopsy. His family had already had two deaths that were comparable. What is the most likely cause of his death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

The above clinical scenario is typical of HCM. The autopsy heart also shows hypertrophied myocardium

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)
  • 60-70% - familial
  • Autosomal dominant (most commonly-  alpha-myosin heavy-chain mutation)
  • May cause sudden death in athletes due to ventricular arrhythmia
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 572.

questions.text: What is the most effective antihypertensive medication for pulmonary hypertension
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bosentan

Bosentan is a non-specific antagonist of endothelin receptors (both ET-A & ET-B). It is approved by FDA for the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension. 

Other options: -
1. Digoxin- It increases myocardial contractility and is used in heart failure
2. Furosemide- It is a loop diuretic used in heart failure mainly
3. Amlodipine- It is a Calcium Channel Blocker used in hypertension

The treatment of PAH is important for INICET -

First we will do a Vasoreactivity test, if it is positive the DOC is Ca Channel blockers. If negative based on severity we can use oral drugs like PDE inhibitors like Sildenafil or Endothelin Receptor antagonists like Bosentan. Severe cases we can use IV Prostaglandins, inhaled NO etc.
        
Online Reference: Gabbay E, Fraser J, McNeil K. Review of bosentan in the management of pulmonary arterial hypertension. Vasc Health Risk Manag. 2007;3(6):887-900. PMID: 18200808; PMCID: PMC2350123.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency room. His pulse is not palpable and his ECG is shown below. What will be the immediate management?
questions.solution:
This a case of Pulseless Ventricular Tachycardia (pVT). Patient came to Emergency with unstable vitals, therefore TOC- Defibrillation.

Cardiac arrhythmias requiring Defibrillation are:
  1. Ventricular fibrillation
  2. Pulseless Ventricular Tachycardia




Reference: Adult Cardiac Arrest Algorithm (ACLS), American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines 2020. URL: https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

questions.text: What does the 'a' wave in the jugular venous pulse indicate?
questions.solution:
The ‘a’ wave is generated by the right atrium contracting and pushing blood into the right ventricle during the end of diastole

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 531

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient complained of severe dyspnea. There was mitral stenosis with LA hypertrophy. Plants on the mitral valve, which was removed.
What does the image of HPE show?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Aschoff nodule

The presented image displays a confined nodule of mixed mononuclear inflammatory cells with accompanying necrosis.
Large active macrophages inside the inflammation exhibit conspicuous nucleoli and chromatin that has been compressed into long, wavy ribbons (caterpillar cells). The results imply the existence of Aschoff's body.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics can be used in the treatment of mild to moderate hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Thiazide diuretic

Thiazide diuretic can be given in mild to moderate hypertension.
  • Low-dose thiazide diuretics may be used alone or in combination with other antihypertensive drugs.
  • Thiazides inhibit the Na+Cl- pump in the distal convoluted tubule and hence increase sodium excretion. In the long term, they also may act as vasodilators.
  • Thiazides are safe, efficacious, inexpensive, and reduce clinical events.
  • They provide additive blood pressure-lowering effects when combined with beta blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE/s), or angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 606.

questions.text:
A badminton player, age 23, suffered a left ankle injury. After three months of immobilization, the cast was taken off, and the patient was able to walk normally.
Later, he reported experiencing discomfort and edema in his left calf, left ankle, and left foot. His mother gave him a 30-minute massage. He eventually experienced extreme dyspnea, was taken to the hospital, where he later passed away. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Pulmonary thromboembolism
 






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2093, 2095.

questions.text: Which of the following heart sounds might occur naturally during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Third heart sound(S3) may be a normal finding during pregnancy. S3 is heard in hyperdynamic circulation during physiological stresses like pregnancy, exercise.
  • The presence of an S3 sound is generally considered a normal finding in pregnancy and in young adults but is relatively rare in the healthy pregnant state.
Other options: -
  • Fixed split S2 seen in ASD hence pathological.
  • S4 is seen in decreased ventricular compliance like Ischemic heart disease, hence pathological. 
  • Pericardial knock is seen in Constrictive Pericarditis. 
 

Reference:Williams Obstetrics 25th Edition Page no 61

questions.text: The heart of a patient whose death was presumed to be from a myocardial infarction was stained with triphenyl tetrazolium tetrachloride dye at autopsy. What shade will the myocardium be that is still viable?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Red

  • It is possible to highlight the area of necrosis by immersion of tissue slices in a solution of triphenyl tetrazolium chloride.
  • This gross histochemical stain imparts a brick-red color to intact, Non infarcted myocardium with preserved lactate dehydrogenase activity.
  • This is Because dehydrogenases leak out through the damaged membranes of dead cells, an infarct appears as an unstained pale zone.
* Audio Explanation:
 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 548.

questions.text: A lipid profile is performed on a 60-year-old patient who had a myocardial infarction two weeks ago. The results show HDL 32 mg/dL, LDL 126 mg/dL, and TG 276 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Atorvastatin 80 mg
 
  • Statins are competitive inhibitors of HMG-CoA reductase.
  • This leads to a decrease in cholesterol biosynthesis. Statins are also effective in reducing LDL and triglyceride levels. 
  • Atorvastatin 80 mg can be used to treat this condition. 
  • The first line of therapy in controlling cholesterol in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) is starting a high-intensity statin. (similar to the above case scenario where the patient has MI)
  • High-intensity statins include atorvastatin (40-80 mg) and rosuvastatin (20-40 mg).
NOTE: While fibrates are known to reduce TG, they are not considered first-line therapy in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Statin+ Fibrate therapy(option 1) has not been shown to reduce mortality. Fibrates are only recommended in moderate to severe TG levels (more than 500mg/dL).

Online Reference: Aronow WS. Management of hyperlipidemia with statins in the older patient. Clin Interv Aging. 2006;1(4):433-8. doi: 10.2147/ciia.2006.1.4.433. PMID: 18046920; PMCID: PMC2699649.

questions.text: What does the inability to perform any physical activity without discomfort fall under?
questions.solution:
The inability to perform any physical activity without discomfort falls under NYHA Class IV.

NYHA Class IV:
Inability to carry on any physical activity without discomfort but also symptoms of heart failure at rest, with increased discomfort if any physical activity is undertaken.

NYHA classification of dyspnea:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1936.

questions.text: Which cell organelle is missing in the area marked by the arrow in the heart muscle
questions.solution:
The region marked by arrow is the perinuclear region which doesnt contain lysosomes in a cardiac muscle fiber. 

Although lacking lysosomes, this perinuclear area is abundant in mitochondria and has  Golgi apparatus, glycogen granules, and lipofuscin granules.


Reference: https://www.kenhub.com/en/library/anatomy/cardiac-tissue

questions.text: The heart of a patient after a myocardial infarction is shown below, stained with hematoxylin and eosin. What can you say regarding the infarction's age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 6 hours.

  • The myocardial biopsy is showing some coagulative necrosis along with wavy fibers with widened spaces between the dead fibers, which contain edema fluid and scattered neutrophils.
  • No dense neutrophilic infiltrate is seen. These are typical early changes after MI, seen within 6 hours of infarction.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 547.

questions.text: What antihypertensive medication is not prescribed during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Enalapril
 
  • Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor and ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • They cause severe fetal malformations such as fetal growth retardation, hypoplasia of organs and fetal death may occur if ACE inhibitors are given during later half of pregnancy.
  • A recent report indicates 2.7-fold higher malformation rate in fetuses exposed to ACE inhibitors in the first trimester.
  • ACE inhibitors must be stopped when the woman conceives.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 531.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not an indicator of chronic congestive heart failure.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Sirtuins
 
  • CHF is a condition characterized by the heart's inability to pump blood efficiently, leading to fluid accumulation and various physiological changes. Several biomarkers and clinical indicators are used to evaluate and diagnose CHF.
  • Sirtuins are a class of enzymes involved in cellular metabolism and aging, are not specifically associated with CHF.

On the other hand, the other options are commonly used as indicators of CHF:
  1. CRP (C-reactive protein): Elevated levels of CRP can indicate inflammation, which is often present in CHF.
  2. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP): BNP is a hormone released by the heart in response to increased stretching of the cardiac chambers, which is a characteristic of CHF.
  3. Troponin: Elevated levels of troponin, particularly troponin T or I, are associated with myocardial damage and can be seen in CHF, especially in acute exacerbations or coexisting myocardial infarction.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1932, 1937, 1939.

questions.text: Determine the ejection fraction using the volume pressure curve that is given.
questions.solution:
From the provided pressure-volume loop,
AB: Isovolumetric contraction from the provided pressure-volume loop
BC: Systolic contraction of the ventricles
CD:Isovolumetric relaxation
Hence,
130 mL is the End-Diastolic Volume (EDV) (Point a).
50 mL is the End Systolic Volume (ESV) (Point d)
Flow Volume (SV) 80 mL = EDV-ESV
Ejection Fraction = SV/EDV = 80/130 = 0.6, or 60% EF


Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition page no 121,122

questions.text: In a patient, commissures fuse together and there are vegetations on the mitral valve along the lines of closure. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Rheumatic endocarditis

The image is showing small vegetations in a row along the lines of closure of valves and commissural fusion can be seen. This is typically seen in Rheumatic Endocarditis.


Fig: Acute rheumatic mitral valvulitis


Fig: Various Types of vegetations

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: Which medication is preferred for pregnancy-related hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Methyldopa
 
  • Drug of choice for hypertension in pregnancy is methyldopa.
  • Methyldopa is a centrally acting antihypertensive agent. It is a prodrug that exerts its antihypertensive action via an active metabolite.
  • Methyldopa was a widely used antihypertensive in the 1960s and 1970s, especially in combination with a diuretic. However, it is rarely used now, except to treat hypertension during pregnancy wherein it has a long track record of safety, both for the mother as well as the fetus.
  • Labetolol is preferred to Methyl dopa due to the drugs association with post partum depression
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 612.

questions.text: A 30-year-old guy went to the emergency room complaining of exhaustion, nausea, and muscle weakness. The ECG displayed lengthy PR intervals, large QRS, tall peaked T waves, and no P wave. Which medication from the list below is not used in management?
questions.solution:
Beta-blockers: Not typically used for the acute management of hyperkalemia.
Beta-blockers can potentially exacerbate hyperkalemia as they inhibit the uptake of potassium into cells.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 355, 1830.

questions.text: Which lead would have the maximum voltage of the R wave on an ECG with a "mean" axis of 90°?
questions.solution:
The cardiac axis of +90° corresponds to aVF, thus maximum R-wave amplitude would seen in aVF only.

 

Reference-: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 516

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is diagnosed with a strawberry tongue, widespread erythematous rash, cervical lymphadenopathy( 2cm), and fever over the past five days. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Kawasaki disease
 
  • Strawberry tongue, rash, fever are common for both scarlet fever and Kawasaki disease. Only distinguishing feature is adenopathy more than 1.5 cm is more characteristic of Kawasaki disease.
  • This clinical picture can resemble TSS and scarlet fever, but clues to the diagnosis of Kawasaki disease are cervical lymphadenopathy, cheilitis, and thrombocytosis.

Fig: Strawberry Tongue and Cheilitis

*Table: Warm CREAM and FEBRILE Mnemonics for KD Criteria
 

Warm = Fever for > 5 days

  • C = Conjunctivitis without exudate
  • R = Rash
  • E = Edema or erythema of hands or feet, followed by desquamation and nail changes
  • A = Adenopathy, often unilateral, cervical node > 1.5 cm 
  • M = Mucosal erythema, fissures or crusting of lips or strawberry tongue
  • F = Fever for > 5 days
  • E = Enanthem of mucosal membranes
  • B = Bulbar conjunctivitis
  • R = Rash, erythematous, polymorphous
  • I = Internal organ involvement: coronary, abdominal, pneumonitis, hepatitis, orchitis
  • E = Extremity changes, initial edema, and erythema, desquamation, nail changes

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 513.

questions.text: Where does the primary action of nitrates in angina patients occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Decreases Preload

Sublingual administration of nitrates reduces O2 demand primarily by preload reduction rather than coronary artery vasodilation.
* Antianginal Effects of Organic Nitrates depends on Following mechanisms:
  • Reduced cardiac O2 demand- The major determinants of myocardial O2 consumption are left ventricular wall tension, heart rate, and myocardial contractility. Ventricular wall tension is affected by preload and afterload.
  • Increase in the delivery of O2 to ischemic regions of myocardium- When considering the effect of vasodilators in the ischemic heart, it is important to realize that myocardial ischemia itself is a powerful stimulus to coronary vasodilation and part of an autoregulatory mechanism.
* Experimental Evidence:
  • when GTN is injected directly into the coronary circulation of patients with CAD, anginal attacks (induced by electrical pacing) are not aborted even when coronary blood flow is increased.
  • In contrast, sublingual administration of GTN does relieve anginal pain in the same patients, indicating that the major antianginal effect of nitro vasodilators is mediated by preload reduction rather than coronary artery dilation.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 611.

questions.text: Which of these heart sounds are not heard in chronic mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Third heart sound is NOT heard in Chronic MS
 
  • Option 1: The OS is followed by a low-pitched, rumbling, diastolic murmur, heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral recumbent position
  • Option 3: The opening snap (OS) of the mitral valve is most readily audible in expiration at, or just medial to, the cardiac apex. The time interval between A2 and OS varies inversely with the severity of the MS.
  • Option 4: The first heart sound (S1) is usually accentuated in the early stages of the disease and slightly delayed.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1820, 1992.

choices.text: Crying and flexion of body like fetus position
Increased production of Noradrenaline for the breakdown of brown fat in adipose tissue

questions.text: A newborn displays all of the following responses to cold, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Neonates lack the shivering mechanism because they do not have enough body fat or muscle mass to generate the heat needed to maintain body temperature. Shivering is an involuntary response triggered by cold temperatures, which causes the body to vibrate and produce heat. Neonates' lack of body fat and muscle mass make it difficult for them to generate enough body heat to maintain their body temperatures in cold environments.



Reference:http://www.cmnrp.ca/uploads/documents/Newborn_Thermoregulation_SLM_2013_06.pdf

questions.text: Regular evaluation of a 17- year-old child with no symptoms reveals a short PR interval and a delta wave on the ECG. The boy would benefit the least from which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Beta blocker
Short  PR/Delta waves point to WPW syndrome (characterised by a presence of Presence of an accessory conduction pathway)
Digitalis, beta blockers, and calcium channel blockers are effective in inhibiting conduction through the AV node; however, they do not impede conduction over most accessory pathways.
Drugs like Beta Blockers may actually reduce the refractory period of an accessory pathway which could lead to a faster ventricular rate (and a risk of ventricular fibrillation and hemodynamic collapse) if administered to individuals suffering from WPW syndrome.
Hence, Beta blockers are NOT Given to individuals with WPW Syndrome

WPW(Wolff–Parkinson–White) syndrome
  • Presence of an accessory conduction pathway (usually in left atrium/free wall of left ventricle)
  • Impulse conduction through the accessory pathway leads to earlier pre-excitation of ventricles since there is no AV nodal delay and ventricular contraction.
ECG Changes
  1. Decreased PR interval -because of earlier ventricular depolarisation and excitation.
  2. Prolonged QRS - since conduction is via accesory pathyway - not AV node. 
  3. DELTA WAVE - initial slurred upstroke of QRS (arrow)




Reference: Chhabra L, Goyal A, Benham MD. Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome. [Updated 2023 Aug 7]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK554437/

questions.text: When should we switch to heparin in a pregnant woman with rheumatic heart disease who has a prosthetic valve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 36 weeks.

Warfarin should be held after 36 weeks' gestation (during 37th week) and replaced with LMWH or unfractionated heparin.
 
  • Before giving birth, anticoagulation should be avoided because warfarin, which crosses the placenta, raises the risk of fetal intraventricular hemorrhage, and therapeutic anticoagulation increases the risk for hemorrhagic complications with regional anesthetic.
  • The purpose of conversion to UFH has less to do with any risk of maternal bleeding at the time of Delivery, but rather with neuraxial blockade complicated by an epidural or spinal hematoma.
  • Administration of warfarin during pregnancy causes birth defects and abortion especially in first trimester.  Fetal or neonatal hemorrhage and intrauterine death may occur, even when maternal INR values are within the therapeutic range. Vitamin K antagonists should not be used during pregnancy, but heparin or LMWH can be used safely.
  • Anticoagulation algorithm is pregnancy- 1st trimester LMWH, 2nd trimester upto 36 weeks warfarin, after 36 weeks LMWH or Heparin.
Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page No 985.

questions.text: A patient exhibits angina, syncope, and dyspnea. Which explanation is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Aortic stenosis
 
  • Aortic stenosis is a condition characterized by the narrowing of the aortic valve, which obstructs the flow of blood from the left ventricle into the aorta. This obstruction leads to increased workload on the left ventricle and can result in symptoms such as angina (chest pain or discomfort), syncope (fainting), and dyspnea (shortness of breath).
  • The angina occurs due to inadequate blood supply and oxygen to the myocardium (heart muscle) as the narrowed aortic valve restricts blood flow. Syncope can occur as a result of reduced cardiac output and inadequate perfusion to the brain. Dyspnea is often experienced due to the increased pressure and fluid backup in the lungs caused by the stenotic aortic valve.
  • Aortic regurgitation (option 2) is the backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle due to an incompetent aortic valve. While it can cause symptoms such as dyspnea, it is less commonly associated with angina and syncope.
  • Atrial septal defect (option 3) and ventricular septal defect (option 4) are congenital heart defects characterized by abnormal communications between the atria or ventricles, respectively. While they can cause symptoms such as dyspnea, they are less likely to manifest with angina and syncope.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1981.

questions.text: What happens to the blood flow to the brain during light exercise?
questions.solution:
When engaging in physical activity, the body shifts how much blood is routed to various parts. The amount of blood sent to the heart and muscles after moderate to heavy workout increases, whereas the quantity flowing to the liver, kidneys, and internal organs is decreased. However, during light exercise, there is no significant change in blood flow to the brain due to autoregulation. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 539

questions.text: How do kidneys react to shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Increases afferent arteriole resistance
 
  • During shock, the kidneys undergo compensatory mechanisms to maintain perfusion.
  • One of the mechanisms is vasoconstriction of the afferent arterioles, which increases resistance and helps maintain blood flow to the vital organs so glomerular filtration rate (GFR) decreases if shock is severe in nature.

*Other options:
  • Decreases renal blood flow would be a consequence of shock rather than a reaction of the kidneys. GFR may decrease as a result of decreased renal blood flow and afferent arteriole vasoconstriction.
  • Decreased perfusion of the kidney is seen in shock.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 135.

questions.text: What is the mechanism through which acetylcholine lowers heart rate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Delayed diastolic depolarization

Acetylcholine lowers heart rate primarily through preventing diastolic depolarization, or the spontaneous depolarization of cells in the SA node.
  • Acetylcholine hyperpolarizes the SA nodal cells and decreases their rate of diastolic depolarization. As a result, rate of impulse generation is reduced bradycardia, or even cardiac arrest may occur.
  • At the A-V node and His-Purkinje fibers refractory period (RP) is increased and conduction is slowed: P-R interval increases and partial to complete A-V block may be produced.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 114.

questions.text: Pick the one that is usually not seen in rheumatic heart disease.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: PS
 
  • Rheumatic heart disease primarily affects the mitral and aortic valves.
  • The mitral valve is most commonly involved, leading to mitral stenosis (MS) or mitral regurgitation.
  • The aortic valve can also be affected, causing aortic stenosis (AS) or aortic regurgitation.
  • Pulmonary stenosis (PS), is generally not associated with rheumatic heart disease. PS is more commonly a congenital heart defect, meaning it is present from birth, rather than a consequence of rheumatic fever. It is a common finding in Noonan syndrome.

Valve abnormalities commonly seen in rheumatic heart disease (RHD):





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2004.

questions.text: Where does ventricular depolarization start?
questions.solution:
Ventricular depolarization starts from the left part of the interventricular septum due to the presence of the specialized conduction system in the heart. This specialized conduction system includes the sinoatrial (SA) node, atrioventricular (AV) node, bundle of His, and Purkinje fibers.

The electrical impulse starts with the SA node and travels through the atria causing them to contract. The electrical impulse then reaches the AV node and spreads to the bundle of His and into the right and left bundle branches.

The electrical impulse then divides and travels down the Purkinje fibers, which are located on the interior wall of the ventricles, causing them to depolarize and contract.

These fibers on the left side of the interventricular septum have a slightly faster conduction velocity and therefore start the ventricular depolarization from the left part of the interventricular septum.

Remember- The sequence of depolarization of heart is endocardium-myocardium-epicardium.

The sequence of repolarization of heart is epicardium-myocardium-endocardium whereas the sequence in an isolated cardiac myocyte is endocardium-myocardium-epicardium.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 529

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the "Flipping effect"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 1) LDH 1 > LDH 2
 
  • The "Flipping effect" refers to the phenomenon observed in the electrophoresis of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) isoenzymes, where the LDH 1 band becomes more prominent than the LDH 2 band.
  • LDH 1 represents the LDH isoenzyme with the highest electrophoretic mobility, while LDH 2 has lower mobility.
  • In certain conditions, such as myocardial infarction, LDH 1 can increase relative to LDH 2, resulting in the flipping effect.


Online Reference: Weinberger I, Rotenberg Z, Sagie A, Fuchs J, Sperling O, Agmon J. "Flipped" lactic dehydrogenase pattern in acute coronary insufficiency. Clin Cardiol. 1986 Dec;9(12):597-9. doi: 10.1002/clc.4960091202. PMID: 3780075.

questions.text: Which mechanism does nitroprusside's active metabolite use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Guanyl cyclase

Sodium nitroprusside active metabolite is Nitric oxide.
Nitric oxide activates guanylyl cyclase and raises levels of cyclic GMP. Myosin light chain phosphorylase, which is dephosphorylated by protein kinase G when cyclic GMP is activated, relaxes the smooth muscles in blood vessels.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 544.

questions.text: What is the best noninvasive test to determine the myocardium's viability?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. PET-CT
 
  • For the evaluation of myocardial viability in patients with ischemic cardiomyopathy, myocardial perfusion imaging (with SPECT or PET) is usually combined with metabolic imaging (i.e., fluorodeoxyglucose [FDG] PET).
  • In hospital settings lacking access to PET scanning, thallium-201 SPECT imaging is an excellent alternative.
  • FDG PET is also used in the evaluation of myocardial and vascular inflammation and in patients with suspected infective endocarditis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1834, 1835.

questions.text: Identify the function of Hyperpolarizing Cyclic Nucleotide (HCN) gated channels.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Cardiac rhythm generation

Phase 0 shows upstroke due to opening of voltage gated calcium channels.

        




 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 511

questions.text: Which of the following have most friable vegetation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Infective endocarditis
 
  • amongst the given options, Infective endocarditis is the most appropriate answer.
  • Infective endocarditis is characterized by the formation of friable vegetations composed of fibrin, platelets, and microorganisms on the heart valves. These vegetations can embolize and lead to systemic complications.
  • Libman Sacks endocarditis is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and is characterized by small, sterile vegetations.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 563.

questions.text: Verapamil was administered to a patient who was taking metoprolol for hypertension. What will this lead to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bradycardia with AV block 
 
  • Among the following bradycardia with AV block are likely to happen with the above combination therapy.
  • Verapamil and metoprolol (beta-blocker) show drug interaction and result in precipitation of bradycardia and AV block since both have inhibitory action on AV node and oppose positive inotropic action.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient comes into your clinic complaining of chest pain that has lasted the last 24 hours and has been accompanied by perspiration and diaphoresis. The ECG results are as follows. It is 150/90 mm Hg. Which of the following is not recommended for this patient's management?
questions.solution:
This is a typical case of ST-elevation MI (STEMI).
Since the patient has come to the hospital 24 hours after the onset of symptoms, there will be no benefit from thrombolysis.

Treatment algorithm for STEMI (ACC/AHA):





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2058.

questions.text: The inward flow pressure in the provided circuit is 100 mm Hg, while the outward flow pressure is 10 mm Hg. The resistance in each parallel circuit is 5 mm Hg/mL/min. How much current will flow via the circuit?
questions.solution:
In fluid mechanics,                                                                 
The hydraulic resistance, R is defined as the ratio of pressure drop, Pi- Po, to flow, Q. Pi is the pressure at inflow
Po is the pressure at outflow
Thus, R = (Pi -Po)/Q
Given each circuit has resistance = 5 mm Hg/mL/min.
Also for resistance in parallel
1/net resistance = 1/r1 + 1/r2 ………1/rn
Thus net resistance in the given question = 1 mm hg/ml min
Hence, by calculation for flow using ohms law, we get
Flow, Q = (100-90)/1 = 90 ml/min.


Reference: https://www.electronics-tutorials.ws/resistor/res_4.html

choices.text: Fibrous endocardial thickening of right ventricle, tricuspid valve & pulmonary valve
Endometrial thickening of tricuspid valve with severe tricuspid stenosis
Collagen rich, elastic deposits in endocardium of right ventricle and pulmonary valve

questions.text: A notable pathological revelation in carcinoid heart disease is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fibrous endocardial thickening of right ventricle, tricuspid valve & pulmonary valve
 
  • Carcinoid heart disease is associated with fibrous endocardial thickening primarily involving the right side of the heart, including the right ventricle, tricuspid valve, and pulmonary valve.
  • It is caused by the release of vasoactive substances (serotonin) from carcinoid tumors, leading to fibrosis and valve dysfunction.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 565.

questions.text: A young female patient on antidepressants arrives at the emergency department with hypotension and impaired sensory function. Wide QRS complexes and a right axis deviation are visible on the ECG. What is the best course of action for this patient's care now?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Sodium Bicarbonate.
 
  • The clinical features and ECG findings typically suggest a diagnosis of tricyclic antidepressant poisoning.
  • Treatment is primarily supportive with gastric lavage, respiratory assistance, fluid infusion, maintenance of BP and body temperature.
  • Acidosis must be corrected by sodium bicarbonate infusion given intravenously in doses of 100 mEq (1-2 mEq/kg), repeated every few minutes until BP recovers and QRS complexes start to narrow.
  • Diazepam may be injected I.V. to control convulsions and delirium.
  • Most important is the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias, for which propranolol/lidocaine may be used. 
Option 2 hemodialysis should not be used as TCAs have a significant volume of distribution and are largely protein-bound.
Option 3 Fomepezole is used as specific antidote of Methanol poisoning.
Option 4 Flumazenil is used as specific antidote of Benzodiazepine poisoning.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 487.

questions.text: A patient who was presented to the emergency department had the following ECG recorded: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Atrial fibrillation
 
  • AF is diagnosed by electrocardiogram (ECG), either by 12-lead standard ECG or limited lead ambulatory monitor ECG, with findings of lack of organized atrial activity (no P wave), with an irregular ventricular response.
 
  • Characterized by no observable P waves and a fluctuating RR interval, erratic QRS response.
 
  • The lack of coordinated atrial activity and the irregularly irregular ventricular response define the ECG in AF.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1903, 1904.

questions.text: Which of the following defines vascular system pressure in the absence of blood flow?
questions.solution:
Equilibrium pressure in the absence of flow pressure is called Mean circulatory filling pressure and is exerted by the blood volume on the whole cardiovascular circuit. When the heart is stopped, either through electrical shock or any other method, circulation ceases almost immediately and the pressures across the body become equal. This pressure is known as the mean circulatory filling pressure.


Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8458763/

questions.text: Granulomatous pathology is linked to all of the following conditions, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Polyarteritis Nodosa (Classic PAN)
 
  • Granulomatous pathology is not typically associated with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN).
  • PAN is a necrotizing vasculitis that primarily affects medium-sized arteries and does not involve small vessels.
  • It is characterized by transmural inflammation, fibrinoid necrosis, and aneurysmal formation in affected arteries.
  • Wegener's granulomatosis, Takayasu arteritis, and giant cell arteritis are examples of vasculitides that can exhibit granulomatous inflammation.
  • In Wegener's granulomatosis, necrotizing granulomas involving the respiratory tract and necrotizing vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels are typically seen.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 513.

questions.text:
In an experimental setting, an unknown drug is being tested. The obtained results are shown in the table. Which new drug is likely to result from these actions?
 
Parameter Placebo treated New Drug treated
Heart rate 72 86
Systolic BP 110 150
Diastolic BP 80 68
Tremors Absent Present
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Beta-1 and beta-2 agonist
 
  • Beta-1 stimulation increases heart rate and systolic blood pressure, because of its receptors present in the heart.
  • Beta-2 stimulation cause vasodilation by it receptors present in the blood vessels and thus decreases diastolic blood pressure and tremors.
  • Hence, the drug appears to be beta-I and beta-2 agonist. Beta 2 causes phosphorylation of calcium channels and results in palpitations (cardiac muscle) and tremors (skeletal muscle).

Reference:  Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.​​​

questions.text: Which of the following medications is not recommended for the treatment of the disease seen in the ECG below?
questions.solution:
• The ECG displays baseline variation and no P waves. Atrial Fibrillation exhibits this.
  • Except for adenosine, which is used in PSVT, Rest all of these medications are utilized in AF. 
  • Acute rate control can be achieved with beta blockers and/or the calcium channel blockers verapamil and diltiazem administered either intravenously or orally, as warranted by the urgency of the clinical situation.
  • Digoxin has been used for many years for rate control, particularly in patients susceptible to congestive heart failure, because it lacks the negative inotropic effect seen in calcium channel blockers and beta blockers.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1905.

questions.text: Which of the following defines vascular system pressure in the absence of blood flow?
questions.solution:
Equilibrium pressure in the absence of flow pressure is called Mean circulatory filling pressure and is  exerted by the blood volume on the whole cardiovascular circuit.      

 When the heart is stopped, either through electrical shock or any other method, circulation ceases almost immediately and the pressures across the body become equal. This pressure is known as the mean circulatory filling pressure.


Reference-: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8458763/

questions.text: Which of the following is the paraganglioma's most distinctive ultrastructural feature as seen under an electron microscope?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Dense core neuroendocrine granules
 
  • Paragangliomas, which are neuroendocrine tumors arising from extra-adrenal paraganglia, exhibit dense core neuroendocrine granules when examined under an electron microscope.
  • These dense core granules contain various hormones and neuropeptides that are characteristic of neuroendocrine cells.
  • The presence of dense core granules is one of the distinguishing features of neuroendocrine tumors and can aid in their identification on electron microscopy.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 746.

questions.text: Isosorbide mononitrate is given to a patient suffering from Prinzmetal's angina. In this case, what is the mechanism of action of nitrates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation
 
  • Prinzmetal Angina is due to recurrent localized (occasionally diffuse) coronary vasospasm which may be superimposed on arteriosclerotic coronary artery disease. Abnormally reactive and hypertrophied segments in the coronary arteries have been demonstrated.
  • Nitrates work by causing endothelium-independent coronary vasodilation in Prinzmetal's angina
  • Organic nitrates are broken down to produce nitric oxide (NO), which binds to guanylyl cyclase in vascular smooth muscle cells and raises the level of cyclic guanosine monophosphate, which relaxes the smooth muscle.
Option 1, 2 and 3 are useful in antianginal property of Nitric oxide.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 613.

questions.text: Breathlessness and shock were detected in a patient who had suffered a steering wheel injury to the right side of the chest. How can cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax be distinguished from one another?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Breath sounds
 
  • Cardiac Tamponade: Breath sounds are normal.
  • Tension Pneumothorax: Breath sounds are absent on the side of Pneumothorax.


Difference between Cardiac tamponade vs Tension Pneumothorax vs Massive Hemothorax: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2021, 2200.

choices.text: Bladder in the blood pressure cuff should cover more than 80% of the arm area
The person should be comfortably sitting and blood pressure cuff should be at a higher level than the heart
Caffeine intake induces decrease in blood pressure

questions.text: Which of the following statements about blood pressure measurement is correct?
questions.solution:
Following are the initial steps of BP measurement outlining the question.
a. Have the patient rest for at least 5 minutes and for 30 or more minutes after drinking coffee or smoking.
b. It is best to take readings for both arms, as the higher of the two is normally closest to the aortic pressure and is thus used to decide on treatment.
c. While the patient is either standing or seated comfortably, make sure to have the arm be placed at a heart level position with no tight clothing on the upper arm. It is also fine to measure by leaving thin clothing on.
d. The usual Riva-Rocci cuff should be 12.5 cm wide and 30-35 cm long. Make sure to have the center of the cuff fit around at least 80% of the circumference of the arm. Place the cuff over the brachial artery.

Option 4 is also false as blood pressure decreases during sleep.



Reference-: https://medlineplus.gov/lab-tests/measuring-blood-pressure/

questions.text: What is the most common cause of abdominal Aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Atherosclerosis 
 
  • Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).
  • AAA is the dilation and weakening of the abdominal aorta, the main blood vessel supplying blood to the abdomen and lower extremities.
  • Atherosclerosis, a condition characterized by the buildup of plaque in the arterial walls, increases the risk of AAA formation.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 506.

questions.text: Angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) with PPARgamma function as well is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Telmisartan 

Telmisartan has a dual function as ARB and PPAR gamma blocker.

Some special points about ARBs
  • Telmisartan and losartan have PPAR gamma blocking action
  • Telmisartan undergoes biliary excretion, can be given in CRF
  • Losartan increases Uric acid excretion (use – hypertension + gout), blocks thromboxane A2
  • Olmesartan and Candesartan are prodrugs
  • Olmesartan causes sprue like syndrome
Online Reference:
Cai W, Yang T, Liu H, Han L, Zhang K, Hu X, Zhang X, Yin KJ, Gao Y, Bennett MVL, Leak RK, Chen J. Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ): A master gatekeeper in CNS injury and repair. Prog Neurobiol. 2018 Apr-May;163-164:27-58. doi: 10.1016/j.pneurobio.2017.10.002. Epub 2017 Oct 12. PMID: 29032144; PMCID: PMC6037317.

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful in monitoring cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Central venous catheter alone is not useful for measuring cardiac output.
 
  • Cardiac output is measured by the Fick method or the thermodilution technique.
  • The Fick method uses oxygen as the indicator substance and is based on the principle that the amount of a substance taken up or released by an organ (oxygen consumption) is equal to the product of its blood flow (cardiac output) and the difference in the concentration of the substance in the arterial and venous circulation (arterial-venous oxygen difference).
  • Cardiac output can also be determined with a pulmonary artery catheter and echocardiography. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1861.

choices.text: Left atrium is compressed posteriorly by pulmonary veins
Right atrial pressure is transmitted into the pulmonary circulation

questions.text: Why is the left atrium's "v" wave larger than the right atrium's "a" wave?
questions.solution:
The v wave represents atrial filling which occurs at the end of ventricular systole, Its height is determined by the volume of blood returning to the right atrium, either antegrade from the vena cavae and/or retrograde through an incompetent TV.V wave in left atrium is higher than in right atrium because left side is high pressure system. In left sided system, muscle mass is more. So, the pressures in left sided chambers are higher than right ones.”

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 530

questions.text: Scattered, large friable plant growth on the valves.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 2) Infective Endocarditis

  • Infective endocarditis is an infection of the lining of the heart, typically caused by bacterial or fungal species, which results in the formation of vegetations (clumps of bacteria or fungi along with coagulated blood).
  • These vegetations can break away and cause embolization.
  • Acute infective endocarditis is caused by highly virulent organisms such as Staphylococcus aureus and the HACEK group (Haemophiles species, Actinobacillus species, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella species) and is typically found in intravenous drug abusers.
  • Subacute endocarditis is caused by lower virulent organisms such as viridians streptococci. Prosthetic valve endocarditis is typically caused by coagulase negative Staphylococci (e.g., Staphylococcus epidermidis). The hallmark of endocarditis is friable, bulky, destructive vegetations, which can be seen on echocardiography.
  • The diagnosis of endocarditis is based on the duke's criteria and may have associated complications, such as palms or soles (Janeway lesions), subcutaneous nodules in the pulp of the digits (Osier nodes), and retinal hemorrhages in the eyes (Roth spots).
  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis, or marantic endocarditis, is a form of nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, which is characterized by small, 1-4 mm in diameter, single or multiple, sterile, pink verrucous/warty vegetations.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 563.

choices.text: Alpha-1 agonist action leading to peripheral vasoconstriction
Increase in renal perfusion due to agonist action on D1 receptors
Releases noradrenaline and causes positive inotropic effect
Direct action on heart via beta-1 receptors

questions.text: Which of the following dopamine characteristics is not beneficial in acute shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Increase in renal perfusion due to agonist action on D1 receptors
 
  • Dopamine at low concentrations (2 to 5 mcg/kg per minute) primarily acts on vascular D1 receptors, especially in the renal, mesenteric, and coronary beds.
  • By activating adenylyl cyclase and raising intracellular concentrations of cyclic AMP, D1 receptor stimulation leads to vasodilation and reducing cardiac load. The net result is a decrease in blood pressure and an increase in cardiac contractility. 
  • Infusion of low doses of dopamine causes an increase in glomerular filtration rate and renal blood flow and Na+- K+ -ATPase pump. Increased renal perfusion and decrease in blood pressure caused by dopamine due to D1 agonism (at low doses) doesn’t improves survival in acute shock.
  • As circulating DA concentrations rise, DA is able to activate β adrenergic receptors to further increase cardiac contractility. At very high concentrations, circulating DA activates α adrenergic receptors in the vasculature, thereby causing vasoconstriction; thus, high concentrations of DA increase blood pressure, i.e, a concentration  of 10mcg/kg/min infusion.

Option 1, 3 and 4 all points towards a Vasoconstrictive action on vasculature and a positive inotropic effect on heart.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 298.

questions.text: ECG is conducted after the patient reports having recent onset breathlessness. The electrocardiogram (ECG) is presented below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• ECG shows- narrow complex tachycardia with irregular rhythm. Since P waves are seen, it rules out AF.
 
  • Different morphologies of P waves in ECG rules out sinus arrhythmia. All the above said features confirm MAT.
 
  • Absence of chest pain and significant ST elevations rules out acute myocardial infarction.
 
  • Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is a cardiac arrhythmia caused by multiple sites of competing atrial activity. It is characterized by an irregular atrial rate greater than 100 beats per minute (bpm). Atrial activity is well organized, with at least 3 morphologically distinct P waves, irregular P-P intervals, and an isoelectric baseline between the P waves.
 
  • MAT is commonly seen in COPD patients. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1901, 1902.

questions.text: Which cells of the human body are most sensitive to ischemia?
questions.solution:
Neurons are the cells of the human body that are most sensitive to ischemia, which refers to a lack of oxygen and nutrients due to decreased blood flow to a particular tissue or organ. Neurons require a constant supply of oxygen and glucose to function properly, and even a brief interruption of blood flow can cause irreversible damage. Other cells, such as nephrons in the kidneys, cardiac myocytes in the heart, and hepatocytes in the liver, are also sensitive to ischemia, but neurons are the most vulnerable

 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 134

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient who had been experiencing exertional dyspnea for the previous month presented to the OPD. He had experienced significant mitral stenosis. A prosthetic valve was used to replace his sick valve. A biopsy was taken from the removed valve. Determine the disease implicated and the typical biopsy finding.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Aschoff nodules, Rheumatic Heart disease

  • The given clinical history is suggestive of rheumatic heart disease.
  • It is an immunologically mediated multi - system disease. It is caused due to type 2 hypersensitivity reaction which usually occurs 2-3 weeks after a Beta haemolytic Streptococcal infection. This is due to molecular mimicry of Streptococcal Antigen with glycoprotein in heart and joints. In chronic rheumatic fever, patient develops mitral stenosis. Diagnosis is by Revised Jones Criteria.
  • Aschoff Bodies (Pathognomic for RHD) consists of lymphocytes, plasma cells, giant cells, fibrinoid necrosis, collagen and cells with wavy, slender, ribbon - like nucleus (Caterpillar cells/Antischkow Cells)


Fig: Microscopic appearance of an Aschoff body

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: Which action of adrenaline is not noticed when treating anaphylaxis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Action on presynaptic alpha-receptors
 
  • Adrenaline action on presynaptic alpha receptors (alpha 2) decreases its actions centrally by presynaptic inhibition and hence not helpful in management of Anaphylactic Shock.
  • The prejunctional α2 receptor activates Gi-protein which then inhibits neuronal Ca2+ channels and also limits the intracellular availability of Ca2+ by decreasing cAMP production. Transmitter (NA) release is consequently diminished. Hyperpolarization through activation of G-protein gated K+ channels may also occur.
  • The use of epinephrine in countering anaphylaxis represents functional antagonism. Functional antagonism refers to the inhibition of an agonist’s action downstream of the receptor.
  • Epinephrine increases cyclic AMP levels within bronchiolar smooth muscle cells, which in turn inhibits myosin light chain kinase and thereby diminishes the contractile response engendered by histamine, thromboxane A2, and other substances released by mast cells
  • The alpha 1 receptor agonism  by epinephrine causes vasoconstriction which counter acts the vasodilatation caused by histamine. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 145.

questions.text: A patient arrives with a history of palpitations that started suddenly. The ECG displayed a narrow complex tachycardia with a rate of 160 BPM but no "P" waves. His BP is 96/68 mm Hg. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Carotid sinus massage must be done as the next step
 
  • Clinically, the rapid nature of the palpitations and narrow complex tachycardia without obvious P Waves points to the possibility of atrioventricular re-entrant tachycardia (AVRT), the most prevalent type of SVT.
 
  • Patient is clinically stable with a systolic BP > 90 mm of Hg. Therefore, cardioversion or defibrillation are not required.
 
  • The best next step in management will be a carotid sinus massage (or any other vagal maneuver), as these can stop roughly 10–20% of AVNRTs.
  • Adenosine is still preferred over beta-blockers as a treatment for failed vagal maneuvers in patients with hemodynamic stability.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1893, 1899.

questions.text: What is the most serious complication of prolonged sitting?
questions.solution:
Following are the Complications of Prolonged sitting posture-
a. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
b. Pressure sores of the
c. Muscle contractures
d. Deconditioning of the cardiovascular system. To prevent the complication low- dose heparin or non-pharmacologic means like graduated compression stockings should be used.


 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 132

questions.text:
Shortness of breath, bilateral pedal edoema, and right upper abdominal pain are the symptoms a 45-year-old chronic smoker presents with. His JVP was discovered to be raised upon examination, and his liver is palpable 8 cm below the right costal edge.
Which heart chamber is not functioning properly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Right ventricle

  • The given signs and symptoms (pedal edema, tender hepatomegaly, raised JVP) is suggestive of right sided heart failure which is due to the inability of right ventricle to pump blood efficiently.
  • Shortness of Breath occurs due to decreased capacity of right ventricle to pump enough blood for oxygenation resulting in accumulation of blood in veins, causing dyspnea

* [Extra Edge]: Signs of right sided heart failure

—Raised JVP.

—Kussmaul sign (Rise in JVP on inspiration) 

—Tender hepatomegaly. 

—B/L pitting oedema. 

—Abdomino - Jugular reflux present.

Right sided heart failure is often caused by pulmonary heart disease (Cor Pulmonale).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 556.

choices.text: Decrease in blood pressure on adrenaline administration after phentolamine has been given

questions.text: Which of these statements best describes Dale's vasomotor reversal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Decrease in heart rate on adrenaline administration after phentolamine has been given

Adrenaline is a both alpha and beta agonist and Phentolamine is an alpha blocker.
  • Administration of epinephrine (Adrenaline) after administration of α-blockers produces only a fall in BP. This is because the α-mediated response is abolished and hence, only the β-mediated response is seen, resulting in a fall in BP. This phenomenon is called the Vasomotor reversal of Dale. 
  • Vasomotor reversal of Dale is a blockade of alpha (α1) followed by stimulation of beta (β2) receptors.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 143.

questions.text: Loud S1 in mitral stenosis is absent in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Loud S1 is present in Mild MS.
 
  • In the initial stages of the condition, the first heart sound (S1) is frequently accentuated.
  • Loud S1 in MS is independent of MS severity.
  • The anterior mitral valve leaflet's distance to return to its annular plane, leaflet mobility, left ventricular contractility, and the PR interval all affect S1 intensity.

Causes of loud S1 include:
  • Tachycardia
  • Increased AV flow
  • Prolonged AV flow
  • Short PR interval

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1991, 1992.

questions.text: Which is the best index to measure cardiac afterload?
questions.solution:
Afterload is defined mainly by Mean arterial pressure.

Cardiac output depends on both preload and afterload. The preload is defined by the venous return and left ventricular end-diastolic volume while the afterload is defined by the mean arterial pressure, which then further depends on total peripheral resistance.



Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK493174/

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman who had migrating arthritis of the lower big joints and tachycardia appeared. Murmur is Pansystolic. Mitral regurgitation is seen on an echo. What does the biopsy reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Aschoff body
 
  • Upon performing a cardiac catheterization, an endomyocardial biopsy revealed the presence of an Aschoff's body in the endocardium, confirming a clinical suspicion of active carditis.
  • Aschoff bodies are nodules that are discovered in the hearts of rheumatic fever patients. They are a defining feature of rheumatic heart disease and are caused by inflammation in the heart muscle.

Fig: Microscopic appearance of an Aschoff body

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of Rho kinase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fasudil 

  • Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitors, such as fasudil, ripasudil, and netarsudil, target the ROCK pathway, influencing smooth muscle contraction, fibrosis, and cellular motility. They are primarily used in treating glaucoma (reducing intraocular pressure) and cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid hemorrhage. They also show potential for pulmonary hypertension, fibrosis, cancer, and neurological recovery. Side effects include conjunctival hyperemia and hypotension.
  • Fasudil is an inhibitor of smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary vasospasm in experimental animals. In clinical trials in patients with CAD, it has improved performance in stress tests. It is investigational in angina.
  • Fasudil appears to reduce pulmonary artery pressure in PAH. Surgical treatment for advanced disease includes creation of a right atrial to left atrial shunt and lung transplantation.


Option 2 Ranolazine is a novel antianginal drug primarily acts by inhibiting a late Na+ current (late INa) in the myocardium which indirectly facilitates Ca2+ entry through Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.
Option 3 Amiloride block ENaCs in the luminal membrane of principal cells in late distal tubules and collecting ducts by binding to a site in the channel pore.
Option 4 Nicorandil is a dual mechanism antianginal drug activates ATP sensitive K+ channels (KATP) in smooth muscle membrane thereby hyperpolarizing and relaxing it.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 313.

questions.text: An intern saw a hypertensive patient's blood pressure readings in the right arm to be 180/100 mm Hg and the left arm to be 130/90 mm Hg during a regular follow-up. He also has an early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the following conditions has the least chance of being connected to these findings?
questions.solution:
Coarctation of aorta, Takayasu arteritis and aortic dissection can cause mid-diastolic murmur but aortic stenosis causes systolic murmur.

Causes of EDM
 
Aortic Regurgitation Backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole due to an incompetent aortic valve. High-pitched decrescendo murmur best heard at the left sternal border. Associated with bounding pulses and wide pulse pressure.
Pulmonic Regurgitation Backflow of blood from the pulmonary artery into the right ventricle due to pulmonary valve insufficiency. Low-pitched decrescendo murmur best heard at the upper left sternal border.
Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) Left-to-right shunt increases flow across the mitral valve, creating a diastolic murmur. Increased flow due to the shunt leads to turbulent flow during diastole.
Tricuspid Regurgitation Backflow of blood from the right ventricle to the right atrium during diastole due to a faulty tricuspid valve. Early diastolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border, accentuated with inspiration.
Aortic Root Dilatation Dilatation of the aortic root causes aortic regurgitation, leading to backflow of blood into the left ventricle. Murmur caused by regurgitant flow through the aortic valve.
Pulmonary Hypertension Increased pressure in the pulmonary artery causes pulmonic regurgitation. Diastolic murmur due to increased backflow through the pulmonic valve.
 
Causes of Unequal BP- 
Coarctation of aorta
Takayasu arteritis
 Aortic dissection



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1981.

questions.text: Which is the second messenger for smooth muscle relaxation mediated by NO?
questions.solution:
cGMP is the second messenger for NO.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 584

questions.text:
While running, one athlete fell and passed away instantly. The heart's autopsy region is shown.
Which of the following statements about the condition is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sudden cardiac death due to arrhythmia
 
  • This is a case of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM). The most common cause of death is ventricular arrythmia.
  • Major clinical problems in HCM are atrial fibrillation, mural thrombus formation leading to embolization and possible stroke, intractable cardiac failure, ventricular arrhythmias, and, not infrequently, sudden death, especially with certain mutations.
  • Indeed, HCM is one of the most common causes of sudden, otherwise unexplained death in young athletes.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 573.

questions.text: Which medication exhibits Q-T Prolongation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Quinidine
 
  • Quinidine blocks Na+ current and multiple cardiac K+ currents. It is an open-state blocker of Na+ channels, with a τ recovery in the intermediate range. Thus, after therapeutic dosages, QRS duration increases modestly, usually by 10% to 20%.
  • At therapeutic concentrations, quinidine commonly prolongs the QT interval up to 25%, but the effect is highly variable.
  • Drugs causing QTc prolongation - 
  • Category Drugs
    Antiarrhythmics (Class 1a & 3) Quinidine, Procainamide, Disopyramide, Amiodarone, Sotalol, Dofetilide, Ibutilide
    Antibiotics Erythromycin, Clarithromycin, Levofloxacin, Ciprofloxacin, Moxifloxacin
    Antifungals Fluconazole, Itraconazole, Voriconazole
    Antipsychotics Haloperidol, Quetiapine, Risperidone, Olanzapine, Ziprasidone
    Antidepressants Amitriptyline, Imipramine, Citalopram, Escitalopram
    Antiemetics Ondansetron, Granisetron, Domperidone
    Other Drugs Methadone, Chloroquine, Hydroxychloroquine, Lithium, Tacrolimus
Other options: -
2. Amiodarone- class 3 antiarrythmic drug blocks potassium channel, causes QT prolongation but lesser than quinidine.
3. Magnesium sulfate is used in treatment of Torsa des depointes
4. Lignocaine - class 1b antiarryhmic drug doesn't cause QT prolongation 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 572.

questions.text: What is the following ECG's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This is a classical ECG showing Ventricular Bigeminy as distinct 2 morphologies of QRS complex could be seen.
     
  • In Ventricular bigeminy, every alternate QRS is a PVC.
  • It is seen in digoxin toxicity.

Electrical alternans would have variable amplitude of qRS but not as distinct 2 morphologies. Here's an image given below:

questions.text: What are the characteristics of neurogenic shock?
questions.solution:
Neurogenic shock: In addition to arteriolar dilation, venodilation causes pooling in the venous system, which decreases venous return and cardiac output." Interruption of sympathetic vasomotor input after a high cervical spinal cord injury, inadvertent cephalad migration of spinal anesthesia, or devastating head injury may result in neurogenic shock. The extremities are often warm, in contrast to the usual sympathetic vasoconstriction-induced coolness in hypovolemic or cardiogenic shock

 

Reference: Online Resource https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459361/

questions.text: Which of these is characteristic of serum-ascites albumin gradient-high ascites?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) CHF
 
  • The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is a measure used to differentiate the causes of ascites (fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity).
  • A high SAAG (>1.1 g/dL) is typically associated with portal hypertension.
  • Conditions associated with a high SAAG include liver cirrhosis, alcoholic hepatitis, and congestive heart failure (CHF).
  • CHF leads to elevated venous pressure, which can cause fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity (ascites).


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 323.

questions.text: What exactly is Sacubitril?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Neutral endopeptidase inhibitor

* Sacubitril: -
  • It is an example of Neprilysin / Neutral endopeptidase inhibitor 
  • Mechanism of action: - It prevents the degradation of Bradykinin, Natriuretic Peptides, Angiotensin II, Substance P which  leads to increase in vasodilation and thereby decrease in ECF volume.
  • Use: - Used in combination with Valsartan to treat Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction
  • Adverse effects: - Hypotension, Cough (Due to increase in levels of Bradykinin)
  • Contraindications: - It is contraindicated with ACE inhibitors since both drugs increase the level of Bradykinin
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 553.

questions.text: Which of the following is a treatment option for heart failure in alternative medicine?
questions.solution:
• Terminalia arjuna is comparable to nitroglycerine in that it helps to relax the coronary arteries and thus, increase blood flow and oxygen supply. This, in turn, results in an increase in exercise capacity and relief from angina pains.
     
  • Additionally, Terminalia arjuna has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties that help protect the heart from damage. It may also help to regulate cholesterol levels and reduce the risk of atherosclerosis which is another factor contributing to angina and other forms of heart disease.
 
  • Patients with ischemic cardiomyopathy showed significant symptomatic relief in coronary heart failure from NYHA class III to class I.
 
  • Ultimately, the ingestion of Terminalia arjuna may have effects similar to those obtained when using nitroglycerine for the relief of angina and increasing exercise capacity.



Reference: Dwivedi, S, and R Jauhari. “Beneficial effects of Terminalia arjuna in coronary artery disease.” Indian heart journal vol. 49,5 (1997): 507-10. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9505018/
