Mean arterial pressure, which is responsible for blood flow to an organ

questions.text: Which is the best indicator for peripheral resistance?
questions.solution:
Peripheral resistance is best indicated by Diastolic blood pressure.

The diastolic component of blood pressure is made up of peripheral resistance, which regulates peripheral blood supply due to the opening of conduction vessels during left ventricular diastole. As a result, an increase in systemic resistance leads to an increase in diastolic blood pressure.




Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538308/

questions.text: Among the following, which has the most friable vegetation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Infective endocarditis
 
  • Friable vegetation refers to fragile and easily breakable growths on heart valves, commonly observed in infective endocarditis.
  • Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the endocardium, typically caused by bacteria.
  • The vegetations in infective endocarditis consist of fibrin, platelets, microorganisms, and inflammatory cells, and they can become large and friable.
* [Extra Edge]: Other options
  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis is a nonbacterial form of endocarditis associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), but the vegetations are usually small and non-friable.
  • Rheumatic heart disease is a consequence of rheumatic fever and can lead to valvular damage, but the vegetations are typically firm rather than friable.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 562.

questions.text: You shouldn't take tadalafil with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Vasodilator
 
  • Tadalafil markedly potentiates the vasodilator action of nitrates and precipitous fall in BP, MI can occur.
  • Tadalafil is contraindicated in patients of coronary heart disease and those taking nitrates. Though sildenafil remains effective for <8 hours, it is advised that nitrates be avoided for 24 hours.
  • Tadalafil is an example of PDE5 inhibitor. Inhibition of Phosphodiesterase leads to increased levels of cGMP. Drugs like Tadalafil, Sildenafil thus leads to vasodilation, flushing, smooth muscle relaxation, tachycardia.
  • Hence Tadalafil should not be combined with other vasodilator drugs.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 328.

choices.text: 9L arrived at the blood bank for platelet apheresis for the first time. He had circumoral numbness and paresthesias during

questions.text:
A young donor with a platelet count of 1.9L arrived at the blood bank for platelet apheresis for the first time. He had circumoral numbness and paresthesias during
the course of the donation. But his vital signs are still steady. Tachycardia with ST-T alterations was seen on the ECG. What is the cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Clinical signs of paresthesias, circumoral numbness, and an ECG with tachycardia and ST-T alterations are strongly suggestive of Hypocalcemia brought on by a protracted citrated blood transfusion.
 
  • Citrate chelates calcium and suppresses the coagulation cascade, which is why it is frequently used to anticoagulate blood components.
 
  • Multiple quick transfusions can cause hypocalcemia, which shows up as circumoral numbness and/or tingling in the fingers and toes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 358.

choices.text: Immediately increase in venous return to heart
Decreased blood flow to the apex of lung

questions.text: Which of the following takes place when a standing person lies down?
questions.solution:
When a standing person lies down, there is an immediate increase in venous return. This happens due to the removal of the effect of gravity.

Other options:- 

  • Cerebral blood flow remains constant 
  • Blood flow to apex of lung increases 
  • Heart rate decreases
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 534

questions.text: What exactly does C-ANCA positivity refer to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Wegener's Granulomatosis
 
  • C-ANCA (cytoplasmic antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody) positivity refers to the presence of specific antibodies targeting neutrophil cytoplasmic antigens.
  • It is most commonly associated with Wegener's granulomatosis, a systemic autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of blood vessels in multiple organs.
  • C-ANCA antibodies primarily target proteinase 3 (PR3), an enzyme found in neutrophil granules.
  • The detection of C-ANCA antibodies in a patient's blood is an important diagnostic marker for Wegener's granulomatosis.
ANCA Memorizing trick:- 
PCM- p-ANCA- Churg's Strauss, Microscopic polyangitis 
c-ANCA- Wegener's 






Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 514.

questions.text: Under what condition does Theophylline cause diuresis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Adenosine A1 receptor antagonism

  • Remember TEA - Theophylline - Enzyme inhibitor (PDE) - Adenosine A1 Receptor inhibitor, and is found in tea and coffee
  • Because of PDE inhibition - smooth muscle relaxation - Bronchodialation occurs - hence can be used in the treatment of status asthmaticus
  • Theophylline is an Adenosine receptor antagonist, meaning it blocks the binding of adenosine, a neurotransmitter, to A1 and A2a receptors located throughout the body. 
  • The A1 receptor is expressed in the proximal tubule and stimulates reabsorption of Na+. Consequently, antagonists of A1 receptors cause diuresis/natriuresis.
  • S/E due to Adenosine A1 R antagonism - Insomnia, seizures, tachypnea, tachycardia, Diuresis, Nausea and Vomiting (most common)

Option 1, 4 PDE3 and PDE4 are likely account for the bronchodilator action of theophylline which is involve in PDE inhibition and the concomitant elevation of cellular cAMP and cyclic GMP.
Option 3 there is no B2 agonist action of Theophylline.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 572.

questions.text: Which scientific principle is the basis for thermodilution method used in measurement of cardiac output by Pulmonary Catheter?
questions.solution:
• The Stewart-Hamilton equation is the foundational element of the thermodilution technique applied to measure cardiac output using a pulmonary catheter.
 
  • The indicator dilution technique has become the de-facto clinical standard for measuring cardiac output due to its simplicity and extensive past usage in multiple contexts.

 
  • This technique requires injecting a known quantity of a substance into a peripheral vein and then monitoring the alteration of its concentration in repeat arterial sampling. 



Reference: Argueta, Erwin E MD*; Paniagua, David MD†. Thermodilution Cardiac Output: A Concept Over 250 Years in the Making. Cardiology in Review 27(3):p 138-144, May/June 2019. | DOI: 10.1097/CRD.0000000000000223. URL: https://journals.lww.com/cardiologyinreview/fulltext/2019/05000/thermodilution_cardiac_output__a_concept_over_250.5.aspx

questions.text: What is the effect on end systolic volume (ESV) during exercise in physiological limits?
questions.solution:
Exercising leads to an increase in venous return to the heart, resulting in higher end-diastolic volume, but the greater contractility of the heart and elevated stroke volume offset this increase and cause the end-systolic volume to decrease.

 

Reference-: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page 308-309

questions.text: What does the needle-shaped void on the histopathology slide of an atheromatous plaque signify?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cholesterol Cleft
 
  • The needle-shaped void on the histopathology slide of an atheromatous plaque signifies a cholesterol cleft.
  • Cholesterol clefts are characteristic histological findings in atherosclerotic plaques.
  • Cholesterol clefts result from the deposition of cholesterol crystals in the necrotic core of the plaque.
  • These crystals are derived from the hydrolysis of cholesterol esters by enzymes such as cholesterol esterase.

Fig: Cholesterol Clefts

Online Reference: Shah N, Nagalli S. Cholesterol Emboli. [Updated 2024 Jan 23]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK556091/

questions.text: Select the antiarrhythmic drug which needs to be avoided in a patient with Interstitial lung diseases
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Amiodarone
 
  • Amiodarone is a drug used to treat arrhythmias and is associated with a number of dose dependent pulmonary side effects, including interstitial lung disease (ILD), Pulmonary alveolitis and fibrosis.
  • The most serious adverse effect during chronic amiodarone therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which can be rapidly progressive and fatal.
  • Underlying lung disease, doses of 400 mg/d or more, and recent pulmonary insults such as pneumonia, ILD appear to be risk factors.
  • Thus, Amiodarone needs to be avoided in a patient with Interstitial lung diseases.
  • Serial chest X-rays or pulmonary function studies may detect early amiodarone toxicity but monitoring plasma concentrations has not been useful.
  • With low doses, such as 200 mg/d or less as used in AF, pulmonary toxicity is less common.
Option 2, 3 and 4 Drugs doesn't have any known contraindication to be used in a patient of ILD
 

Drugs that can cause lung fibrosis (drug-induced interstitial lung disease) include:

Category Examples
Chemotherapeutics Bleomycin, Busulfan, Methotrexate, Cyclophosphamide
Antiarrhythmics Amiodarone
Antibiotics Nitrofurantoin, Sulfasalazine
Biologics TNF-alpha inhibitors (e.g., Etanercept, Infliximab)
Immunosuppressants Sirolimus, Everolimus

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 578.

questions.text: Cardiomegaly was discovered in a woman who had cold intolerance and hoarseness of voice. What investigation needs to be done to determine the cause?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is of dysphagia lusoria, i.e. hoarsness of voice due to RLN compression by enlarged left ventricle. 
  • Echocardiography is a noninvasive imaging test that uses sound waves to produce images of the heart and its surrounding structures.
  • It is useful in detecting enlargements of the heart, which is an indicator of cardiomegaly. With echocardiography, doctors can evaluate the size and shape of the heart and the thickness of the heart walls.
  • It can detect any obstructions in the blood flow, changes in the heart valves, and other abnormalities.
  • The images can then help in determining the underlying cause of cardiomegaly and in creating an effective treatment plan.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1832, 1833.

choices.text: Slow filling at the end of diastole

questions.text: The JVP waveform is used to assess the status of the right side of the heart and is helpful in diagnosing various cardiovascular conditions. When are C waves in JVP visible?
questions.solution:
When observing the JVP waveform, there are several waves and descents that can be identified: A wave (Atrial contraction): This is the first positive wave seen in the JVP waveform. It corresponds to atrial contraction, which occurs just before ventricular systole (contraction). The A wave reflects the increased pressure caused by blood flowing into the right atrium during atrial contraction. X descent (Atrial relaxation): After the A wave, there is a downward descent known as the X descent. This descent is caused by the relaxation of the right atrium, which results in decreased pressure in the jugular vein. C wave (Isovolumic ventricular contraction): The C wave is a small upward deflection that occurs shortly after the A wave. It represents a slight increase in pressure in the right atrium caused by the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the atrium during isovolumic ventricular contraction. X' descent (Ventricular ejection): Following the C wave, there is a rapid descent known as the X' descent. It is caused by the downward movement of the tricuspid valve as the right ventricle contracts and ejects blood into the pulmonary artery. V wave (Venous filling): The V wave is a large positive wave that occurs after the X' descent. It represents the filling of blood into the right atrium from the peripheral veins during systole. The V wave is often prominent in conditions such as tricuspid regurgitation or right-sided heart failure. Y descent (Rapid ventricular filling): The Y descent is a downward slope that follows the V wave. It represents the rapid ventricular filling phase, during which the tricuspid valve opens and blood flows from the right atrium to the right ventricle.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 530

questions.text: Except for______, each of the following statements concerning Anitschkow cells is accurate.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Pathognomonic of Rheumatic Heart Disease 
 
  • Anitschkow cells, also known as Aschoff cells, are modified cardiac histiocytes and are characteristic of rheumatic heart disease.
  • Anitschkow cells are large cells with a central, wavy, or rod-like nucleus (caterpillar appearance) when observed in longitudinal section.
  • In transverse sections, they show a characteristic "owl's eye" appearance due to the folding and condensation of the nucleus.
  • While Anitschkow cells are strongly associated with rheumatic heart disease, they are not pathognomonic and can also be seen in other inflammatory conditions.

Fig: Aschoff Body

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: Name the principal late inward sodium channel blocker.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ranolazine
 
  • Ranolazine is a late inward sodium channel blocker, meaning that it can be used to reduce the influx of sodium ions into the cell by blocking the late inward sodium currents.
  • This property can be used to prevent arrhythmias, as excessive influx of sodium can lead to abnormal electrical signals that trigger arrhythmia.
  • Furthermore, ranolazine can reduce the excitability of the ventricular myocardium, decreasing heart rate and lowering the amount of oxygen used by the heart. This can help reduce the symptoms of angina and reduce the risk of ischemic heart failure.
Trick:-
RaNolazine- Na+ channel blocker

Option 1 Ivabradine is a selective blocker of hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide–gated (HCN) ion channels involved in the generation of automaticity in the SA node.
Option 3 Trimetazidine is a partial fatty acid oxidase (PFOX) inhibitor that prevents cardiac tissue from oxidizing free fatty acids (major source of ATP in heart).
Option 4 Fasudil is a selective RhoA/Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor that appears to reduce pulmonary artery pressure in PAH.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 600.

questions.text: Midsystolic click is heard in a female. Pathology seen in mitral valve is:
questions.solution:
• It appears that the clinical signs indicated in the question point to Mitral Valve Prolapse Syndrome (MVP).In the event of an inspection of the cells and tissues, a myxomatous degeneration and the falling back of the mitral valve are likely results to be seen in Mitral Valve Prolapse Syndrome.
 
  • Mitral valve prolapse syndrome is a condition in which the mitral valve, which separates the upper and lower chambers of the heart, bulges abnormally into the left atrium. It is the most common form of heart valve disorder.

 
  • Symptoms of mitral valve prolapse range from no symptoms to a wide variety of uncomfortable symptoms and can include chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Other common symptoms may include dizziness, fainting, anxiety, dry cough, and significant fatigue.
  • Patients may also suffer from a palpitation when the mitral valve fails to close properly and a murmur may be heard. In some cases, mitral valve prolapse can cause a leak in the valve, leading to even greater issues such as heart arrhythmia and congestive heart failure.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2000.

questions.text: There is a______in hypovolemic shock.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Afferent arteriolar constriction In hypovolemic shock, the body compensates for volume loss by increasing heart rate and contractility, followed by baroreceptor activation resulting in sympathetic nervous system activation and peripheral vasoconstriction. Thus renal blood flow and gfr also decreases. Afferent arteriolar constriction —> decreased gfr —> less fluid loss in urine.This way the blood is shunted towards the heart in c/o shock. Options 2 and 3 are incorrect as efferent arteriolar constriction will result into increased gfr and loss of fluid furthermore. Renal blood flow is decrease and not increased by peripheral vasoconstriction. Option 4 : as effective circulating blood volume is reduced, CO also decreases. Grading of Hypovolemic Shock

 

Reference-:Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 27th Edition Page nos 13,14

questions.text: What is Bilateral upper limb pulseless disease is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Takayasu Arteritis
 
  • Takayasu Arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects large vessels, including the aorta and its major branches.
  • It commonly affects young females and leads to stenosis, occlusion, or aneurysmal dilation of affected vessels.
  • The involvement of the subclavian arteries can cause upper limb pulselessness, known as "pulseless disease."
  • Other features of Takayasu Arteritis include systemic symptoms, such as fever and fatigue, hand claudications, and symptoms related to the affected organs or regions.
VASCULITIS:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 512.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a drug related to heart failure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Trimetazidine
 
  • Trimetazidine is a partial fatty acid oxidase (PFOX) inhibitor that prevents cardiac tissue from oxidizing free fatty acids (major source of ATP in heart). In order to generate ATP, the heart therefore adjusts by boosting glycolysis. Since glycolysis requires less oxygen than other metabolic processes, there is a significant reduction in myocellular oxygen demand.
  • There is no effect on determinants of myocardial O2 consumption, such as HR and BP, both at rest as well as during exercise, but angina frequency is reduced, and exercise capacity is increased.
  • Thus Trimetazidine is an anti-anginal drug and not used in heart failure.

Option 1 Nesiritide, a BNP analog that has been approved for the treatment of resistant pulmonary edema associated with acute CHF.
Option 3 Sacubitril, a neutral endopeptidase inhibitor, is approved for use in conjunction with valsartan to treat chronic CHF.
Option 4 Metoprolol if introduced gradually and maintained for long term, can retard the progression of CHF and prolong life. The benefit may result from antagonism of delete­rious effects of sympathetic overactivity (invoked reflexly by heart failure) on the myocardium.

A frequent area of questions is regarding drugs with mortality benefit in treatment of Heart failure, remember the 2 D's - Digoxin and Diuretics do not have mortality benefit in maintainance treatment of CHF. the drugs having mortality benefit in their descending order are given below, with the best being Beta blockers.
Rank Drug Class Examples
1 Beta-Blockers Bisoprolol, Carvedilol, Metoprolol Succinate
2 ARNI (Angiotensin Receptor-Neprilysin Inhibitor) Sacubitril/Valsartan 
3 ACE Inhibitors (ACEi) Enalapril, Lisinopril (if ARNI not available)
4 Mineralocorticoid Receptor Antagonists (MRA) Spironolactone, Eplerenone
5 SGLT2 Inhibitors Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 599.

questions.text: Streptokinase and warfarin are given to a patient who has transmural thrombi. After which further testing should thrombolysis be stopped?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Pericardial Effusion
 
  • Fibrinolytics and anticoagulants can be continued in case of pericarditis, however, once significant pericardial effusion develops after MI, fibrinolytics should be discontinued.
  • The risk of post MI pericardial effusion is not increased with the use of fibrinolytic agents, heparin, aspirin and other antiplatelet agents.
  • In contrast, a pericardial effusion occurring in the setting of MI is an indication to discontinue anticoagulation and fibrinolytics.
  • As soon as pericardial effusion is established by echocardiography, emergency percutaneous pericardiocentesis should be performed at 20 +/- 6 h after thrombolytic therapy was started.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2056, 2020.
Renkin J, de Bruyne B, Benit E, Joris JM, Carlier M, Col J. Cardiac tamponade early after thrombolysis for acute myocardial infarction: a rare but not reported hemorrhagic complication. J Am Coll Cardiol. 1991 Jan;17(1):280-5. doi: 10.1016/0735-1097(91)90739-v. PMID: 1898952. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1898952/

questions.text: The following descriptions of bronchial circulation are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Contribute to gaseous exchange The pulmonary circulation is responsible for oxygenating the blood and removing carbon dioxide, while the bronchial circulation which is a part of systemic circulation supplies the lung tissue with oxygen and nutrients necessary for its function. It constitutes 2% of systemic circulation and takes part in venous admixing in arterial blood. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 615,616

questions.text: What among the following is a "Small Vessel Vasculitis"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Microscopic polyangiitis
 
  • Microscopic Polyangiitis is a systemic vasculitis affecting small blood vessels, including arterioles, capillaries, and venules.
  • It is characterized by necrotizing inflammation of vessel walls, without granulomatous inflammation.
  • The term "microscopic" refers to the involvement of small vessels, which can be visualized microscopically.
  • Other forms of small vessel vasculitis include Henoch-Schönlein Purpura (HSP) and Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA), which involve granulomatous inflammation.
Vasculitis Memorizing Trick: -
Large vessel- GT road is the largest road- Giant cell arteritis and Takayasu arteritis
Medium Vessel- PK- PAN and Kawasaki 
Rest are small vessel vasculitis

VASCULITIS:


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 513.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions calls for the use of inhaled nitric oxide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Pulmonary hypertension
 

  • Nitric Oxide inhalation dilates pulmonary vessels, resulting in decreased pulmonary vascular resistance and reduced pulmonary artery pressure.

  • Inhaled Nitric Oxide also improves oxygenation by reducing mismatch of ventilation and perfusion in the lung.

* Mechanism of Action:

Nitric oxide (NO) activates cytosolic soluble guanylyl cyclase → increased cGMP → causes dephosphorylation of myosin light chain kinase (MLCK) through a cGMP dependent protein kinase (PKG) → Reduced availability of phosphorylated (active) MLCK interferes with activation of myosin → it fails to interact with actin to cause contraction → Relaxation occurs.

* Indications: 

  • Therapeutic: The FDA has only approved chronic pulmonary neonatal hypertension as the use of inhaled NO. 

  • Diagnostic: During cardiac catheterization, inhaled NO can be utilized to assess the ability of patients with heart failure and newborns with congenital heart disease to dilate their blood vessels in the lungs to ascertain the alveolar-capillary unit's diffusion capacity (DL).

Option 1, 2 and 3 doesn't have an indication to use Inhaled nitric oxide.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 344.

questions.text: Determine the diagnosis based on the ECG below:
questions.solution:
• The ECG seen above is often observed in a 2:1 heart block, a kind of second-degree "fixed ratio" AV nodal block.
 
  • It develops when every other P wave is NOT followed by a QRS complex because the P wave is not passed by the AV node to reach the ventricles.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1881, 1883, 1924.

choices.text: Increase in the number of open capillaries
Sympathetically mediated greater distensibility of pulmonary vessels
Large amount of smooth muscle in pulmonary arteries

questions.text: During vigorous exercise, pulmonary arterial pressure barely rises but cardiac output (CO) increases up to fivefold. The best explanation for this physiological property of the pulmonary circulation is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Increase in the number of open capillaries During exercise the demand for O2 increases drastically. By opening more capillaries, the surface area available for gas exchange increases, allowing for a greater amount of oxygen to be taken up from the alveoli into the blood and a larger amount of carbon dioxide to be released from the blood into the alveoli for exhalation. Option 2 - Sympathetic activation can cause vasoconstriction in systemic circulation to redirect blood flow to the working muscles during exercise, but it does not play a significant role in regulating pulmonary vascular resistance. Option 3 – large amount of smooth muscles can constrict or dilate the arteries up to some extent but it’s not the primary mechanism. Option 4 – it is incorrect as the surface area for pulmonary circulation is actually very large.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 615,616

questions.text: Clopidogrel was given to a patient who had suffered an ischemic stroke. He experienced another stroke episode even after six months of therapy. Which of the following describes clopidogrel's failure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) CYP2C19 inhibition
 
  • Clopidogrel is a prodrug only 50% of the ingested drug is absorbed, out of this only a fraction is activated in the liver by two step metabolism into an active thiol metabolite via CYP2CI9.
  • CYP2C19 inhibition by proton pump inhibitors (e.g., omeprazole, lansoprazole, dexlansoprazole, and pantoprazole) may reduce conversion to the active metabolite of clopidogrel, which may contribute to the lower efficacy of clopidogrel when coadministered with proton pump inhibitors.
  • Since CYP2C19, exhibits genetic polymorphism, the activation of clopidogrel and consequently its antiplatelet action shows high interindividual variability. Some patients are nonresponsive.
* Mechanism of action
Clopidogrel reduces ADP-induced aggregation by inhibiting the P2Y12 receptors on the surface of platelets. This Gi-coupled GPCR inhibits adenylyl cyclase and lowers cAMP. It permanently reduces platelet function.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 678.

questions.text: Continuous murmur cannot be heard in:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. VSD with aortic regurgitation
 
  • A continuous murmur is predicated on a pressure gradient that persists between two cardiac chambers or blood vessels across systole and diastole. The murmurs typically begin in systole, envelop the second heart sound (S2), and continue through some portion of diastole.
 
  • The classic example of a continuous murmur is that associated with a PDA, which usually is heard in the second or third interspace at a slight distance from the sternal border.
 
  • Other causes of a continuous murmur include a ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm with creation of an aortic–right atrial or right ventricular fistula, a coronary or great vessel arteriovenous fistula, and an arteriovenous fistula constructed to provide dialysis access.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1822.

questions.text: Venous return to heart during quiet standing is not facilitated by which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Gravitational increase in arterial pressure

Arterial pressure increases while standing but it does not facilitate venous return, instead it decreases it by causing venous congestion. All the other 3 options play a role in increasing venous return while standing.



 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 570

questions.text: Resistant hypertension occurs when blood pressure is not controlled despite the use of three types of antihypertensive medicines. Which of the following classes of medications must the patient be taking to meet the criteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Diuretics
 

  • Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains high despite the use of 3 different classes of anti-hypertensives, one of which must be a diuretic. Especially Thiazide group of diuretic. 
  • The underlying cause of resistant hypertension is increased production of aldosterone. The drug of choice for resistant hypertension is spironolactone.

Here is an updated table with the treatment strategies for each type of hypertension:

Type Definition Treatment
Resistant Hypertension Blood pressure remains above target despite the use of 3 antihypertensive drugs, including a diuretic, at optimal doses. Optimize medication (adding spironolactone). 
Refractory Hypertension Extremely difficult to control blood pressure despite 5 or more drugs, including a diuretic. Consider renal denervation
Hypertensive Emergency Severe hypertension (>180/120 mmHg) with acute target organ damage (e.g., stroke, heart failure, renal failure). Intravenous antihypertensive agents (e.g., nitroprusside, labetalol, nicardipine) to rapidly lower blood pressure under close monitoring.
Hypertensive Urgency Severe hypertension (>180/120 mmHg) without acute target organ damage. Oral antihypertensive agents (e.g., labetalol, captopril, clonidine) to lower blood pressure gradually over hours to days.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 616.

questions.text: A P wave greater than _____ indicates a persistent right atrial overload.
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. 2.5 mm 
 
  • Right atria chronic overload or acute overload is indicated by P wave of more than 2.5 mm.
  • The electrical signal for atrial depolarization originates at the sinus node and then spreads from the right to the left atrium, resulting in a downward and left-pointing vector in the electrocardiogram (ECG).
  • This vector is recorded in leads I and aVR as positive and negative, respectively. Normal p wave is less than 2.5mm in lead II. If it is more than 2.5, this indicate right atrial overload.


Reference: Douedi S, Douedi H. P wave. [Updated 2023 Jul 24]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK551635/

questions.text: The following is not an action of Bradykinin:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Bronchodilation Effects of bradykinin Vasodilation Contraction of smooth muscle (Bronchoconstriction) Vascular leakage Pain

questions.text: A man arrives at the OPD with a history of falling. He is hypertensive with a history of atrial fibrillation and is currently taking captopril, atenolol, aspirin, and amiodarone. As indicated in the graphic, he offers the following findings. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Amiodarone induced skin lesion   

  • The given image shows a bluish discoloration of skin of face. It is a common side effect associated with long term use of Amiodarone.
  • Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug used in the treatment of atrial fibrillation.
  • The skin deposits result in a photodermatitis and a gray-blue skin discoloration in sun-exposed areas, the malar regions.
Option 1 Lupus pernio is a characteristic sign present in chronic Sarcoidosis. Rashes involved Raised skin lesions not maculopapular rashes.
Option 2 Captopril Toxicity may lead to allergic maculopapular skin rashes, but the malar gray blue skin discoloration described in the image is characteristic of Amiodarone.
Option 4 Silver toxicity also known as Argyria is a condition where deposits of silver build up in your body at toxic levels. This causes your skin and nails to turn bluish gray, but the Clinical scenario given in the above question has nothing to do with silver toxicity.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not a major criteria in acute rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
According to Modified Jones criteria, Major criteria include- Polyarthritis, myocarditis, subcutaneous nodules, erythema Nodosum and Sydenham's chorea. While Polyarthalgia comes in minor criteria in Low risk population.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2769.

questions.text: Which receptors does endothelin act through?
questions.solution:
Endothelin amongst other hormones acts via IP3-DAG pathway(Gq) that leads to Ca++ influx and contraction.

Trick :- All hormones related to contraction act via IP3-DAG pathway as Ca++ is required for contraction of smooth muscle. Ex:- Angiotensin II, Oxytocin, Endothelin.

Reference- https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/neuroscience/endothelin-receptor

questions.text: An individual was receiving metoprolol treatment for hypertension. VERAPAMIL was also given to him. With the aforementioned combo therapy, which of the following is most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Bradycardia with AV block 
 
  • Among the following bradycardia with AV block are likely to happen with the above combination therapy.
  • Verapamil and metoprolol (beta-blocker) show drug interaction and result in precipitation of bradycardia and AV block since both have inhibitory action on AV node and oppose positive inotropic action.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 561.

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic man with palpitations arrives at the AIIMS emergency department. Systolic blood pressure was 70 mm Hg at the time of assessment. His ECG was recorded in an emergency and is shown below. What is the management's next most important step?
questions.solution:
• The ECG is showing narrow complex tachycardia with absent P-waves with regular R-R interval. The patient is likely to be having paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).
 
  • Since the patient is in shock with hypotension, electrical cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.
 
  • Drug of choice for PSVT is Adenosine but it is to be used in hemodynamically stable patients.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1898, 1899.

questions.text: Which of the following is increased by nitric oxide?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: cGMP

NO released by a group of enzymes called NO synthases from endothelial cells of blood vessels ————> it binds to and activates the enzyme guanylate cyclase —————> guanylate cyclase converts guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cGMP —————> cGMP regulates numerous physiological processes, including smooth muscle relaxation, platelet aggregation, neurotransmission.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 55

questions.text: Which of the following medications should a patient taking rosuvastatin therapy avoid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Clarithromycin

Clarithromycin should be avoided in a patient on rosuvastatin therapy.
  • Inhibition of OATP1B1 by Clarithromycin reduces tissue uptake of rosuvastatin.
  • The overall result is an increase in systemic plasma levels of rosuvastatin, which may result in increased susceptibility to statin-induced myopathy.
  • Efficacy will depend upon the net effect on hepatic levels of rosuvastatin, driven by the lower hepatic uptake via OATP1B1 inhibition.
* All statins, except rosuvastatin are metabolized primarily by CYP3A4.
* Metabolism of Rosuvastatin is mainly done through BCRP and OATP1B1.

Option 2, 3 and 4 Drugs doesn't have any known role in inducing or inhibiting Rosuvastatin metabolism.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 160.

questions.text: A 76-year-old male patient who has been experiencing retrosternal chest pain for six hours comes to the AIIMS emergency room. The next EKG was recorded. What is going to be your main line of management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows STEMI and onset of symptom is 6 hours so PCI is the best possible intervention.
PCI could be done upto 24 hours. Ideal door to balloon time is 90 minutes.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2058, 2059.

choices.text: Bulging of tricuspid valve during the isovolumetric contraction phase

questions.text: JVP with C wave is due to
questions.solution:
The C wave of the jugular venous pulse (JVP) is created by the bulging of the tricuspid valve during ventricular systole, when the right ventricle contracts. As the right ventricle contracts, the tricuspid valve is forced open, allowing the blood to flow through the tricuspid valve into the right atrium. The increase in pressure in the right atrium causes the jugular vein to bulge and create the C wave of the JVP.

The jugular venous pulse (JVP) is observed to look different due to factors such as changes in the heart rate, respiratory rate, and intrathoracic pressure. Waves in the JVP include the a wave, c wave, v wave, and x and y descents. The a wave is caused by right atrial contraction, the c wave is related to the bulging of the tricuspid valve, the v wave is related to filling of the right atrium, and the x and y descents are attributed to the relaxation of the right atrium/tricuspid valve.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 530

questions.text: Identify the drug that can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic overdose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Epsilon amino caproic acid

Epsilon amino caproic acid can be used as an antidote for fibrinolytic overdose. 

* Mechanism of action- Being a lysine analogue, it combines with the lysin binding site of plasminogen and plasmin. As a result, plasmin is unable to bind to fibrinogen and lyse it. 

* Indication-
  • It is a specific antidote for fibrinolytic agents and has been used in many hyperplasminemic states associated with excessive intravascular fibrinolysis resulting in bleeding.
  • The primary indication of EACA is to counteract the effect of fibrinolytic drugs and bleeding due to their use.
  • In hemophiliacs, it has adjunctive value for controlling bleeding due to tooth extraction, prostatectomy, trauma, etc.
Following are the antidotes that are used in case of fibrinolytic agent overdose
  • Epsilon amino caproic acid
  • Tranexamic acid
Option 1 Ethamsylate reduces capillary bleeding when platelets are adequate; probably corrects abnormalities of platelet adhesion but does not stabilize fibrin (not an antifibrinolytic).

Option 2 Alteplase is a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA) Produced by recombinant DNA technology from human tissue culture, it catalyzes the cleavage of endogenous plasminogen to generate plasmin, and is moderately specific for fibrin bound plasminogen, so that circulating fibrinogen is lowered only by ~ 50%.

Option 3 Recombinant coagulation factor Xa, also called Andexanet alfa, is FDA-approved for reversal of patients treated with rivaroxaban and apixaban with serious bleeding.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 676.

choices.text: Cardiac apex is displaced laterally to left

questions.text: About isolated aortic stenosis, all of the following is accurate except for:
questions.solution:
• Pulsus bisferiens is seen in a patient of AS along with AR and is rare in isolated AS.
  • The cardiac apex is usually displaced to left because of Left ventricular hypertrophy.
 

Causes of Pulsus Bisferiens:

  1. Aortic regurgitation (AR)
  2. Aortic regurgitation with aortic stenosis (AR+AS)
  3. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1818, 1981.

questions.text: In respect to heart contraction, at what point does the mitral valve open?
questions.solution:
1. At the end of isovolumetric contraction : Aortic valve opens 

At the end of isovolumetric relaxation : Mitral valve opens

questions.text: Identify the drug that is not indicated in the treatment of NSTEMI:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Streptokinase 

All of the following drugs are indicated in the treatment of NSTEMI except streptokinase.
Following are the drugs indicated for the treat of NSTEMI:
 
  • NSTEMI is treated with beta-blockers and statins that improve circulation and prevent further damage to the heart muscle.
  • At the same time, blood thinners like aspirin or Plavix (clopidogrel) are used to prevent blood clots and the complete blockage of the vessel.
  • Patients of NSTEMI who are managed without PCI/thrombolysis are generally put on a combination of aspirin + clopidogrel or ticagrelor, which is continued for upto one year.
Remember- Thrombolysis is not indicated in NSTEMI since the risk of thrombolysis, particularly bleed outweighs its benefit of thrombolysing the clot since the clot in NSTEMI is small in dimension. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 674.

Acute ischemic stroke within 3 hours of onset

questions.text: Digoxin was being taken by an AF patient. Aspirin, KCl, Triamterene, and Clarithromycin were the first medications he received. Digoxin's serum concentration increases from 2.5 mg/dl to 3.4 mg/dl. ECG thickening of the T waves is the problem. Which medication among the following is to blame for the rise in digoxin levels in the serum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Clarithromycin
 
  • MDR1 (P-Glycoprotein) is expressed on the brush border membrane of renal epithelia, and its function can be monitored using digoxin (>70% excreted in the urine).
  • MDR1 inhibitors (e.g., quinidine, verapamil, valspodar, spironolactone, clarithromycin, and ritonavir) all markedly reduce renal excretion of digoxin.
  • This means that more of the drug Digoxin is present in the body for a longer period of time, which can increase the risk of Digoxin toxicity.
Option1, 2 and 3 Drugs have no enzyme induction or inhibition action significant to Digoxin Metabolism.

* Symptoms of Digoxin toxicity can include,
- Anorexia, nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain are usually reported first, are due to gastric irritation, mesenteric vasoconstriction and CTZ stimulation.
- Almost every type of arrhythmia can be produced by digoxin, pulsus bigeminies is common; others are nodal and ventricular extrasystoles, ventricular tachycardia and terminally ventricular fibrillation.

Drugs that can cause digoxin toxicity (P glycoprotein/MDR 1 inhibitors) are remembered  as CAVE Q drugs. These include:   

Drugs
C - Clarithromycin, Cyclosporine
A - Amiodarone
V - Verapamil
E - Erythromycin
Q - Quinine/Quinidine

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 91.

• Diagnosis is DVT leading to Pulmonary thromboembolism. This is a case of High risk PTE as the patient is Hypotensive and 2D- Echo shows RV dyskinesia.
  • It needs immediate thrombolysis by IV Tissue plasminogen activator for treatment since the patient is unstable.

Risk stratification and treatment is summarised below: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2098, 2100.

questions.text: During an experiment, a scientist detected bradycardia and hypotension. This could be because of:
questions.solution:
1. Bezold-Jarisch reflex- significant bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by fast shallow breathing when chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region (eg, juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) are activated. Numerous chemicals, such as capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine, can cause this reflex.

Cushing's Reaction- is a specific kind of CNS ischemic response that happens when the CSF pressure is very high causing an increase in arterial pressure.

Bainbridge Reflex- an atrial reflex that controls heart rate. An increase in atrial pressure causes an increase in heart rate. 

 

Peripheral chemoreceptor reflex- Chemoreceptors primarily influence respiration, although their activation also causes vasoconstriction.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 581

questions.text:
Chronic hypertension affects a 35-year-old lady. To receive preconception counselling, she goes to the clinic.
Which anti-hypertensive medication from the list below needs to be stopped before conception?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) ACE inhibitors
 
  • Fetal growth retardation, hypoplasia of organs and fetal death may occur if ACE inhibitors are given during later half of pregnancy.
  • A recent report indicates 2.7-fold higher malformation rate in fetuses exposed to ACE inhibitors in the first trimester.
  • ACE inhibitors must be stopped when the woman conceives.
Option 1,2 and 4 Drugs does not have known Teratogenic Side effects in humans.

* THE FOLLOWING TABLE IS TO SUMMARISE A FEW EXAMPLES OF TERATOGENIC DRUGS AND SUBSTANCES FREQUENLY TESTED IN EXAMS ALONG WITH THE DEFECTS THEY CAUSE: -



* VACTERL: -
  • V = Vertebral abnormalities
  • A= Anal Atresia
  • C = Cardiac defects
  • TE = Tracheal-oesophageal abnormalities, including atresia, stenosis and fistula.

choices.text: Patient should be asked to take normal breaths
The cuff pressure should be increased to 20 mm over systolic pressure
The cuff should be slowly deflated until the first Korotkoff sound is heard only during expiration

questions.text: A patient with possible cardiac tamponade arrives at the emergency department of the AIIMS. All of the following measures should be observed while taking BP EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The cuff is slowly deflated and the paradoxical pulse is recorded from the point when first Korotkoff sound is heard only during expiration to when it is heard in both expiration and inspiration. Rest statements are true.
 
  • Pulsus paradoxus refers to a fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration. Pulsus paradoxus is measured by noting the difference between the systolic pressure at which the Korotkoff sounds are first heard (during expiration) and the systolic pressure at which the Korotkoff sounds are heard with each heartbeat, independent of the respiratory phase.
 
  • Between these two pressures, the Korotkoff sounds are heard only intermittently and during expiration. The cuff pressure must be decreased slowly to appreciate the finding.
 
  • The patient must also breathe normally during the recording.

Pulsus paradoxus is seen in patients with:
 
  1. Pericardial tamponade
  2. Massive pulmonary embolism
  3. Hemorrhagic shock
  4. Severe obstructive lung disease
  5. Tension pneumothorax.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1818.

questions.text:
What will be the sequence after the P wave

A. a wave
B. 1st heart sound
C. Filling of ventricles
D. T wave
questions.solution:
The correct sequence on cardiac cycle is  3. A -> C -> B - > D. 
Amongst given option correct answer would be a wave ->Ventricular filling ->1st heart sound ->T wave
 

  • A wave: After the P wave, the a wave on JVP occurs, which represents atrial contraction. This follows the depolarization of the atria (P wave), leading to the contraction of the atria and the push of blood into the ventricles.

  • Filling of ventricles: After the a wave, the ventricles fill with blood following the atrial contraction.(NOTE: 70% of ventricular filling is passive - only about 30% is due to atrial contraction)

  • 1st heart sound (S1): The first heart sound (S1) occurs when the AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) close, signaling the beginning of ventricular systole.

  • T wave: The T wave represents ventricular repolarization and occurs much later, after the ventricular contraction (systole) has finished.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 529,530

questions.text: A 68yr old female patient presented with Atrial fibrillation with Mitral stenosis. ECHO does not show any thrombus. Which among the following is the best to prevent stroke ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Warfarin

Anti coagulation is a very important part of the treatment of Atrial Fibrillation in order to prevent stroke.

Novel Oral anticoagulants like Dabigatran can generally be used for anti-coagulation in Atrial Fibrillation except the following: -
 
  • NOAC are contraindicated in patients with Mechanical prosthetic valves
  • NOAC are contraindicated in patients with Atrial Fibrillation in the backdrop of valvular heart disease like Moderate / Severe mitral stenosis
In such cases Warfarin can be used for the purpose of Anticoagulation.

* NOAC are preferred compared to Warfarin in case of stroke prevention in patients with Atrial Fibrillation who are at a high risk of Ischemic Stroke.

* A higher INR range (2.5–3.5) is recommended for patients with mechanical heart valves in the mitral position or for patients with mechanical valves in another position who have concomitant atrial fibrillation or a prior history of stroke.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 717.

questions.text: A female patient, age 41, visits the emergency room of AIIMS with complaints of agitation, palpitations, excessive sweating, and a sense of impending doom. To rule out biological causes in an emergency, the following test should be performed:
questions.solution:
The presentation of this patient is suggestive of panic attack.

  • Before diagnosing a panic attack, we must rule out organic (medical) causes of anxiety. All the investigations listed above are important to rule out organic causes.
  • Although anemia can also present with panic attacks, Hemoglobin need not be done as an emergency investigation.
  • The most important investigation to be done here is ECG.
  • Hypoglycemia can be ruled out by asking a history of diabetes mellitus.


Organic causes of Anxiety:

  1. Hypoglycemia
  2. Hyperthyroidism
  3. Pheochromocytoma
  4. Cardiac- Angina/MI/MVP




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1888, 1892.

questions.text: What happens when a person changes posture from supine to standing?
questions.solution:
When a person changes his posture from supine to standing, there is venous pooling in lower limbs.

This pooling causes decrease in the venous return which leads to decreased cardiac output.

This cascade continues and the decrease in cardiac output causes a similar decrease in blood pressure which leads to decreased firing from Baroreceptors.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 666

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not correctly matched with their metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Digoxin: p-glycoprotein
 
  • P-glycoprotein is not involved in the metabolism of digoxin it is involved in Efflux of the drug. Metabolism and Elimination of drug, and Toxicity parameter depends on both but as question on Metabolism specifically answer have to be 1.
  • Digoxin has small amount of Hepatic metabolism via Glucuronide and Hydrolysis in liver and then rest mostly in large intestine by bacteria.
  • The cytochrome P450 (CYP) isoform CYP3A4 serves as the major pathway for metabolism of lovastatin, simvastatin and atorvastatin.
  • Carvedilol is extensively metabolized by oxidation by CYP1D6 and CYP2C9.
  • Verapamil is metabolized CYP3A4.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 141.

questions.text: For which of the following is Left bundle branch block (LBBB) on ECG least likely to develop?
questions.solution:
LBBB occurs when normal electrical activity in His-Purkinje system is interrupted.
It occurs in patients with underlying heart disease and may be associated with progressive conducting system disease.

Causes of LBBB:

• Structural heart diseases
• Primary disease of cardiac electrical and Coronary artery disease conduction system
• Dilated cardiomyopathies
• Long standing hypertension leading to aortic root dilation
• Hyperkalemia



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 349, 350, 1896, 1897.

questions.text: The fourth heart sound is produced as a result of:
questions.solution:
1. 4th Heart sound- A stethoscope nearly never picks it up due to its weakness and low pitch. This sound is produced as the atria contract, and it is most likely brought on by the blood's rush into the ventricles, which sets off vibrations resembling those of the third heart sound.

1st heart sound- A-V Valves closing.

2nd heart sound- closing of the aortic and pulmonary valves.

3rd Heart Sound- begins at the start of the Middle Third of the Diastole and is caused by blood oscillating back and forth between the walls of the ventricles, which is caused by blood pouring in from the atria.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 531

questions.text: What is the latest oral direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI) for preventing acute stroke?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dabigatran
  • The most recent oral direct thrombin inhibitor (DTI) for acute stroke prevention is Dabigatran.
  • Dabigatran is used to treat deep vein thrombosis (DVT; a blood clot, usually in the leg) and pulmonary embolism (PE; a blood clot in the lung). Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTIs) are small molecules that inhibit thrombin directly, with no need for a cofactor.
  • DTI action results in specific inhibition of free and fibrin-bound thrombin, thereby preventing:
                            -​Fibrin formation
                         -​Thrombin-mediated activation of FV, FVIII, FXI, and FXIII.
                      -​Thrombin induced platelet aggregation.

Option 1 Ximelagatran has been investigated in several large randomized controlled studies for prophylaxis against venous thromboembolism occurring after major orthopedic surgery, therapy in vein thrombosis, stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation, and acute coronary syndromes. It is a Prodrug of melagatran.
Option 2 Idraparinux is a heparinoid Penta saccharide, antithrombin III-dependent Factor Xa inhibitor
Option 4 warfarin works as an anticoagulant by inhibiting vitamin K epoxide reductase (VKOR) in the liver.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 672.

questions.text: The heart's phase of minimal motion during cardiac imaging is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Mid diastole

During mid diastole, the heart is in a relaxed state, and the ventricles are filling with blood. This phase is characterized by minimal motion of the heart, making it an optimal time for cardiac imaging procedures such as echocardiography or cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
 
  • Late systole (Option 1) refers to the end of the contraction phase of the cardiac cycle.
  • Mid systole (Option 2) is the middle of the contraction phase when the heart is actively pumping blood.
  • Late diastole (Option 3) refers to the end of the diastole phase just before the next contraction begins.



Reference: Otton, James M et al. “Defining the mid-diastolic imaging period for cardiac CT - lessons from tissue Doppler echocardiography.” BMC medical imaging vol. 13 5. 1 Feb. 2013, doi:10.1186/1471-2342-13-5. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3570333/

questions.text: Which of the following best represents the relationship between end-diastolic volume and contraction force
questions.solution:
Greater the ventricular diastolic volume, more the myocardial fibres are stretched during diastole. Within a normal physiologic range, the more the myocardial fibers are stretched, the greater the tension in the muscle fibers and the greater force of contraction of the ventricle when stimulated, as explained by Frank-Starling's law. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 534

questions.text: Which of the following is a Rho kinase inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fasudil 
Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitors, such as fasudil, ripasudil, and netarsudil, target the ROCK pathway, influencing smooth muscle contraction, fibrosis, and cellular motility. They are primarily used in treating glaucoma (reducing intraocular pressure) and cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid hemorrhage. They also show potential for pulmonary hypertension, fibrosis, cancer, and neurological recovery. Side effects include conjunctival hyperemia and hypotension.
  • Fasudil is an inhibitor of smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary vasospasm in experimental animals. In clinical trials in patients with CAD, it has improved performance in stress tests. It is investigational in angina.
  • Fasudil appears to reduce pulmonary artery pressure in PAH. Surgical treatment for advanced disease includes creation of a right atrial to left atrial shunt and lung transplantation.

Option 2 Ranolazine is a novel antianginal drug primarily acts by inhibiting a late Na+ current (late INa) in the myocardium which indirectly facilitates Ca2+ entry through Na+/Ca2+ exchanger.
Option 3 Amiloride block ENaCs in the luminal membrane of principal cells in late distal tubules and collecting ducts by binding to a site in the channel pore.
Option 4 Nicorandil is a dual mechanism antianginal drug activates ATP sensitive K+ channels (KATP) in smooth muscle membrane thereby hyperpolarizing and relaxing it.

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 313.

questions.text: Following waves in ECG are seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hypokalemia
 
  • U waves are small deflections that can appear on an electrocardiogram (ECG) following the T wave and before the next P wave.
  • U waves are often prominent and can be seen in leads V2 to V4 on the ECG.
  • U waves can be seen in certain conditions such as hypokalemia (low potassium levels), which is the most common cause.
  • Hyponatremia (low sodium levels) and hypercalcemia (high calcium levels), do not typically cause U waves in an ECG.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1830, 1831.

When there is increase in myocardial contractility the end systolic volume decreases and stroke volume increases which will lead left shift of end systolic pressure-volume curve without change in slope.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions makes the usage of beta blockers safe?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) HOCM

  • Beta blockers improve cardiac output in these patients during exercise by reducing left ventricular outflow obstruction, though they have little effect at rest.
 Option 1, 2 and 3 are all Contraindications for using Beta blockers.

* USES OF BETA BLOCKERS:-

  • Portal hypertension

* CONTRAINDICATIONS OF BETA BLOCKERS:-

  • COPD

questions.solution:

questions.text: Hypertension is treated with aliskiren. Aliskiren reduces blood pressure because it-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Prevents formation of Angiotensin-1

*ALISKIREN:-
Trials so far have shown that aliskiren reduces hypertensive left ventricular hypertrophy and benefits CHF patients, but its value compared to ACE inhibitors/ARBs as monotherapy and as additional drug remains to be established on the basis of outcome data. Aliskiren reduces albuminuria and has reno protective effect in hypertension and diabetes mellitus.
 
  • It is an example of Direct Renin inhibitor
  • MECHANISM OF ACTION – It blocks the conversion of Angiotensinogen to Angiotensin 1 and the effector chain of RAS is interrupted. While the concentration of renin in plasma is increased by feedback, the plasma renin activity (PRA) is decreased.
  • USE – At present, aliskiren is recommended as an alternative antihypertensive drug (for those who do not respond or do not tolerate 1st line drugs) and in combination with ACE inhibitor/ARB to achieve more complete RAS blockade and greater BP lowering/ cardio protection
  • ADEVERSE EFFECTS – Hyperkalemia, Hypotension, Angioedema
  • CONTRAINDICATIONS – Pregnancy; In patients taking ACE inhibitors and ARBs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 538.

questions.text: The myocardial stunning pattern does not correspond to the ECG. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as "broken heart syndrome" or "stress-induced cardiomyopathy," is a condition characterized by a sudden weakening of the heart muscle. It often occurs following a stressful or emotional event.
 
  • One of the distinguishing features of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is that the pattern of myocardial stunning or dysfunction does not correspond to the typical distribution of coronary arteries, meaning that the area of myocardial dysfunction is not directly related to a specific blockage or ischemia in the coronary arteries.
 
  • On the other hand, restrictive cardiomyopathy (option 2) is characterized by impaired filling of the ventricles due to stiffness or fibrosis of the heart muscle, and it is not typically associated with myocardial stunning.
 
  • Brugada cardiomyopathy (option 3) refers to Brugada syndrome, an inherited arrhythmia disorder that primarily affects the electrical conduction system of the heart, causing abnormal ECG patterns and an increased risk of life-threatening arrhythmias. It is not directly associated with myocardial stunning. ECG pattern if Brugada syndrome is is known as the "Brugada pattern" or "Brugada sign." It is typically observed in the right precordial leads (V1 to V3) most commonly as ST elevation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1966.

questions.text: The graph below depicts how quickly different haemoglobin chains normally synthesise both during pregnancy and after birth. Which of the following describes the gamma chain of haemoglobin
questions.solution:
Gamma chain of haemoglobin is indicated by graph B. The foetal Hb is composed of 2 alpha and 2 gamma chains which is changed to the HbA as seen in adults which contain 2 alpha and 2 beta chains. In graph, A- alpha chain, B- gamma chain and C- beta chain

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 632,605

questions.text: The following antiarrhythmic drug and its respective use is correct:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Adenosine in supraventricular tachycardia

Adenosine and Verapamil both can be used in case of SVT but there is following instances Adenosine has advantage over Verapamil-
  • Efficacy equivalent to or better than verapamil.
  • Action lasts < 1 min; adverse effects (even cardiac arrest, if it occurs) are transient.
  • No hemodynamic deterioration. It can be given to patients with hypotension, CHF or those receiving β blockers. Verapamil is contraindicated in these situations.
  • Safe in wide QRS tachycardia (verapamil is unsafe).
  • May be effective in patients not responding to verapamil.
However, adenosine produces transient dyspnea, chest pain, fall in BP and flushing in 30–60% patients; ventricular standstill for few sec or VF occurs in some patients, but resolves quickly. Bronchospasm may be precipitated in asthmatics; verapamil is the drug of choice for such patients.

So, Between Option 2 and Option 4 Adenosine should be chosen as the answer in this question.
Option 1 and 3 Regarding Lidocaine and Quinidine is Untrue.



TRICK TO REMEMBER COMMON ARRYTHMIA AND THEIR DRUGS WHICH ARE FREQUENTLY ASKED:-
 
  • SUPRAVENTRICULAR – Adenosine, Verapamil, Diltiazem, Digoxin
  • VENTRICULAR –Lidocaine, Mexiletine
  • BOTH – Amiodarone, class 1a,1c, Beta blockers

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 581.

questions.text: An alternative drug to epinephrine for treating cardiac arrest is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Amiodarone. Amiodarone is an alternative drug that can be used in the treatment of cardiac arrest.

It is administered during advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) as a substitute for or in combination with epinephrine. It can be particularly useful in certain situations, such as VF or pVT, where the effectiveness of epinephrine may be limited.

Apart from Epinephrine, Amiodarone and Lignocaine are other two drugs recommended by AHA for the treatment of Adult Cardiac arrest. Rest other drugs are NOT recommended.

ACLS algorithm:
  • Step 1: Assess responsiveness Determine if the patient is responsive and shout for help.
  • Step 2: Activate emergency response system Activate the emergency response system or ask someone to do it.
  • Step 3: Check for a pulse Assess for the presence of a pulse. If absent or not palpable within 10 seconds, proceed to the next step.
  • Step 4: Start high-quality CPR Begin high-quality CPR with a compression-to-ventilation ratio of 30:2 for adult patients. Ensure adequate depth and rate of compressions with minimal interruptions.
  • Step 5: Attach and analyze a defibrillator Attach an automated external defibrillator (AED) or manual defibrillator to the patient and analyze the rhythm.
  • Step 6: Deliver defibrillation If a shockable rhythm (ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia) is detected, deliver a single shock and immediately resume CPR.
  • Step 7: Perform rhythm checks After 2 minutes of CPR, assess the rhythm to determine if it is shockable or non-shockable.
  • Step 8: Administer medications Administer medications as indicated based on the rhythm and protocol. Epinephrine is typically given every 3-5 minutes. Additionally, consider administering vasopressin as an alternative vasopressor to one dose of epinephrine.
  • Step 9: Continue cycles of CPR and rhythm assessments Perform cycles of CPR with rhythm checks every 2 minutes. Follow the specific guidelines for rhythm interpretation, shock delivery, and medication administration.
  • Step 10: Consider advanced airway management If feasible and in accordance with local protocols, consider advanced airway management such as endotracheal intubation or supraglottic airway placement.
  • Step 11: Post-resuscitation care After return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC), provide post-resuscitation care, including monitoring, optimizing oxygenation and ventilation, treating underlying causes, and transferring the patient to an appropriate care setting.





Reference: Adult Cardiac Arrest algorithm, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines. URL: https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

questions.text: What causes c waves in JVP?
questions.solution:
Jugular venous pressure is the indirectly observed pulse pressure over the venous system via visualisation of the internal jugular vein. 

JVP waveform—

Classically it has three upward deflections and two downward deflections. a wave : Right atrial contraction.

c wave : Isovolumetric contraction of right ventricle. x descent : Pulling of tricuspid valve downward during ventricular ejection. v wave : Venous filling when tricuspid valve is closed causing rise in venous pressure. y descent : Rapid emptying of the atrium into the ventricle following the opening of tricuspid valve.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 530

    • Inhibits Angiotensin converting enzyme thereby decreasing AT 2 levels which thus decreases the GFR by preventing the constriction of efferent arterioles.

questions.text: A patient complains of breathing difficulties and widespread weakness. A mid-diastolic murmur with pronounced "a" waves is audible on auscultation in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: TS (Tricuspid stenosis)

The symptoms given such as breathing difficulty and weakness along with a mid diastolic murmur with pronounced “a” waves is definitive of TS.
  • The narrowing of the tricuspid valve impedes blood flow, leading to several symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath (especially during physical activity), palpitations, abdominal discomfort, and edema. In severe cases, tricuspid stenosis can cause heart failure.
  • A mid diastolic murmur is a characteristic feature of mitral stenosis but is seen in both mitral as well as tricuspid stenosis.
  • MDM + dyspnea suggests left sided defect like MS
MDM + edema suggests Right sided defect like TS
  • In this case, even though patient is presenting with MDM + dyspnea, a classical prominent “a” wave is seen on jvp which strongly suggests TS as the right answer.
A small table to remember in valvular heart diseases is as follows-



JVP waveforms and the abnormalities associated with them-




Reference- Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition Page no 284

questions.text: Select the one that acts for the longest duration-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rosuvastatin

Rosuvastatin are not extensively metabolized by CYP3A4, is excreted unchanged in the urine, greater LDL-CH reduction can be obtained in severe hypercholesterolemia partly due to its longer persistence in the plasma.
  • Rosuvastatin is a statin medication used to lower cholesterol levels.
  • It has a long half-life, which means it stays in the body for a longer duration compared to other statins.
  • The half-life of rosuvastatin is approximately 19 hours, allowing for sustained cholesterol-lowering effects over an extended period.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 684, 685.

questions.text: Other than MI, what are the causes of myocardial shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: All of the above

Myocardial shock, also known as cardiogenic shock, is a severe condition characterized by inadequate circulation of blood due to the heart's inability to pump effectively. While acute myocardial infarction (MI) is a common cause of myocardial shock, other conditions can also lead to this condition.
  1. Acute mitral regurgitation: Severe acute mitral regurgitation can result in a sudden increase in left ventricular volume and pressure overload. This can lead to a decrease in cardiac output and ultimately result in myocardial shock.
  2. Ventricular septal rupture: Ventricular septal rupture is a complication that can occur after an MI. It involves a rupture in the septum that separates the ventricles of the heart. This condition leads to a significant shunting of blood between the ventricles, compromising cardiac output and causing myocardial shock.
  3. Isolated right ventricular shock: Isolated right ventricular shock refers to a condition where the right ventricle fails to pump blood effectively. It can occur due to various causes, such as right ventricular infarction, severe pulmonary embolism, or right heart failure. In this condition, there is a decrease in systemic cardiac output, resulting in myocardial shock.
Therefore, all of the listed options can contribute to the development of myocardial shock by compromising the heart's ability to pump blood effectively.



Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1148.

questions.text: How is the mean arterial pressure calculated?
questions.solution:
Mean arterial pressure is calculated as (SBP + 2DBP)/3.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of nitrates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) GI disturbance
 
  • Nitrates are a class of medications commonly used for the treatment of angina (chest pain) and certain cardiovascular conditions.
  • Nitrates primarily work by dilating blood vessels, leading to improved blood flow and reduced cardiac workload.
  • While nitrates can cause several side effects, including vasodilation-related effects, GI disturbance is not typically associated with their use.
Option 1, 2 and 4 are correct regarding Side effects of Nitrate 
  • Nitrates can cause a drop in blood pressure, especially when changing positions from lying down to standing, leading to orthostatic hypotension.
  • Nitrates can cause an increase in heart rate, due to reduced BP causing Bainbridge reflex resulting in tachycardia.
  • Tachyphylaxis refers to a reduced response to a drug over time with repeated administration. Nitrates are known to develop tolerance, and their effectiveness can decrease with prolonged use, requiring dose adjustments or drug holidays.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 587.

questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Cushing syndrome
 Mobitz type 2 second degree AV block is due to-
