  • Clinically, patients with Dressler syndrome have malaise, fever, pericardial discomfort, leukocytosis, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and a pericardial effusion.
  • The cause of post-MI syndrome s not clearly established, although detection of antibodies to cardiac tissue suggests an immunopathologic process.
  • Treatment is with Aspirin, 650 mg as often as every 4 hours, may be effective. Glucocorticosteroids and NSAIDs are best avoided in patients with Dressler syndrome within 4 weeks of STEMI because of their potential to impair infarct healing, cause ventricular rupture, and increase coronary vascular resistance


Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1163.

questions.text: What is the sequence of color changes in Raynaud's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: White - Blue - Red
 
  • Raynaud's syndrome occurs due to peripheral vasospasm, and it is more common in the upper extremities. It may occur due to exposure to various stimuli, including cold temperatures, tobacco, or emotional stress, and certain occupational groups, such as those who use vibrating tools, or it can be secondary to scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus, Sjogren's syndrome, and antiphospholipid syndrome.
  • The sequence of color changes typically starts with pallor (white) due to decreased blood flow to the extremities.
  • This is followed by cyanosis (blue) as the lack of oxygen causes the skin to turn blue.
  • Finally, as the blood flow returns, the affected areas may turn red due to reactive hyperemia, a rebound increase in blood flow.
  • Therefore, the correct sequence of color changes in Raynaud's disease is White - Blue - Red.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2778.

questions.text: Where do we see the Epsilon wave?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia 
 
  • The epsilon wave is a characteristic finding seen in the ECG of a patient with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy.
  • It is a small positive deflection buried at the end of the QRS complex.
  • The sinus rhythm ECG suggests the disease in >85% of patients, most often showing T-wave inversions in V1–V3.
  • Delayed activation of the right ventricle may cause a widened QRS (>110 ms) in the right precordial leads (V1–V3) and a prolonged S-wave upstroke in those leads and, occasionally, a notched deflection at the end of the QRS known as an epsilon wave.

Image showing Epsilon wave seen in ARVD: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1921.

questions.text: For patients with Congestive Heart Failure and an ejection fraction of <40 percent i, which is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: ACE-I+ Beta Blocker
 
  • Heart failure is termed HFrEF when the EF is below 40%. The pharmacological management of HfrEF includes two broad categories of drugs:


Combining ACE-I with Beta blocker will have mortality benefit more than other combinations given in options.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1941, 1942.

questions.text: In which of the following is the Duroziez's sign seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Aortic Regurgitation
 
  • Duroziez's sign is heard over the femoral artery.
  • It is elicited by partially compressing the femoral artery with a stethoscope.
  • The sign is associated with a to-and-fro murmur.
  • Duroziez's sign is indicative of aortic regurgitation.

Peripheral signs of Aortic Regurgitation:  




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1988.

questions.text: In which of the following is the Vitum's sign seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tricuspid Regurgitation 
 
  • Vitum's sign is associated with tricuspid regurgitation and is characterized by a systolic pulsation felt in the right supraclavicular fossa.
  • It is a hepatic Pressure Maneuver to identify Tricuspid Regurgitation on Physical Exam.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2003.

questions.text: Where do we see Carvallo's Sign representing a Diastolic Murmur that increases on inspiration?
questions.solution:
The correct option is option 2-Tricuspid regurgitation
 
  • Carvallo's sign is a physical examination finding that helps to diagnose the cause of a heart murmur.
  • It is characterized by an increase in the intensity of a diastolic murmur during inspiration.
  • The sound may be more audible when the patient is lying on their left side.
  • Increased Ventricular regurgitation ->Increased right ventricular volume ->Increased stroke volume->Velocity of regurgitant flow increases
  • Carvallo's sign disappears in RV failure.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2003.

questions.text: What is the dose of Reteplase for management of Acute MI?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 10 IU 
 
  • Reteplase is a thrombolytic agent that is used to treat acute myocardial infarction (AMI).
  • It is a tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), which means that it helps to break down blood clots.
  • Reteplase is given as two 10 IU intravenous (IV) injections, 30 minutes apart.

Reteplase:





Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1132.

questions.text: The target BP must be below which value before thrombolysis can be done in ischemic stroke?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 185/110 mm Hg 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke:
  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in the preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3337, 3338.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of Aneurysmal rupture in case of a patient with suspected subarachnoid haemorrhage presents with blood isolated in the fourth ventricle on a CT scan?
questions.solution:
The correct Option is 1: Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery Aneurysm 
 
  • The fourth ventricle is located in the brainstem, and blood isolated in this area on a CT scan indicates bleeding in that region.
  • The Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is a branch of the vertebral artery, and aneurysms in this artery can cause subarachnoid hemorrhage with blood isolated in the fourth ventricle.
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) - the largest branch of vertebral artery. It supplies the lateral part of the medulla, the cerebellar hemisphere, and the choroid plexus of the fourth ventricle.



Vertebral artery branches:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3330, 3354.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best marker to look for in athletes with acute STEMI?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Troponin T/I
 
  • Troponin T and Troponin I are cardiac-specific biomarkers that are released into the bloodstream when there is damage to the heart muscle, such as in acute STEMI.
  • They are highly sensitive and specific indicators of myocardial injury, and their levels rise within a few hours after the onset of a heart attack.
  • Troponin T/I levels are widely used in clinical practice to diagnose acute myocardial infarction (AMI) and to assess its severity in athletes and non-athletes alike.
  • CK levels, CRP and LDH may be falsely elevated in professional athletes due to skeletal muscle damage that occurs. So, it can't be used as a marker for myocardial injury.



Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1116, 1184

questions.text: The initial treatment of acute, life-threatening cardiogenic Pulmonary edema involves all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Digoxin
 
  • Cardiogenic pulmonary edema: Accumulation of fluid in the lungs due to heart failure.
  • The initial treatment aims to relieve the acute symptoms and improve the patient's condition rapidly.
  • Digoxin is not typically used in the initial treatment of acute, life-threatening cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to its slower onset of action.
Management of Acute Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1942, 1943, 1950.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has the lowest likelihood of being linked to infectious endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Small ASD
 
  • Infective endocarditis: Infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and heart valves, usually caused by bacteria or fungi.
  • It is most commonly associated with abnormalities that cause turbulent blood flow or damage to the endocardium, which can provide a favorable environment for bacterial attachment and colonization.
  • The risk of infective endocarditis is relatively lower for small ASDs compared to larger defects or conditions involving heart valves.
  • As the gradient is less in ASD thus turbulence doesn't take place and thus Infective Endocarditis doesn't usually happen. 
  • Other conditions like small ventricular septal defects (VSDs), mild mitral regurgitation (MR), and mild mitral stenosis (MS) may still present some risk, depending on their severity and structural abnormalities.


Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1486.

choices.text: Increased coronary flow improves LV systolic performance
Increased coronary blood flow reduces LV diastolic distensibility
Increase in coronary flow decreases the myocardial oxygen demand
Increase in coronary flow decreases myocardial work

questions.text: Identify the statement which is true about 'Gregg' effect:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Increased coronary flow improves LV systolic performance 
 
  • Gregg effect: Increased coronary flow improves LV (left ventricular) systolic performance by enhancing oxygen and nutrient delivery to the heart muscle, aiding better contraction and preventing heart failure.
Treatment options to increase coronary blood flow:
  • Angioplasty: Opens narrowed/blocked coronary arteries.
  • Stent placement: Keeps coronary arteries open after angioplasty.
  • Coronary artery bypass grafting: Creates a new blood supply to the heart.



Reference: Salavastru, C I, and R Cârmaciu. “The role of the Gregg phenomenon in cardiac performance.” Romanian journal of physiology : physiological sciences vol. 35,3-4 (1998): 253-7. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11061325/

questions.text: Which among the following is not an autoimmune disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ulcerative colitis

The most appropriate option after elimination is ulcerative collitis rest all have autoimmune etiology. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 799.

choices.text: Osteoporosis leading to hip fracture in women

questions.text: Pick the option that is not a side effect of long-term use of PPI.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hypothyroidism

Proton Pump Inhibitors have not yet been found to cause hypothyroidism.

They inhibit acid secretion - their long-term use increases the chances of infections like Community-acquired pneumonia
and Clostridium difficile. They can also lead to hypocalcemia leading to osteoporosis. 

* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 700.

questions.text: Which one of the following can be used as a substitute for a liver biopsy to detect fibrosis in order to avoid a liver biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Serum hyaluronic acid and laminin
 
  • Serum hyaluronic acid and laminin are biomarkers that can provide information about liver fibrosis, which is scarring of the liver tissue.
  • Elevated levels of these biomarkers are associated with liver fibrosis, indicating potential liver damage.
  • However, these are non-specific biomarkers and should not be used as reliable tests for detecting fibrosis. Fibroscan is a better non-invasive test to detect Hepatic fibrosis.
 
  • Although the other options (SGOT and SGPT, serum ALP and GGT, unconjugated and conjugated bilirubin) are also liver function tests, they do not specifically evaluate liver fibrosis or provide a comprehensive assessment of liver health without the need for a biopsy.






Reference: Yamada’s Textbook of Gastroenterology, 6th edition, Page no 2952.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the investigation of choice for childhood acute appendicitis?
questions.solution:
With its lack of ionising radiation, USG should be the investigation of choice/best diagnostic investigation for acute appendicitis in children. Ultrasound has a sensitivity of 85-90% and specificity of 95-100% for diagnosing appendicitis.

Computed tomography may be done in cases if the diagnosis is in doubt. CT is considered the Investigation of choice in adults, not in children. 
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 281,282

questions.text: What factor best determines the prognosis of esophageal cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) T stage
 
  • Long-term survival following esophagectomy depends on a number of factors such as the number of involved lymph nodes (N), depth of the tumor invasion (T), and the location of the tumor in the esophagus.
  • In esophageal cancer, the prognosis is best determined by the T stage, among the options provided.
* Prognosis is better for tumors of the cervical esophagus and tumors located at the GE junction. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 762.

choices.text: Causes irreversible inhibition of proton pump. Acid secretion suppressed till new pumps are generated
Prodrugs and needs generation of active metabolites

questions.text: Why does PPI act longer despite having a short half-life?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Causes irreversible inhibition of proton pump. Acid secretion suppressed till new pumps are generated
 
  • Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs) are a type of pharmaceutical drug used to reduce the production of stomach acid. Despite their relatively short half-lives of around two hours, they can still cause prolonged suppression of acid secretion for up to 48 hours, due to their effect on the proton pumps which produce the acid.
  • The PPIs bind to and irreversibly inhibit the proton pump molecules, meaning that for acid secretion to occur again, new proton pumps need to be synthesized. Therefore, although the PPIs are short-lived, their effects can be prolonged due to the time taken for new proton pumps to be made.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 700.

questions.text: Pick the drug is not active against Hepatitis B.
questions.solution:
Zidovudine(AZT) is active against HIV. However, it is not active against Hepatitis B.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2595.

questions.text: What kind of test should be used to rule out biliary atresia in a 1-month-old baby?
questions.solution:
• Investigation of choice to rule out biliary atresia in a 1-month-old child is Hepatic scintigraphy.
  • Hepatobiliary scintigraphy with technetium-labeled iminodiacetic acid derivatives (HIDA scan) is used to differentiate biliary atresia from non­ obstructive causes of cholestasis.
  • Uptake by hepatocytes is intact, but excretion depends on patent bile ducts.
  • In biliary atresia -uptake occurs, but no excretion into intestine (even after pretreatment with phenobarbital, which stimulates bile flow).
  • High negative predictive value - if tracer passes into intestine, BA is ruled out.
  • Hence, the Investigation of choice/test to rule out BA.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 327

choices.text: Most common mesenchymal tumour of gastrointestinal tract
ALK gene mutation is seen in most of the cases

questions.text: Select the option that is not true about Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumour (GIST).
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) ALK gene mutation is seen in most of the cases
 
  • GIST is not associated with ALK (Anaplastic Lymphoma Kinase) gene mutations. They are associated with KIT gene mutations. 
  • GISTs typically originate from the interstitial cells of Cajal, which are specialized cells in the gastrointestinal tract involved in regulating gut motility.
  • They are the most common mesenchymal tumor of the gastrointestinal tract, and the prognosis can depend on factors such as tumor size, mitotic rate, and presence of metastasis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 778.

choices.text: Change atenolol and thiazide to calcium channel blocker and ACE inhibitor and add bisacodyl for constipation
Change imipramine and haloperidol to fluoxetine and risperidone and add bisacodyl for constipation
Only add bisacodyl for constipation and continue rest of the medications
Discontinue all her medications and start her on steroids

questions.text: A 86-year-old woman arrived at the clinic with acute constipation. She had been taking medicine for five years as a recognised hypertension. Her blood pressure was  157/98 mm Hg in the clinic. A supine blood pressure reading revealed a reading of 90/60 mm Hg. She has just experienced depression. She is taking docusate, imipramine, haloperidol, atenolol, thiazide as medications. What is the management's best course of action going forward?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Change imipramine and haloperidol to fluoxetine and risperidone and add bisacodyl for constipation

Considering the symptoms given in the problem, imipramine and haloperidol must be changed to fluoxetine and risperidone and add bisacodyl for constipation.
 
  • This patient's postural hypotension is most likely caused by imipramine's alpha blocking and its interactions with thiazides.
  • She also has Imipramine's anticholinergic side effects (constipation). Imipramine, a TCA, must thus be stopped, and Fluoxetine, an SSRI, together with a laxative to treat any existing constipation, should be begun.  
  • Additionally, because Haloperidol and other conventional antipsychotics have anticholinergic adverse effects, she should begin taking the atypical antipsychotic Risperidone(with lesser anticholinergic side effects).
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 485.

questions.text: Pick the option that is diagnostic of acute hepatitis B infection.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: IgM anti-HbC
 
  • During acute hepatitis B infection, IgM antibodies against the hepatitis B core antigen (anti-HBc) are typically detectable.
 
  • IgM anti-HBc is an important marker of recent or ongoing infection and is used to confirm acute hepatitis B infection. It indicates an active immune response to the hepatitis B virus.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2565, 2576.

questions.text: A one-month-old baby was diagnosed with intrahepatic cholestasis and conjugated bilirubinemia. Hepatocytes were found to contain red-colored granules after liver tissue staining with PAS. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
One-month-old child with conjugated bilirubinemia and intrahepatic cholestasis suggests neonatal cholestasis syndrome.
The biopsy from the liver is PAS positive.
So, the most probable diagnosis would be Alpha-I Antitrypsin deficiency.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2225,2226

choices.text: Nutmeg liver with dark areas of perivenular dead hepatocytes and gray areas of periportal viable hepatocytes
Nodular regenerative hyperplasia of liver induced due to OCPs
Nutmeg liver with pale areas of necrosis and dark congested areas of perivenular viable hepatocytes

questions.text: The following findings are revealed by a liver biopsy. What is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Nutmeg liver with dark areas of perivenular dead hepatocytes and gray areas of periportal viable hepatocytes
 
  • This iconic image of Nutmeg liver shows the liver with chronic passive venous congestion. Necrotic hepatocytes make up the dark, crowded spots, whereas viable hepatocytes are present in the paler, brownish-looking areas around them.
  • In chronic passive hepatic congestion, the centrilobular regions are grossly red-brown and slightly depressed (because of cell death) and are accentuated against the surrounding zones of uncongested tan liver (nutmeg liver).
  • Microscopically, there is centrilobular congestion and hemorrhage, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, and variable degrees of hepatocyte dropout and necrosis
To remember this, think the blood supply comes via portal vein and Hepatic artery from the portal triad towards the center of the lobule, so when there is stasis the first to be affected is the centrilobular area than the periportal area which is close to the vascularity. It is therefore - Periportal fibrosis and Centrilobular necrosis seen in CVC liver
                                        

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 533.

questions.text: Which of these inhibits CYP450 the least?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rabeprazole

  • Rabeprazole is exclusively metabolized by CYP2C19 and does not cause any inhibition of CYP450.
  • Among the PPIs, only omeprazole inhibits CYP2C19 (thereby decreasing the clearance of disulfiram, phenytoin, and other drugs) and induces the expression of CYP1A2 (thereby increasing the clearance of imipramine, several antipsychotic drugs, tacrolimus, and theophylline).


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: Both HbsAg and HbeAg seropositivity was discovered in a nurse. She is afflicted with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Acute infectious hepatitis B

The nurse has recently acquired hepatitis B infection. The presence of both HBsAg and HBeAg seropositivity is commonly seen during the acute phase of hepatitis B infection when the virus is actively replicating. In this case, the nurse is likely experiencing an acute infectious episode of hepatitis B.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2565, 2576.

questions.text: Ursodeoxycholic acid and steroids were administered to a 3-month-old baby who had a history of passing clay-colored stools and dark yellow urine since one month. Further examination revealed that he had direct bilirubin of 6 mg%. Which of the following tests is most accurate for diagnosing the aforementioned condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: HIDA scan

The most likely diagnosis for an infant passing clay coloured stools and showing conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is Biliary atresia.
For diagnosis of biliary atresia,
  • USG – triangular cord sign
  • HIDA scan – (screening test)will show absent uptake of the radiotracer in the biliary tract
  • Liver biopsy – confirmatory test
  
The above images show triangular cord sign and HIDA scan respectively.

Option 3 and 4 : Liver function tests and CT abdomen are not specific tests.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 327

choices.text: H. pylori infection, Silver stain, Gram-negative coccobacilli

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient complains of heartburn. An upper GI endoscopy was done and a biopsy from a suspicious lesion showed the following picture.
What is the significance of this? What particular stains are you going to use for confirmation, and what are you looking for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Barrett’s esophagus, mucin stain, dysplasia
 
  • The histological picture of the esophagus shows intestinal-type epithelium with goblet cells, characteristic of Barrett's esophagus.
  • Mucin stain helps to better define the extent of dysplasia and rule out malignant transformation.
  • Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present, but there is not universal agreement as to whether they are sufficient for the diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text: What aspect of metoclopramide causes its antiemetic effects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) D2 antagonist

  • Metoclopramide is a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist and is also a mixed 5-HT3 receptor antagonist & 5-HT4 receptor agonist.
  • The antiemetic action of metoclopramide is due to its antagonist activity at D2 receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone in the central nervous system-this action prevents nausea & vomiting triggered by most stimuli.
  • At higher doses, 5-HT3 antagonists' activity may also contribute to the antiemetic effect.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 713.

questions.text: Between peritoneum and which of the following is the Le-Veen shunt in ascites done?
questions.solution:
The LeVeen shunt a.k.a Peritoneovenous shunt designed for ascites management due to CLD.

One end of the tube is inserted into the peritoneal cavity while the other end is subcutaneously tunneled to the neck, where its inserted into the IJV and fed into the SVC.




Reference: LeVeen, H H. “The LeVeen shunt.” Annual review of medicine vol. 36 (1985): 453-69. doi:10.1146/annurev.me.36.020185.002321. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3888061/

questions.text:
For the past six days, a 1-year old baby has experienced 10 to 12 episodes of watery stools per day.
What additional medications should be given to the infant in addition to the zinc supplements?
questions.solution:
• The infant here suffers from acute diarrhea and treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 289-292

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman complained of recurring bloody diarrhea. Multiple geographic ulcers are seen during colonoscopy, as seen in the histological analysis below.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Crohn’s disease

  • The histology of what appears to be a geographical ulcer is indicating a transmural inflammation, meaning it extends through the lamina propria and the muscle layer.
  • A non-caseating granuloma too is seen. Therefore, Crohn's disease is the most likely diagnosis.
  • In contrast, amoebic colitis yields a flask-shaped ulcer and pseudomembranous colitis have ischemic cryptitis and pseudo membrane on histology.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 800.

questions.text: What are the effects of laxative abuse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hypokalemia

* Following are the complications of Chronic Laxative Abuse:
  • a. Hypokalemia
  • b. Renal tubular acidosis
  • c. Secondary hyperaldosteronism
  • d. Hypermagnesemia - magnesium containing preparations
  • e. Acute phosphate nephropathy
  • f. Metabolic alkalosis
  • g. Pancreatic damage (but no changes in glucose levels)
  • h. Ileocecal sphincter dilatation
  • i. Colonic inflammation
  • j. Urolithiasis

Reference: Basic & Clinical Pharmacology, Bertram G. Katzung, 14th edition, Page No 1128.

questions.text:
Serology profile done for a patient is mentioned below. What is the likely cause of the abnormal findings:
HbsAg-Non-reactive
HBV DNA-Undetectable
HbeAg-Non-reactive
IgG Anti-HbC-Reactive
questions.solution:
State of recovery from chronic hepatitis

It is evident from the aforementioned serology profile that the patient either has a remote past of Hepatitis B infection or is a low-level Hepatitis B carrier.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2576.

choices.text: Refer to higher center with mother giving frequent sips of water
Immediately admit the child, give IV fluids and then refer to higher center
Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center in an ambulance with sips of ORS along the way
Send child home with few packets of ORS and call after 3 days.

questions.text: A one-month-old boy who had been suffering of a fever for two days was brought to the subcenter by his mother. The child weighs 2 kilograms. Upon examination, it was discovered that the youngster was drowsy,felt very hot, that a skin pinch had returned very slowly, oral mucosa was dry, and the eyes were sunken. His forehead had ten pustules. What actions should be taken at the subcenter?
questions.solution:
The child must be given the first dose of antibiotics and referred to a higher center.(with sips of ORS)

The patient here has multiple signs of possible serious bacterial infection/very severe disease - (drowsy child/multiple pustules/felt hot suggesting high grade fever). Hence, According to IMNCI child should immediately referred after first dose of IV antibiotic. Since child also has severe dehydration - he should be ensured to have ORS on the way. 

Other options
 
  • Option 1 - Patient should be referred after giving the first dose of IV antibiotic, not without giving the first dose of IV Antibiotic and with ORS on the way - not water. 
  • Option 2 - Child does have severe dehydration(sunken eyes/drowsy child , delyed skin pinch) - however - According to IMNCI - if the child has severe dehydration with other signs of very severe disease/severe classification - child should be referred with ORS on the way rather than giving IV fluids at the subcentre.  See the image from IMNCI given below. 

 
  • Option 4 - Child has signs of severe bacterial disease - needs t be admitted and hence cannot be sent back home


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 289-292

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient was admitted with dysphagia. What is the result of the upper GI biopsy of the esophagus indicated in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Barrett’s esophagus
 
  • The result of the upper GI biopsy of the esophagus indicated in the image is consistent with Barrett's esophagus.
  • Barrett's esophagus is a condition characterized by the replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the lower esophagus with specialized intestinal-type columnar epithelium (intestinal metaplasia).
  • It is commonly associated with chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is a premalignant condition for the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

choices.text: Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of aldehyde dehydrogenase
Toxic level of methanol is 1.25 gm/kg body weight
Formic acid is mainly responsible for toxicity

questions.text: Which of these is not true regarding methanol poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of aldehyde dehydrogenase 
 
  • Fomepizole is a specific inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, and not aldehyde dehydrogenase. Rest of the options are features of methanol poisoning.
  • Formic acid is mainly responsible for toxicity, and it can lead to methanol-induced toxic retinopathy which can even cause blindness.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 423.

questions.text: 2 hours after eating at a restaurant, a young male experienced 5 episodes of loose stools. He is afebrile and slightly dehydrated. What is the next course of action?
questions.solution:
The patient in the hypothetical clinical situation is mildly dehydrated and experiencing diarrhea.

Replacement of lost fluid and electrolytes is crucial for all types of diarrhoea. Fluid replacement with ORS is adequate in cases of mild diarrhea. 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 301, 302.

questions.text: A 3 days old baby is admitted with intraventricular hemorrhage. Baby develops abdominal distention. The X-ray abdomen showed pneumatosis portalis (portal vein gas). What would be the stage of NEC?
questions.solution:
The presence of pneumatosis portalis signifies that the stage of Necrotizing Enterocolitis is stage 2B. The 'Modified Bell's staging criteria’ is used to determine the severity, radiography, and management of Necrotizing Enterocolitis.
According to this staging, 'pneumatosis portalis’ (presence of gas in the portal vein) indicates stage 2B; Pneumatosis intestinalis is 2A.




Reference:https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Modified-Bell-s-Staging-Criteria-for-Necrotizing-Enterocolitis-NEC_tbl1_273870645

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient comes in with fever, diarrhea, and intense abdominal pain that lasts for six hours. As seen, an erect abdominal X-ray was taken. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Toxic megacolon
 
  • The most probable diagnosis for the patient with fever, diarrhea, and intense abdominal pain seen in the erect abdominal X-ray is toxic megacolon.
  • Toxic megacolon is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by severe inflammation and dilation of the colon, usually due to severe infection or inflammatory bowel disease.
  • It can present with symptoms such as abdominal pain, fever, diarrhea, and signs of systemic toxicity.

Crohn’s vs ulcerative colitis:


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2475.

questions.text: Pick the 'Proton pump inhibitor'.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Omeprazole

Proton pump inhibitors are Omeprazole – maximum interaction with clopidogrel
Esomeprazole – longer acting
Pantoprazole – least enzyme interaction
Lansoprazole, Rabeprazole – most potent and longest acting

Option 1 : Ranitidine – H2 blocker
Option 2 : Misoprostol – PGE1 analog
Option 4 : Laxatidine – H2 blocker

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 699.

questions.text: A patient arrived with ascites. Ascitic fluid analysis was done and found to have a SAAG greater than 1.1. Which of the following is not a cause?
questions.solution:
In tubercular peritonitis, Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG) is <1.1gm/dL.
 
  • The SAAG is effective for separating ascites resulting from portal hypertension from ascites without portal hypertension.
  • The SAAG corresponds with the hepatic venous pressure gradient and represents the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids.
  • The SAAG is determined by deducting the serum albumin level from the ascitic albumin concentration, and it is unaffected by diuresis.
  • A SAAG <1. g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension, as in tuberculous peritonitis, peritoneal carcinomatosis, or pancreatic ascites.
 
SAAG \(\geq\) 1.1 g/dl SAAG < 1.1 g/dl
• Liver cirrhosis • Malignancy
• Fulminant hepatic failure • Peritoneal carcinomatosis
• Liver metastases • Nephropathy
• Budd-Chiari syndrome • Malnutrition
• Portal Vein Thrombosis • Protein-losing enteropathy
• Veno-occlusive Disease • Tuberculous peritonitis
• Myxedema • Pancreatic ascites
• Cardiac Failure • Serositis
• Constrictive Pericarditis • Secondary peritonitis
• Pulmonary Hypertension



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 322, 323, 2631, 2632.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of passage of drops of blood through the rectum in a toddler?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of passage of a few drops of blood per rectum in a toddler is Juvenile rectal polyp.
  • Juvenile polyps are the most common form of colorectal hamartoma and are mostly found in children under the age of 5.
  • It occurs due to SMAD 4 mutation. 
  • They usually present as a single lesion in the rectum and may cause rectal bleeding, mucus discharge, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.
  • They are also known as retention polyps due to their occurrence as a result of the obstruction of the crypt necks leading to dilation of the mucus-filled glands.

There is no increased risk of cancer associated with juvenile polyps


Reference:Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th Edition Page no 805

questions.text: What does a lack of urobilinogen in the urine indicate in a jaundice patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Obstructive jaundice
 
  • In obstructive jaundice, urobilinogen levels are typically decreased or absent in urine.
  • This occurs because the obstruction prevents conjugated bilirubin from entering the intestines, where it would normally be converted to urobilinogen by gut bacteria and then excreted in urine.
           
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2650.

questions.text: What is pirenzepine used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Gastric ulcer
 
  • Pirenzepine is an example of M₁ selective antagonist (Anti cholinergic drugs)
  • USE:- Treatment of peptic ulcers
  • MECHANISM OF ACTION :- Reduces gastric acid secretion and muscle spasm

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 129.

questions.text: The most common presentation of immunoproliferative small intestinal disease is:
questions.solution:
• IPSID, also known as Mediterranean Lymphoma, is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the small intestine caused by infection with the bacteria Campylobacter jejuni. It is most commonly seen in patients of Middle Eastern, North African and Central Asian origin.
 
  • The most prominent feature of this disorder is malabsorption. This can lead to diarrhea, weight loss, abdominal pain and loss of appetite.
 
  • Other symptoms that may be seen with IPSID include fever, anemia, and an enlarged spleen.
 
  • Patients with this condition will often require lifelong antibiotic treatment to control the infection and may also need nutritional supplementation to ensure proper nutrition.


Reference: Martin, I G, and M I Aldoori. “Immunoproliferative small intestinal disease: Mediterranean lymphoma and alpha heavy chain disease.” The British journal of surgery vol. 81,1 (1994): 20-4. doi:10.1002/bjs.1800810107. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8313111/

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2459.

choices.text: RL infusion 120 ml in the first hour followed by 360 ml in the next 5 hours
RL infusion 180 ml in the first hour followed by 420 ml in the next 5 hours
RL infusion 180 ml in the first hour followed by 480 ml in the next 5 hours
RL infusion 240 ml in the first hour followed by 360 ml in the next 5 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: RL infusion 180 ml in the first hour followed by 420 ml in the next 5 hours

Management of Diarrhea should be done on the basis of clinical features and the presence and severity of dehydration.



Plan A :


Plan B :

  • 100 ml/kg for 1st 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg

Plan C – 100 ml/kg Ringer lactate IV


In the above example, the child is showing features of severe dehydration, so plan C must be followed.
