questions.text:
A 17-year-old patient was diagnosed with intussusception, which required surgery and the removal of a section of his intestine that had several polyps.
Pathology was visible using microscopy as follows: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hamartomatous polyps 
 
  • The histology shows a sizable, large, pedunculated polyp with a distinct lobulated shape.
  • Well-developed smooth muscle and an arborizing network of connective tissue are seen to extend into the polyp, and it's surrounded by normal intestinal epithelium rich in goblet cells.
  • This is typical of PJ syndrome (Peutz-Jegher syndrome) which has hamartomatous polyps. 
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 808.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions results in melanosis coli?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Senna
 
  • Senna is an example of stimulant laxative predominantly used as anti constipation agent.
  • It has a very well known side effect called MELANOSIS COLI.
  • Melanosis coli is a non inflammatory bowel  condition characterised by deposition of  brown or black pigment  in the colorectal mucosa. It happens due to prolonged use of Stimulant laxatives like Senna.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1093.

questions.text:
A patient with hematemesis was examined, and his blood pressure was 90/60 mmHg and his heart rate was 120. There was also splenomegaly.
What is the most probable cause of bleeding?
questions.solution:
Portal hypertension is a condition in which the pressure in the portal vein (the primary vein that carries blood from the intestines, pancreas, spleen, and stomach to the liver) is abnormally high.

Splenomegaly (enlarged spleen) and massive bleeding due to rupture of gastric varices leading to hypotension and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) are symptoms often seen in patients with portal hypertension. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2625.

questions.text: A newborn has a fever, lethargy, distension in the abdomen, vomiting, and constipation. Clinically, he was identified as having a possible perforation and volvulus neonatorum. Best imaging modality would be:
questions.solution:
• Correct Option is 1: Plain X-ray to see free gas under diaphragm. 
  • Option 2 and 4 : Barium enema and barium meal follow through are contraindicated in a case of suspected perforation as barium causes chemical peritonitis.
  • Option 3: Upper GI endoscopy also cannot be done as an endoscope itself may cause more perforations. Hence, in a case of volvulus neonatorum, plain X-ray abdomen standing becomes the best option among the ones given.
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1953

questions.text:
An endoscopic image of an esophageal lesion is shown below.



What is the expected histopathology finding?


1. 



2. 




3. 




4.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Barrett's esophagus
 
  • The given endoscopic image is of Barrett's esophagus, the pale region signifies squamous epithelium of esophagus and the reddish region signifies columnar region.
  • The histopathologic image of option 3 shows the squamous to columnar metaplasia seen in Barrett's esophagus.
  • Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present, but there is not universal agreement as to whether they are sufficient for the diagnosis
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text: The intern administered an antiemetic medicine to a patient who had a history of a few episodes of vomiting. A few hours later, the patient's posture began to change. Which of the following medication administrations is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Metoclopramide
 
  • Metoclopramide has a central anti-dopaminergic (D2) action on the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ), which is the primary cause of its antiemetic property.
  • This action of metoclopramide also leads to certain major side effects such as extrapyramidal effects like dystonias, akathisia and parkinsonian features that are observed in individuals who take the drug to control vomiting.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 713.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is best for determining whether an individual has intestinal malabsorption?
questions.solution:
• The D-Xylose absorption test, which examines Xylose absorption in the intestinal villi and can differentiate between Intestinal and Pancreatic malabsorption, is the most effective test for diagnosing Intestinal Malabsorption
 
  • Urinary D-xylose Test: The urinary D-xylose test for carbohydrate absorption provides a measure of proximal small-bowel absorptive function. d-Xylose, a pentose, is absorbed almost exclusively in the proximal small intestine and is excreted in the urine. The d-xylose test is usually performed by administering 25 g of d-xylose and collecting urine for 5 h. An abnormal test (excretion of <4.5 g) primarily reflects duodenal/jejunal mucosal disease.
 
  • For pancreatic malabsorption,we use the NBT-PABA and serum amylase assays.
  • Although, the gold standard for intestinal malabsorption is considered as faecal fat estimation, D-Xylose absorption is the best test.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2468.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy reports having stomach ache and complaints of blood in stools. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Intussusception




 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 283

choices.text: Inability to induce inflammation to remove the organism
Integration of viral DNA with host DNA

questions.text:
Asymptomatic hepatitis B affects 2–3 percent of the general population, but there is an increased risk of progression to hepatocellular carcinoma.
What could be the reason?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Integration of viral DNA with host DNA
 
  • HBV DNA serves as an insertional mutagenesis agent by randomly integrating into the chromosomes of hepatocytes.
  • 90% of HCCs linked to HBV experience integration of HBV DNA into the host genome, which has been proposed as an early occurrence in persistent viral infection.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 326.

questions.text: A patient on phenytoin for seizure disorder was prescribed sucralfate 4 times a day for peptic ulcer. What should be the minimum duration between consumption of two drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) 120 min

  • Sucralfate is a gastroprotective agent used in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease, oesophageal ulcers and as prophylaxis in radiation proctitis and stress ulcers. It acts by increasing prostaglandin secretion and also increases gastric pH.
  • Phenytoin is a weakly acidic drug and is absorbed from the stomach. Sucralfate raises the gastric pH, hence phenytoin will be in ionised form and can’t be absorbed normally.

So, a minimum gap of 2 hours must be present between consumption of phenytoin and sucralfate for phenytoin to be effective.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 21.

questions.text: The right upper quadrant of the abdomen is full in a 40-year-old obese woman. Her medical history is significant for both hyperlipidemia and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely one that a liver biopsy would point to?
questions.solution:
Non alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is used to describe clinical features of liver injury, such as elevated transaminases.

Commonly associated abnormalities are: -
a. Type 2 diabetes
b. Obesity, primarily central obesity)
c. Dyslipidemia
d. Hypertension



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2622.

questions.text: Which of the following  is not a feature of severe dehydration?
questions.solution:
Following are the features of severe dehydration except option A- Thirsty child.

Features of severe dehydration are:
  • Lethargic, apathetic, unconscious child
  • Drinks poorly, unable to drink
  • Skin pinch recoil in > 2 seconds


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 289

questions.text: In Barrett’s Esophagus:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Intestinal Metaplasia
 
  • Barrett's esophagus is a condition where the normal tissue in the esophagus is replaced by abnormal tissue that resembles the lining of the small intestine with goblet cells. 
  • Diagnosis of Barrett's esophagus is made by endoscopic guided biopsy.
  • Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present, but there is not universal agreement as to whether they are sufficient for the diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text: Which statement regarding octreotide is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Used in secretory diarrhea

Octreotide is used in secretory diarrhea. Octreotide is an octapeptide analog of somatostatin, effective in inhibiting the severe secretory diarrhea brought about by hormone-secreting tumors of the pancreas and the GI tract. It is preferentially administered subcutaneously.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 928.

questions.text: Progressive jaundice was detected in a patient who was 50 years old. LFT revealed SGOT-50, SGPT-65, alkaline phosphatase-550 IU, direct and total serum bilirubin levels of 4.8% and 6.7% respectively. On clinical examination GB was non palpable. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis is Jaundice due to choledocholithiasis.
 
  • High Conjugated (Direct) bilirubin and increased alkaline phosphatase levels point towards post hepatic obstruction as seen in case of choledocholithiasis.
 
  • Serum bilirubin levels > 20 mg/dL should suggest the possibility of neoplastic obstruction, which is not seen in this case.
 
  • Moreover, According to Courvoisier's law, GB is palpable in Malignant Obstructive jaundice (Periampullary CA) whereas it is non palpable in Choledocholithiasis, due to repeated inflammation and fibrosis.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2553, 2554, 2557

questions.text: An infant of three days old is experiencing repeated bilious vomiting. The results of an abdomen X-ray are displayed below. Which of the following will come next in the care of the patient in question?
questions.solution:
Radiographs are not always reliable in distinguishing between small and large bowel in newborns, making contrast studies, such as those with Water-soluble enemas (Gastrografin, Hypaque), beneficial for differentiating jejunoileal atresia from a meconium ileus or Hirschsprung disease, as was suggested by the X-ray that showed multiple dilated bowel loops and a history of recurrent bilious vomiting.



Reference:https://radiopaedia.org/articles/water-soluble-contrast-challenge

questions.text: What is the most important risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hepatitis B

Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a virus that can cause an acute or chronic liver infection.
Chronic HBV infection is a major risk factor for the development of liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 326.

choices.text: Ranitidine combines with sucralfate and prevents its action
Combination produces serious side effects like agranulocytosis
Ranitidine increases the gastric pH so sucralfate is not able to act

questions.text: Why is it wrong to combine ranitidine and sucralfate in a patient with a peptic ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ranitidine increases the gastric pH so sucralfate is not able to act
  • Ranitidine reduces gastric acid secretion (Increasing the gastric pH) by blocking the H2 receptors on the parietal cells in the stomach.
  • Polymerisation of Sucralfate only occurs at acidic pH - this polymer forms a protective coating over the ulcerated or damaged areas in the stomach preventng ulcer from coming in contact with HCl.
  • When ranitidine and sucralfate are taken together, sucralfate polymerisation is affected due to higher pH - this reduces the efficacy of Sucralfate.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 21.

choices.text: Negative nasogastric aspirate does not exclude variceal bleed
Nasogastric tube insertion can provoke variceal bleeding

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with alcoholic liver disease and a history of hematemesis presented to emergency. Which of the following statements about his management is false?
questions.solution:
NG tube insertion DO NOT provoke variceal bleed. Rather, it should be done to prevent aspiration in patients with acute variceal bleed. NG tube aspirate do not necessarily contain variceal bleed.
 
  • Treatment for esophageal varices as a complication of portal hypertension is divided into two main categories: (1) primary prophylaxis and (2) prevention of rebleeding once there has been an initial variceal hemorrhage.
 
  • Upper GI endoscopies are recommended at diagnosis of compensated cirrhosis and then every 2 years if the liver disease is active or every 3 years if inactive (alcohol cessation, viral hepatitis eradication). Endoscopy is also recommended at the time of hepatic decompensation.
 
  • The use of vasoconstricting agents, usually somatostatin or octreotide, has been shown to improve initial bleeding control and reduce transfusion requirements and all-cause mortality.
 
  • Balloon tamponade (Sengstaken-Blakemore tube or Minnesota tube) can be used in patients who need stabilization prior to endoscopic therapy or as a bridge to transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) after endoscopic failure


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2630.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl has a viral fever. She later has severe vomiting for five days and is admitted to the hospital. She develops cerebral edema while in the hospital. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in a liver biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Marked micro vesicular steatosis
 
  • Marked Micro vesicular steatosis can be seen in liver biopsy of this child, as the features are suggesting Reye Syndrome which is a genetic disorder that is triggered by a viral infection, such as influenza or varicella, and the use of salicylates.
  • Symptoms can include vomiting, encephalopathy, seizures, coma, and increased intracranial pressure that can lead to death. Liver biopsy typically shows micro vesicular steatosis without liver inflammation or necrosis.
  • Treatment includes screening for fatty-acid oxidation and fatty-acid transport defects as well as supportive care for symptoms.

Fig: Microvesicular Steatosis

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 826.

choices.text: 8 mg/dL (direct = 18.6 mg/dL) in the serum, respectively. What plausible diagnosis is there?
Acute hepatitis E superimposed on chronic liver failure due to hepatitis B
Fulminant hepatitis due to hepatitis B infection
Acute hepatitis E with chronic hepatitis A
Fulminant hepatitis due to hepatitis E infection

questions.text:
A pregnant woman of 27 years old arrives with severe jaundice and decreased sensory function. The patient is found to be severely icteric, unresponsive to orders, and the pelvic ultrasound shows an intrauterine foetal demise. The values of AST and ALT are 1063 and 28.8 mg/dL (direct = 18.6 mg/dL) in the serum, respectively. What plausible diagnosis is there? 
Viral indicators are: 
Anti-HAV lgG Reactive
Anti-HAV lgM Nonreactive
HbSAg Nonreactive
Anti-HbSAg Nonreactive
Anti-HBc lgM Nonreactive
Anti-HBc lgG Reactive
Anti-HCV lgG Nonreactive
Anti-HEV lgM Reactive
Anti-HEV lgG Nonreactive
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Fulminant hepatitis due to hepatitis E infection.
 
  • From the markers mentioned, it can be concluded that the patient is previously infected and immune to hepatitis A and hepatitis B. Since the IgM for hepatitis E is positive, the patient is suffering from Acute fulminant hepatitis E. This is common in pregnant women.
 
  • Hepatitis E causes fatal fulminant hepatitis in upto 20% cases in pregnant women.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2574, 2578.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in a previously healthy infant presenting with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain? The mother says that the child has been passing altered jelly like consistency stool after episodes of pain, but gives no history of vomiting or bleeding per rectum.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Intussusception 

The history given in the clinical vignette is of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and passage of altered jelly like consistency stools best matches with Intussusception. Intussusception is characterised by telescoping of one intestinal segment into another which results in mesenteric ischaemia and damage to the blood vessels/gut epithelia. This sloughed off epithelium mixed with blood gives the stool its jelly like consistency along with red colour resulting in the characteristic red currant jelly like stools.

Other Options
Option 1: Rectal Polyps – Characterised by painless bleeding per rectum and no colicky abdominal pain. 

Option 3: Necrotizing Enterocolitis – It occurs due to immaturity of the gut in preterms. Characterised by abdominal distension, decreased bowel sounds, Pneumatosis intestinalis, Pneumatosis portalis, Pneumoperitoneum, Peritonitis.

Option 4: Meckel Diverticulum – Characterised by features like haematochezia/ melena, right lower quadrant pain and does not have stools with jelly like consistency. 



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 283

questions.text: Jaundice and increased liver enzymes are seen in a young female patient. She had already experienced two instances that are comparable. Her IgG level was 2400 IU, and her serum ANA was 1:40. Her viral indicators were negative, and her serum copper levels were normal. After a liver biopsy, you administered immunosuppressants based on the pathology report, and the patient's condition got better. What was the pathology report's most probable finding and the recommended course of treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Autoimmune hepatitis

Autoimmune hepatitis has a variable clinical presentation. Patients may be asymptomatic or present in acute liver failure (rare), or anywhere between. It tends to have a relapsing-remitting course. There is an association with other autoimmune conditions.

* Depending on the phase, the patient may present with;

  • hepatomegaly +/- splenomegaly
  • jaundice
  • elevated aminotransferases (ALT and AST)

* Diagnostic criteria of autoimmune hepatitis include:

  • elevated antinuclear antibodies, anti-smooth muscle antibodies
  • globulin level of more than 20 g/L
  • coexistence of non-hepatic autoimmune diseases, including autoimmune thyroiditis, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic lupus
  • the elimination of other forms of hepatitis such as viral or toxic hepatitis
  • histologic examination findings consistent with AIH
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with abdominal pain, a binge drinking episode, shock, and a blood pressure of 70/50 mm Hg and a heart rate of 115 beats per minute arrives at the emergency room. The patient has an oxygen saturation level of 70 mm Hg. The amount of serum creatinine was 2.4 mg/dl and BUN 30 mg/dl. The patient's transaminases were elevated. Based on the CT scan below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Alcohol binge is a common cause of acute pancreatitis. Here the CT scan showing blurry margins of the pancreas is confirming the diagnosis.

Since vitals are unstable and end organ damage is developing as S. Cr is 2.4mg/dL and BUN is 30 mg/dl, therefore it is Severe Acute Pancreatitis. 

Markers for Severe acute Pancreatitis: 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2661.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in case of a 12 year old boy who is presented with hematemesis, Malena and mild splenomegaly? There is no obvious jaundice.
questions.solution:
• Clinical condition typically presents in children with portal hypertension due to obstruction of the portal vein outside the liver.
  • It often results in hematemesis (due to esophageal varices), splenomegaly, and normal liver function (no jaundice), making this the most likely diagnosis.

  • Non-Cirrhotic Portal Fibrosis (NCPF): This is also a cause of portal hypertension with splenomegaly and hematemesis, but it is more common in adults and would likely present with features such as ascites or liver dysfunction, which are not seen here.

  • Cirrhosis: Typically presents with signs of liver dysfunction such as jaundice, ascites, and potentially splenomegaly, along with portal hypertension. The absence of jaundice  in this patient makes cirrhosis less likely.

  • Malaria with DIC: Malaria can cause splenomegaly, but the absence of fever, jaundice, or signs of hemolysis makes malaria with DIC an unlikely diagnosis.



    Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4455142/

choices.text: Germline mutations in the cationic trypsinogen gene

questions.text: Which of the following is not an etiological cause for pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 3) Islet cell hyperplasia 
 
  • Islet cell hyperplasia does not cause pancreatitis.
  • Pancreatitis is inflammation of the pancreas. The most common cause of pancreatitis is alcohol abuse and chronic usage of certain medications, such as steroids and diuretics.
  • Other potential causes include gallstones, infections, abdominal trauma, auto-immune disorders, genetic disorders, and certain medications. In some cases, the cause of pancreatitis can be unknown.
* [Extra Edge]: Etiologic Factors in Acute Pancreatitis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 882.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effective tool for malabsorption research?
questions.solution:
13 C Triclosan is used for bad oral odor, not used in malabsorption.
 
  • The D-xylose absorption test is used in evaluation of malabsorption syndromes.
 
  • The 14 C-triolein and trioctanoin breath test is used for fat malabsorption.
 
  • The triolein breath test provided the most reliable discrimination, with 100% sensitivity and 96% specificity. The trioctanoin and tripalmitin breath tests were sensitive, but lacked specificity




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2468.

Young, Alix et al. “A study of triclosan and its solubilizers as inhibitors of oral malodour.” Journal of clinical periodontology vol. 29,12 (2002): 1078-81. doi:10.1034/j.1600-051x.2002.291205.x.URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12492907/

Newcomer, A D et al. “Triolein breath test: a sensitive and specific test for fat malabsorption.” Gastroenterology vol. 76,1 (1979): 6-13. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/758149/

questions.text: Which of the following describes a stomach epithelial tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Gastric adenocarcinoma
 
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma is a malignant epithelial tumor that arises from the glandular cells lining the stomach.
  • Gastric adenocarcinoma is a type of stomach cancer characterized by tumor invasion into the stomach wall, including the deeper layers. It can be classified into different histological types, such as intestinal and diffuse types, based on the appearance of tumor cells.
  • Pathologists also assess the tumor grade, ranging from well-differentiated to poorly differentiated, to determine the aggressiveness of the cancer.
* Other options:
  • Carcinoid tumors arise from neuroendocrine cells and are more commonly found in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Lymphoma refers to malignant tumors of lymphoid tissue and can occur in the stomach but is not specific to epithelial cells. GIST (Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor) is a mesenchymal tumor arising from Interstitial cells of Cajal and is not from epithelial cells.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 774.

questions.text: A young girl complains of stomach ache as well as a recent change in bowel habits that includes the passage of mucus in the stool. The symptoms are worsened by stress and there is no related blood in the stool. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Irritable bowel syndrome 

Here's a summary table on Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS):






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 24980, 2491.

questions.text: Pick the marker that is specific for Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST).
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) CD 117
 
  • DOG1 and CD117 were the most sensitive and specific antibodies used in GIST diagnosis.
  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are characterized by the expression of CD 117, also known as c-kit protein.
  • CD 117 is a transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinase that plays a crucial role in the pathogenesis of GIST. Immunohistochemical staining for CD 117 is commonly used to identify and diagnose GIST, as it is highly specific for this tumor type.

Other markers, such as CD 34 and S-100, may also be expressed in GIST, but CD 117 is considered the most specific and sensitive marker for GIST.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 778.

questions.text: Most common cause of chronic pancreatitis is:
questions.solution:
Chronic alcohol abuse is a major risk factor for developing chronic pancreatitis. Prolonged alcohol intake leads to pancreatic injury and inflammation, eventually resulting in the development of chronic pancreatitis.
 
  • Other causes of chronic pancreatitis include long-standing pancreatic calculi (option 2) that obstruct the pancreatic duct, pancreatic divisum (option 3), a congenital anatomical variation of the pancreatic ducts, and gallbladder stones (option 4), which can cause recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis but are less commonly associated with chronic pancreatitis.
 
  • A common mnemonic used to remember the causes of chronic pancreatitis is
  • TIGAR-O: Toxic-metabolic, Idiopathic, Genetic, Autoimmune, Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis and Obstructive
Most common cause of Acute pancreatitis is GB stone. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2665.

questions.text: What is the most typical site for a stomach ulcer?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is lesser curvature.

Gastric ulcers most commonly occur along the lesser curvature of the stomach, particularly near the junction of the body and antrum. This region is more susceptible to mucosal injury due to factors like H. pylori infection, NSAID use, and direct acid exposure.

Other options

  • The pyloric antrum is more commonly associated with duodenal ulcers rather than gastric ulcers.
  • The greater curvature is a less frequent site for ulcers, and when present, it raises concern for malignancy.
  • Ulcers in the large intestine are unrelated to stomach ulcers and are usually caused by inflammatory bowel disease, ischemia, or infections.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 767.

choices.text: Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.text: A 5 year old presented with acute liver failure. He has no history of Acetaminophen intake. Which of the following requirements does not fall under the purview of the King's College requirements for liver transplantation?
questions.solution:
The King’s college criteria for Acute Liver Failure stipulate that if acetaminophen is involved, the patient must have a PH level of less than 7.30, or a prothrombin time of over 100 seconds (INR of over 6.5). Additionally, the patient must have a serum creatinine value of over 3.4 mg/dl (300 mmol/l) if encephalopathy is present.

In cases where acetaminophen is not involved, the patient must have a prothrombin time over 100 seconds (INR over 6.5), or 3 of the following: age less than 10 years or over 40 years, non-A/non-B hepatitis, drug-induced, or idiosyncratic reactions, duration of jaundice before onset of encephalopathy over 7 days, prothrombin time over 50 seconds (INR 3.5) and a serum bilirubin of over 17.6 mg/dl (300 mmol).

King’s College Criteria for Liver transplantation in Acetaminophen and Non-Acetaminophen induced Acute Liver Failure: 





Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1195.

questions.text: Which of the following about Crohn's disease is untrue
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Continuous lesion visualized in endoscopy
 
  • The untrue statement is 2. Continuous lesion visualized in endoscopy.
  • Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the digestive tract, from the mouth to the anus.
  • While Crohn's disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum (the last part of the small intestine) and the colon, it can also affect the rectum. Crohn's disease can affect different segments of the gastrointestinal tract in a patchy manner, with skip lesions.
  • Involvement of the rectum in Crohn's disease can lead to symptoms such as rectal bleeding, mucous discharge, tenesmus (the feeling of incomplete evacuation), and perianal fistulas.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 800.

questions.text: The graph in the figure reflects the serology response in resolved HBV infection. What does the curve to which the arrow is pointing show ?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Anti HBc

Serological course of hepatitis B:
 
  



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2565.

questions.text: Select the most potential diagnosis used on a 20 year old patient with malabsorption diarrhoea and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient shows crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy and CD8 plus cells in lamina propria.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Celiac disease

  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder in which the body’s immune system attacks and damages the lining of the small intestine when foods containing gluten are consumed.
  • Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. Celiac disease can develop at any age and is thought to affect 1 in 100 people.
  • The damage to the small intestine caused by celiac disease leads to various findings in the body. First, malabsorption of important nutrients and vitamins can occur due to the damaged intestine.
  • This can lead to malnutrition, weight loss, and anemia. Other symptoms can include abdominal pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea, fatigue, and depression.
  • In addition, skin rashes like dermatitis herpetiformis, easy bruising, delayed growth and development, canker sores, and osteoporosis may also be present.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 784.

questions.text: Which of the following will you not do in a patient having massive hematemesis
questions.solution:
Platelet transfusion is NOT done in case of active variceal bleeding unless definite coagulopathy is documented. It is indicated only when Platelet count is < 50,000/microL or in patients with evidence of micro vascular bleeding.
 
  • Bleeding Esophageal Varices: The most frequent location for variceal haemorrhage is the lower oesophagus. The risk of bleeding of esophageal varices increases above 12 mm of Hg. It is a medical emergency. Those who have severe bleeding should be admitted to the intensive care unit.
 
  • Management Blood transfusions, colloids, and plasma expanders should all be used to reduce the blood volume. Rectify coagulopathy: Vitamin K (10 mg intravenously) is given, but fresh-frozen plasma must also be given to correct a coagulopathy (FFP). Esophageal balloon tamponade (Sengstaken-Blakemore tube): Four lumens are present in modified Sengstaken-Blakemore (old Sengstaken-Blakemore tube contains 3 tubes). One for esophageal balloon dilation, one for stomach aspiration, one for gastric balloon dilation, and one for esophageal aspiration.
 
  • Pharmacotherapy:  Somatostatin and octreotide, which are long-acting analogues of the hormone, are effective. Previously used vasopressin is also useful, but nitroglycerin must be administered in addition to it to prevent constriction of the coronary vessels. Terlipressin has recently become widely used to stop bleeding.
 
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunts (TIPSS) is an intrahepatic shunt done as definitive management of Esophageal varices. Urgent Endoscopy is also indicated. Studies have demonstrated that a lower rate of rebleeding and shorter length of hospital stay when endoscopy was performed within 24 hours of admission.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1203.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page no 274.

questions.text: A child, of age 5 diagnosed with anal polyp. The most Histopathological image is given below. What diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Juvenile Polyp

  • Juvenile polyps are a common type of polyp that occurs mostly in children and adolescents.
  • Diagnosis is usually made after a colonoscopy. During the colonoscopy, the doctor will take a small sample of the polyp and examine it under a microscope to confirm the diagnosis.
  • Other tests can also be used to diagnose juvenile polyps, including imaging tests, such as X-rays or CT scans, to get a better look at the inside of the colon.
  • Finally, a colon biopsy may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and to differentiate between benign and malignant polyps. Microscopy reveals dilated glands filled with mucin, inflammatory debris.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 808.

questions.text: What will be the colour of the iv cannula used in a patient with diarrhea and severe dehydration presenting in OPD, for rapid infusion of fluid?
questions.solution:
The 16 G grey cannula has a larger bore, which increases the flow rate. Hence, it is used for quick fluid replacement.





Reference: Equipment in Anaesthesia and Critical Care, 1st edition (2013), Page no 294.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man who complained of chronic mouth ulcers and congested eyes was seen in the OPD. Inquiries revealed that he had h/o prior hospitalization for venous thrombosis. What illness is he dealing with exactly
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Behcet's disease
 
  • The patient is dealing with Behcet's disease.
  • Behcet's disease is a systemic autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and eye inflammation (conjunctivitis/uveitis).
  • In addition, it can cause blood vessel inflammation, leading to thrombosis and other systemic manifestations.

* The international criteria for Behçet disease scoring system

Sign/Symptom Points
Ocular lesions 2
Genital aphthosis 2
Oral aphthosis 2
Skin lesions 1
Neurological manifestations 1
Vascular manifestations 1
Positive pathergy test 1

* Patients with a score of < 3 were considered as not having BD.
* A score of 3 was considered probable BD, and a score of ≥4 indicated a definitive diagnosis of BD. 

Online Reference:
Adil A, Goyal A, Quint JM. Behcet Disease. [Updated 2023 Feb 22]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470257/

questions.text: Hypothyroidism is now evident in the patient with h/o DM, and she is not gaining weight. What has to be done in terms of additional diagnostic research
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Anti TPO antibodies
 
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the thyroid gland, causing inflammation and damage to the thyroid cells.
  • This destruction and damage leads to a decrease in the production of thyroid hormones.
  • It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas where iodine is not deficient.
  • It is more commonly found in women than in men. It is associated with the presence of autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase (TPO), and there is a genetic component linked to the genes CTLA4 and PTPN22.
  • Histologically, the thyroid gland shows a mononuclear infiltrate, atrophic thyroid follicles and Hurthle cells.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2933, 2934.

choices.text: Failure of migration of Neural crest cells

questions.text: Hirschsprung disease is caused due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Failure of migration of Neural crest cells
 
  • Hirschsprung disease is caused due to failure of migration of neural crest cells during embryonic development.
  • Histopathological findings include the absence of ganglion cells in the affected segment of the colon.
  • Accumulation of fecal material above the aganglionic segment leads to distension of the colon.
  • PR examination lead to expulsion of feaces. 
  • Biopsy reveals hypertrophic nerve trunks and increased number of nerve fibers in the aganglionic segment.
  • The transition zone between the aganglionic and normal segments shows a characteristic "cuff" of hypertrophic nerves.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 755.

questions.text: Which test distinguishes between organic d/s and functional disorder of Bowel?
questions.solution:
Stool Calprotectin is a marker used to differentiate between IBS and IBD.

  • It is a protein released into the stool by white blood cells when inflammation is present in the intestinal wall. It is elevated in IBD due to the inflammatory process.
  • It is usually normal in IBS, but can occasionally be mildly elevated due to certain food triggers.
  • Fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin levels have been used to distinguish IBD from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), to assess whether CD is active, and to detect postoperative recurrence of CD.
  • Fecal calprotectin is a more sensitive marker of ileocolonic or colonic inflammation rather than isolated ileal inflammation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2477.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements applies to a person with advanced liver disease?
(i) Hyperammonemia
(ii) Low ATP production
(iii) Conversion of alpha-keto glutarate to glutamate and then to glutamine is increased
(iv) Alpha-keto glutarate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) i, ii & iii

  • In case of advanced liver disease / liver failure, conversion of NH3 to Urea (Urea Cycle) doesn’t take place in the liver.
  • As a result, NH3 accumulates in the body, especially in the neurons of brain where they bind all the H+ ions to form NH4+.
  • Because of H+ ion depletion, there is decreased ATP production via the ETC. Alpha ketoglutarate is the scavenger of NH3. It binds to form Glutamate.
  • Glutamate binds with NH3 to form Glutamine (carrier of NH3).

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2549.

questions.text: From the options given below, identify the one which is not a feature of the MELD score:
questions.solution:
Albumin among the following is not a component of MELD score.

MELD stands for model for end stage liver disease. MELD score is calculated using serum bilirubin, serum creatinine, and International normalised ratio (INR).

COMPONENTS OF MELD SCORE: [Mnemonic- C.B.I]
  1. Creatinine
  2. Bilirubin and
  3. INR (PT)
It may also include Sodium levels which is known as MELD-Na score.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2635, 2636.

questions.text: Which of the following is disrupted by cholera toxin (ZOT) in the intestinal epithelial cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Zonula occludens

Zonula occludens is disrupted by cholera toxin (ZOT) in the intestinal epithelial cells.
  • Other than the well-known CT and TCP toxins, Vibrio has been extensively investigated with respect to Zot, RTX, and Ace among others. 
  • CT toxin- made up of A and B subunits. B binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors in intestinal mucosal cells. A causes production of Adenyl cyclase, this increases cAMP which activates CFTR causing increased secretion of chloride ions. 
  • Zot toxin- zona occludens toxin, alters the tight junctions. Induces a transitory reduction in transepithelial electrical resistance and an increase in transepithelial flux, increasing the permeability of TJs.
  • ACE toxin - integral membrane protein that affects ion transport, builds up in ligated rabbit ileal loops, and produces moderate diarrhea.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 12.

questions.text:
40 yr female presents with abdominal pain and gross distension. Vitals are stable. P/A findings shows presence of dullness in flanks ?

i. Minimum amount of fluid should be 1500ml to show shifting dullness in flanks
ii. Minimum amount of fluid should be 500ml to show shifting dullness in flanks
iii. USG can detect minimum < 100ml
iv. USG can detect minimum > 500ml
v. Most common cause is cirrhosis
questions.solution:
• Minimal amount of fluid present to demonstrate shifting dullness is 500ml, for horse shoe shaped dullness is 1000 ml and for fluid thrill is 1500 ml.
 
  • USG is the most sensitive modality to detect ascites for it can detect minimum of 100 ml of ascitic fluid. 
  • Abdominal ultrasonography can detect as little as 100 mL of ascitic fluid, hepatosplenomegaly, a nodular liver, or a mass.
 
  • Most common cause of Ascites is DCLD due to Liver Cirrhosis. Cirrhosis accounts for 84% of cases of ascites.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 322, 323.

questions.text: What is the most likely primary site of a female with metastatic liver adenocarcinoma with CK7-, CK20+, and CDX-1 IHC markers
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Colorectal ca
 
  • CDX-1 + IHC marker for metastatic liver adenocarcinoma means colorectal carcinoma is the possible answer.
  • Transcription factors unique to the gut require genes CDX-1 and 2 which control intestine phenotypic development, differentiation, and maintenance.
  • CK7 and CK 20 are used to identify organ of origin in carcinoma of unknown primary. 
  • Colorectal Adeno Ca is ck 7 negative.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 814.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient was admitted with severe ascites and had an abdominal paracentesis. The fluid is clear, cell-free under a microscope, and contains ascitic albumin levels of 1.2 g/dl and ascitic protein level of 2.1 g/dl. Serum albumin levels is 3.5 g/dl. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The etiology is Late Budd Chiari syndrome.

SAAG = S. albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin = 3.5-1.2= 2.3 gm%.

Causes of SAAG > 1.1% with Ascitic protein < 2.5% are:
  • Cirrhosis
  • Late Budd-Chiari syndrome
  • Massive liver metastases





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 323.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about Peutz-Jeghers syndrome?
 A. Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is most common extra-intestinal manifestation
 B. Arborising pattern 
 C. STK-11 mutation
 D. Autosomal recessive
 E. Multiple GI polyps
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) B, C, E are correct

* Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is one of the polyposis syndromes due to mutation in tumor suppressor gene STK11. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and is characterized by:

  • multiple hamartomatous polyps, most commonly involving the small intestine (predominantly the jejunum), but also colon and stomach; mouth and esophagus are spared

  • mucocutaneous melanin pigmentation involving the mouth, fingers and toes

* Peutz-Jeghers polyps are non-neoplastic hamartomas due to the proliferation of all three layers of the mucosa, which have a characteristic feature of a smooth muscle core continuous with muscularis mucosa in a tree-like branching pattern.

* Patients are at increased risk of:

  • Intussusception
  • GI tract adenocarcinoma, although the polyps themselves are not premalignant

* Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium is the most common extra-intestinal manifestation of familial adenomatous polyposis coli (FAP) syndrome. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 809.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male patient who had a history of smoking enters the OPD at AIIMS with fever, tiredness, jaundice, and yellow urine and faeces. He had grown wary of smoking cigarettes over the last few days. On inspection, scleral icterus was discovered. LFT are
Total Bilirubin 18.5
Direct Bilirubin 7.5
SGOT 723
SGPT 812
What investigations will you send for ruling out acute viral hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Anti-HAV, HBsAg, IgM antiBc, Anti-HCV investigations are done to detect the presence of the hepatitis viruses that cause acute viral hepatitis.

We mainly test for Hepatitis A, B and C. Hepatitis D and E are rarely tested.
 
  • The anti-HAV antibody test is done to detect the presence of the Hepatitis A virus, which is transmitted by direct contact with infected material such as food or water that has been contaminated with the virus.
 
  • Hepatitis E is not tested routinely as majority of patients who acquire HEV infection spontaneously resolves or clears the virus. ALF is more likely in Pregnant, malnourished and patients with previous history of Liver disease.
 
  • The HBsAg test is used to detect the presence of the hepatitis B virus, which is typically spread through contact with bodily fluids of an infected person.
 
  • The IgM anti-HBC test is used to detect the presence of Hepatitis C, which is most often spread through contact with the blood of an infected person.
 
  • The Anti-HCV test is done to detect the presence of the hepatitis C virus, which is transmitted through contact with infected blood or other bodily fluids.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 74-77, 2562-2568.

questions.text: The absence of marked Cells will present with all except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Zollinger Ellison syndrome

The marked structures are Parietal Cells which secrete HCl and Castle's intrinsic factor.

Within the stomach, the most remarkable feature is a marked increase in oxyntic mucosal thickness due to massive parietal cell hyperplasia. Gastrin also induces hyperplasia of mucous neck and endocrine cells within oxyntic mucosa.
In case of Zollinger Ellison syndrome, there is massive parietal cell hyperplasia.

* They are absent in:
  • Vit B12 deficiency
  • Intrinsic factor deficiency
  • Type 1 gastric carcinoid syndrome

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 773.

questions.text:
Recurrent respiratory tract infections and passing of large, oily stools in a 13-year-old child.
The amount of fat in the feces was considerable. Which statement about this ailment is accurate?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of Cystic Fibrosis, obstruction of small intestine occurs due to pellet formation. 


Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2176.
Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 2284, 2287.

choices.text: APC, Kras and loss of 10 on nyc

questions.text: A colon cancer diagnosis has been made for a male patient. Which of the following genetic changes is most likely to exist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) APC, Kras, P53

In this patient APC, Kras, P53 gene mutations are likely to be present.

* [Extra Edge]: Adenoma-carcinoma sequence:
Fearon and Vogelstein proposed this classic model for the multistage progression of colorectal cancer.
  • A mutation in the APC tumor suppressor gene is generally considered to be the initiation event.
  • This is followed by the sequential accumulation of other epigenetic and genetic changes that eventually result in the progression from a normal cell to a metastatic tumor.
  • The classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence accounts for up to 80% of sporadic cancers and typically includes mutation of APC early in the neoplastic process.
  • Sequence of genetic mutations is in this order APC -> Kras -> P53
  • With loss of APC function, β-catenin accumulates and translocates to the nucleus, where it forms a complex with the DNA-binding factor TCF and activates the transcription of genes, including MYC and cyclin D1, that promote proliferation.
Memorizing Trick: -
AK53- APC, KRAS, P53

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 814.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old female patient with atrial fibrillation and mitral stenosis was diagnosed.
No thrombus is shown on the ECHO. Which of the following prevents stroke the best in feature?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Oral warfarin
 
  • Irregular heartbeats (atrial fibrillation) and narrowing of the mitral valve (mitral stenosis) can cause blood clots, posing a stroke risk.
  • Both conditions increase the risk of blood clot formation in the heart, which can potentially travel to the brain and cause a stroke.
  • In the absence of a thrombus on ECHO, the patient is at risk for developing a blood clot in the heart.
  • Oral Warfarin has been shown to be effective in preventing strokes in patients with atrial fibrillation and mitral stenosis.

Anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation:
Anticoagulation is indicated for patients with mitral stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, previous history of stroke. In nonvalvular atrial fibrillation, the risk of stroke and the need for anticoagulation is assessed with the CHA2DS2-VASc score.

Anticoagulants that can be used include:
  • Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
  • Antithrombin inhibitor - Dabigatran
  • Factor Xa inhibitors - Rivaroxaban, Apixaban, and Edoxaban
 
  • In AF patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves, the anticoagulant of choice is warfarin. The newer anticoagulants are not yet tested for rheumatic heart disease.
  • Warfarin is a less compliant drug because it requires routine PT/INR monitoring for dose adjustments and has many drug interactions. The newer oral anticoagulants are easy to use and do not require PT/INR monitoring for dose adjustments.



Anticoagulation in A. fib Trick- 
Valvular pathology- Warfarin
No valvular pathology- NOACs 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1906.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with cirrhosis. Eosinophilic material that was cytokeratin-positive during the liver biopsy was CK 8+ and CK 18+. What is it most likely composed of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Intermediate
 
  • Patients with chronic alcoholism and purulent destructive pulmonary diseases have been found to have an accumulation of intermediate filaments in their lung macrophages and endotheliocytes.
  • In liver accumulation of cytokeratin 8 and 18 is known as Malory Denk Body. 
  • Cytoskeletal components that build up excessively are an indication of cell dystrophy.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 837.

questions.text: What types of salivary gland tumours are most common?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Pleomorphic adenoma
 
* ADENOMA PLEOMORPHIC 
  • Most common benign salivary gland tumor. 
  • It can develop from the submandibular, parotid, or other small salivary glands. It typically comes from the parotid's tail. 
  • Pleomorphic adenomas are slow-growing tumors that might present fairly large. 
  • They occur in females of the third or fourth decade. Because both epithelial and mesenchymal components can be observed in histology, they are known as "mixed tumors."
  • The tumor's stroma can vary in type—it could be mucoid, fibroid, vascular, myxochondroid, or chondroid—and its epithelial proportion may vary.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 748.

  • ￲high urinary excretion of copper￲

questions.text: The correct statement about celiac disease is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Can cause GI Lymphoma

True about celiac disease is that it can cause GI lymphoma.
  • Enteropathy associated T Cell lymphoma can be caused due to celiac disease.
  • Which is a rare gastrointestinal non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, originating from intraepithelial T-lymphocyte, which is specifically associated with celiac disease.
  • It is diagnosed on biopsy and the disease worsens further on consumption of complex carbohydrates.

questions.text: What condition among the following carries a high chance of developing hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which is the most common type of intestinal fistula in Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ileosigmoid

Crohn's disease can cause fistula formation between different parts of the gastrointestinal tract.
  • Types of intestinal fistulas in Crohn's disease:
    • Enterocutaneous: Fistula between the intestine and the skin.
    • Ileosigmoid: Fistula between the ileum (part of the small intestine) and the sigmoid colon (part of the large intestine).
    • Gastrocolic: Fistula between the stomach and the colon.
    • Rectovaginal: Fistula between the rectum and the vagina.
  • Among these, the ileosigmoid fistula is the most common in Crohn's disease.
  • Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus.
  • It is characterized by inflammation, ulcers, and scarring of the intestinal walls, which can lead to the formation of fistulas.
  • An ileosigmoid fistula is a connection between the ileum (the last part of the small intestine) and the sigmoid colon (the last part of the large intestine). It can develop as a complication of Crohn's disease when inflammation and ulcers erode through the intestinal walls and create a passageway between the two organs. Symptoms of an ileosigmoid fistula may include abdominal pain, diarrhea, bloating, and fever. Treatment typically involves surgery to remove the affected portion of the intestine and repair the fistula. 
* [Extra Edge]: Crohn’s vs ulcerative colitis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 800.

questions.text: Which of the following salivary glands is the source of deep plunging ranula?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Sublingual gland.
 
  • A ranula is a type of mucous retention cyst in the floor of the mouth.
  • It results from the obstruction of salivary gland ducts, causing the accumulation of saliva.
  • Deep plunging ranulas are a specific type of ranula that are located in the submandibular space.
  • They are caused by a leakage of saliva from the sublingual gland into the submandibular space.
  • The sublingual gland, located under the tongue, can lead to deep plunging ranulas when its saliva leaks into the submandibular space.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 833, 834.

questions.text: Salivary gland tumor was exclusively seen in parotid gland-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer Is (Option 1) Warthin's tumor

Many other tumors in the body show similar morphology as the salivary gland tumors such Pleomorphic adenoma of skin (chondroid syringoma), Adenoid cystic variant adenocarcinoma of endometrium, Warthin's tumor however is seen only in salivary gland.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 749.

questions.text: Which is the most common part of GIT involved in Hirschsprung disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rectosigmoid 
 
  • Hirschsprung disease is a congenital disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal segment of the colon and rectum.
  • Ganglion cells are necessary for the normal peristaltic movement of the intestine.
  • The most common part of the gastrointestinal tract involved in Hirschsprung disease is the rectosigmoid region (junction of the rectum and sigmoid colon).
  • Other parts of the colon, such as the descending colon, transverse colon, or entire colon, can also be affected.
  • The involvement of the small intestine is less common.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 755.

questions.text: The Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is not diagnosed using which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Gastrin stimulation test.
 
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) causes excessive production of gastrin, a hormone that stimulates stomach acid production. This can lead to ulcers in the stomach and duodenum.
  • Gastrin stimulation test is not used for ZES diagnosis due to potential false-positive results in conditions like chronic kidney disease.

The diagnosis of ZES is made using a combination of tests, including:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2453, 2454.

questions.text: The following conditions does not cause predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rotor syndrome 

Rotor syndrome, also known as Rotor type hyperbilirubinemia, is an autosomal recessive disease and a rare cause of mixed direct (conjugated) and indirect (unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia. The disease is characterized by non-hemolytic jaundice due to chronic elevation of predominantly conjugated bilirubin.
  • Rotor syndrome does not cause predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is caused by an increase in the level of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood, which is usually due to either increased production or decreased clearance of bilirubin.
  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, on the other hand, is caused by an increase in the level of conjugated bilirubin in the blood, which is usually due to impaired excretion of bilirubin.
  • Hypothyroidism, hemolysis, and physiological jaundice can all cause predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • In hypothyroidism, there is decreased clearance of bilirubin due to decreased activity of liver enzymes. In hemolysis, there is increased production of bilirubin due to breakdown of red blood cells.
  • In physiological jaundice, there is increased production of bilirubin due to immature liver function.
  • Rotor syndrome, on the other hand, is a rare genetic disorder that causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is characterized by the accumulation of bilirubin in the liver and blood due to impaired excretion of bilirubin. However, it is important to note that unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia may also be present in some cases of Rotor syndrome, but it is not the predominant feature.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 853.

questions.text:
Which class of antibodies is most frequently linked to autoimmune pancreatitis?
1. IgG1
2. IgG2
3. IgG3
4. IgG4
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: IgG4
 
  • Autoimmune pancreatitis is associated with the class of antibodies known as IgG4.
  • IgG4-related disease is characterized by inflammation and fibrosis due to infiltration of tissues by IgG4-positive plasma cells.
  • Elevated levels of IgG4 antibodies are commonly observed in autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP1) and serve as an important diagnostic marker for the disease.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2664, 2666.

questions.text: Which is the most common benign tumor of the salivary gland?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Mixed cell parotid neoplasm
  • The most common benign tumor of the salivary gland is a mixed cell tumor, also known as pleomorphic adenoma, because of its dual origin from epithelial and myoepithelial elements. It is the commonest of all salivary gland tumors constituting up to two-thirds of all salivary gland tumors and is most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • This tumor accounts for approximately 60-70% of all salivary gland tumors.
  • It typically arises from the parotid gland, which is the largest salivary gland located in front of the ear.
  • Mixed cell tumors are composed of both epithelial and mesenchymal cells, which give rise to the diverse histologic appearance and varied clinical behavior.
  • They are slow-growing and painless, and usually present as a painless, mobile mass that has been present for months or years.
  • Histologically, mixed cell tumors are characterized by a mixture of ductal epithelial cells, myoepithelial cells, and stromal cells.
  • The epithelial cells form duct-like structures, while the myoepithelial cells are spindle-shaped and surround the epithelial cells.
  • The stromal cells are responsible for the production of the myxoid or chondroid matrix which gives the tumor its characteristic rubbery consistency.
  • Surgical excision is the treatment of choice for mixed cell tumors, and the prognosis is generally favorable with a low rate of recurrence.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 748.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about osmotic diarrhoea is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Osmol gap < 50
 
  • Osmotic diarrhea is caused by osmotically active solutes in the stool, leading to watery diarrhea.
  • The osmolar gap, which measures the difference between stool and plasma osmolality, is typically greater than 50 in osmotic diarrhea.
  • Stool osmotic gap is calculated as 290 mOsm/kg − 2 × (stool Na + stool K). 290 mOsm/kg is the presumed stool osmolality, and the measured concentration of sodium and potassium cations is doubled to account for the corresponding anions which must be present.
  • The characteristic features of osmotic diarrhea:
    • Watery diarrhea. The stool is typically watery with a volume of >1 L/day.
    • Osmolar gap > 50.
    • Stool does not contain blood, pus, or mucus.
    • Stool does not contain blood, pus, or mucus.
    • Diarrhea stops after fasting. If the patient fasts, the diarrhea will stop, as there will be no food in the intestine to cause the osmotic effect.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 303.

questions.text: Which of the following exhibits a predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Common bile duct stone
 
  • Hyperbilirubinemia refers to increased levels of bilirubin in the blood.
  • Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is characterized by increased levels of conjugated bilirubin.
  • The common bile duct stone can cause obstruction of the bile flow, leading to the accumulation of conjugated bilirubin in the blood.
* Other options:
  • Physiological jaundice is a transient condition in newborns and is characterized by unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Breast milk jaundice is a condition that occurs in breastfed infants and is also associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Hypothyroidism can lead to impaired bilirubin conjugation but is not associated with predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2560.

questions.text: All stomach conditions are premalignant, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Hiatus Hernia
 
  • Hiatus hernia is not considered premalignant.
  • It is a condition where a portion of the stomach protrudes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity.
  • While hiatus hernia can cause symptoms like acid reflux, it is not directly associated with an increased risk of malignancy or cancer development in the same way that conditions like atrophic gastritis or pernicious anemia are.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 629, 630.

questions.text: Typically, pseudopolyps are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ulcerative colitis 
 
  • Pseudo polyps are inflammatory polypoid lesions that can be seen in the colon and rectum.
  • They are typically observed in the setting of chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal mucosa.
  • Ulcerative colitis, an inflammatory bowel disease, is one of the conditions in which pseudo polyps are commonly seen.
  • Pseudo polyps are formed due to the regeneration of the mucosal epithelium in areas of ulceration and destruction.
Crohn’s vs ulcerative colitis:
