questions.text: Which of the following statements about Menetrier disease is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Usually increased acid secretion
 
  • Menetrier disease is characterized by gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, protein-losing gastropathy, and hypochlorhydria.
  • This disease is caused by the overexpression of TGF- alpha, which increases the growth of mucous cells.
  • The increased number of mucous cells leads to giant rugal folds.
  • The resulting excessive production of mucous in the stomach causes an increased loss of proteins and chloride from the body.
  • Patients with Menetrier disease usually present with diarrhea, hypoproteinemia, and anemia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2458.

questions.text: The APC gene is mutated in every single one of the genetic disorders listed below that are linked to colorectal cancer, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Lynch Syndrome 
 
  • The APC (adenomatous polyposis coli) gene is a tumor suppressor gene involved in the regulation of cell growth and division.
  • Mutations in the APC gene are associated with various forms of familial colorectal cancer syndromes.
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), Gardner's syndrome, and Turcot's syndrome are all linked to mutations in the APC gene.
  • However, Lynch syndrome, also known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is caused by mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes and not the APC gene.


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 813.

questions.text: Which antibodies are ordinarily high in primary biliary Cholangitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Antimitochondrial antibodies 

Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC)
  • PBC is an autoimmune disease characterized by nonsuppurative, inflammatory destruction of small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Large intrahepatic ducts and the extrahepatic biliary tree are not involved.
  • Disease of middle-aged women, with a female predominance of 9:1.
  • Antimitochondrial antibodies are the most characteristic laboratory finding in PBC.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2627.

questions.text: Which of the following liver areas is most vulnerable to ischemia damage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Centrilobular
 
  • The centrilobular (zone III) region of the liver is the most vulnerable to ischemic damage.
  • This area is the furthest from the oxygenated blood supply and thus receives the lowest oxygen tension.
  • When blood flow to the liver is compromised, such as in cases of severe hypotension or liver ischemia, the centrilobular zone is the first to be affected.
  • Centrilobular necrosis is commonly seen in conditions like ischemic hepatitis (shock liver) and drug-induced liver injury.
* [Extra Edge]: Nutmeg liver
  • Congestion of the hepatic and portal vessels may produce pathologic changes in the liver, the spleen, and the gastrointestinal tract.
  • The liver is usually increased in size and weight (congestive hepatomegaly) caused by passive congestion, greatest around the central veins Grossly, this is reflected as congested red brown pericentral zones, with relatively normal-colored tan periportal regions, producing the characteristic “nutmeg liver” appearance.
  • In some instances, especially when left-sided heart failure with hypoperfusion is also present, severe centrilobular hypoxia produces centrilobular necrosis. With longstanding severe right-sided heart failure, the central areas can become fibrotic, eventually culminating in cardiac cirrhosis



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 533.

questions.text: Which is an exception to Large bowel Colonic Diarrhea associations?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Large Volume stool 

Large Volume stool: In large bowel colonic diarrhea, the stool volume is typically reduced due to impaired water reabsorption in the colon.

Features of Large bowel colonic diarrhea :
  • Urgency: There is a sudden and strong urge to have a bowel movement.
  • Tenesmus: The feeling of incomplete evacuation and persistent desire to pass stool, even after bowel movements.
  • Mucus: Presence of mucus in the stool.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 298, 299.

questions.text: Except for___, all of the following are components of Snover's triad in acute cellular rejection of liver transplantation.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 3. Cholangitis.

Snover's triad, which is associated with acute cellular rejection of liver transplantation, includes:

  1. Portal inflammation: Infiltration of inflammatory cells in the portal areas.
  2. Endothelialitis: Inflammation of the endothelial cells in the small bile ducts and portal vessels.
  3. Periportal fibrosis: Fibrosis around the portal tracts.

Cholangitis, on the other hand, is not a component of Snover's triad but is a separate condition that can occur due to bile duct complications or infections. Cholangitis is a component of Charcot's triad. 


Online Reference: 
Górnicka B, Ziarkiewicz-Wróblewska B, Bogdańska M, Ołdakowska-Jedynak U, Wróblewski T, Morton M, Ziółkowski J, Paczek L, Krawczyk M, Wasiutyński A. Pathomorphological features of acute rejection in patients after orthotopic liver transplantation: own experience. Transplant Proc. 2006 Jan-Feb;38(1):221-5. doi: 10.1016/j.transproceed.2006.01.002. PMID: 16504708.

questions.text: Congenital Hypertrophy of Retinal Pigment Epithelium (CHRPE) is associated with which of the Gastrointestinal Polyposis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Gardner's syndrome 
 
  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) presents with pigmented ocular fundus and is usually associated with familial adenomatous polyposis, and Gardner's syndrome is a subtype of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a gastrointestinal polyposis syndrome caused by mutations in the APC gene.
  • CHRPE is often found in individuals with Gardner's syndrome, making it a significant clinical feature in the diagnosis of this gastrointestinal polyposis syndrome.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1356.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl who had previously experienced protracted fever and discomfort in her abdomen was found to have splenomegaly and leukopenia. She developed an acute abdominal incident throughout the course of the illness and passed away. What is the most likely outcome of the autopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Longitudinal ulcers
 
  • The given clinical scenario suggests a case of Typhoid disease
  • Longitudinal ulcers are seen in Typhoid 
  • Ulcer may perforated -> peritonitis and finally may lead to death 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 923.

questions.text: Which is the best provocative test for diagnosis of Gastrinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Secretin injection test 
 
  • Gastrinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that produces excess gastrin, a hormone stimulating stomach acid production.
  • The secretin injection test is used to diagnose gastrinoma by injecting secretin and measuring gastrin levels in the blood afterward.
  • Secretin is a hormone released by the pancreas to regulate stomach acid production in response to food intake.
  • The most sensitive and specific gastrin provocative test for the diagnosis of gastrinoma is the secretin study. An increase in gastrin of ≥120 pg within 15 min of secretin injection has a sensitivity and specificity of >90% for Gastrinoma in ZES. 

Other options:
  • Infusion test: Measures pancreatic function
  • ACTH stimulation test: Assesses adrenal gland function
  • Steroid assay: Measures steroid levels in the blood.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2454.

questions.text: Chronic liver disease can be associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Alpha-1 Antitrypsin deficiency 
 
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) is a protein that helps to protect the lungs from damage.
  • People with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency do not produce enough AAT, which can lead to damage to the lungs and liver.
  • Chronic liver disease is a condition in which the liver is damaged over a long period of time. It can be caused by a number of factors, including alcohol abuse, hepatitis, and alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

Other options:
  • Hepatitis A: Viral infection that can cause acute liver inflammation.
  • Chronic malaria: Can cause liver damage, but it is not as common as alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
  • Infectious mononucleosis: Viral infection that can cause inflammation of the lymph nodes, but it does not typically affect the liver.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2591, 2624.

questions.text: Celiac disease has which of the following vitamin deficiencies as uncommon?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Vitamin B12
 
  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder that damages the small intestine when gluten is ingested.
  • Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.
  • The damaged small intestine is unable to absorb certain nutrients properly, leading to various deficiencies.
  • In celiac disease, it is uncommon to have a deficiency in Vitamin B12. Vitamin B12 deficiency is more frequently associated with other gastrointestinal disorders that affect the absorption of this vitamin.
  • Vit B12 absorption mainly happens in Ileum, which is unaffected in Celiac disease. Celiac diseases predominantly affects Duodenum followed by jejunum. Jejunum is the principal site of Folate absorption.

The other common vitamin deficiencies associated with celiac disease include:
 
  1. Vitamin D
  2. Folic Acid (Vitamin B9)
  3. Vitamin A



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2460.

questions.text: Which medication is prescribed for constipating-related irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Lubiprostone

Lubiprostone is a chloride channel activator. It promotes the secretion of water and chloride into the bowel and improves bowel movements. It is effective in the treatment of constipation predominant IBS.

Other options:
 
  • Cholestyramine resin – used in the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS.
  • Alosetron, a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist used in the treatment of IBS relieves pain and abdominal discomfort. It causes constipation in IBS patients with diarrhea alternating with constipation.
  • Rifaximin is a RNA synthesis inhibitor approved for use in diarrhea-predominant IBS.

IBS management:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2496.

questions.text: An individual receiving ketoconazole treatment for a fungus develops gastroesophageal reflux illness (GERD). Which medication from the list below shouldn't be given to him?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Cisapride
 
  • Cisapride is a prokinetic agent. Its prokinetic action is exerted mainly through 5-HT4 agonism aided by weak 5-HT3 antagonism.
  • It enhances gastrointestinal motility and is often used to treat conditions like GERD and gastroparesis.
  • However, cisapride has a potential interaction with ketoconazole, which can lead to an increased risk of life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias (specifically, QT prolongation).
  • Due to this risk, cisapride should not be given to individuals who are taking ketoconazole or other medications that can prolong the QT interval.
  • Metoclopromide and Domperidone may also cause QTc prolongation but its frequency and severity is much less Cisapride

Drugs causing QT prolongation: 





Prokinetics :





Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 715, 716.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies occurs most frequently in short bowel syndrome with ileal resection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Vitamin B12 (Cyanocobalamin)
 
  • Short bowel syndrome is a condition that occurs when a significant portion of the small intestine is surgically removed or non-functional, leading to malabsorption of nutrients.
  • The ileum, the last part of the small intestine, is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12.
  • In cases of ileal resection, the absorption of vitamin B12 is impaired, resulting in a deficiency of this vitamin.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to various symptoms and complications, including megaloblastic anemia, neurological issues, and gastrointestinal problems.
  • Absorption of Fat soluble vitamins are also impaired




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2465, 2466.

questions.text: The most typical vitamin deficiency associated with short bowel syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Vitamin B12
 
  • Short bowel syndrome is a condition that occurs when a significant portion of the small intestine is surgically removed or non-functional, leading to malabsorption of nutrients.
  • The ileum, the last part of the small intestine, is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12.
  • In cases of ileal resection, the absorption of vitamin B12 is impaired, resulting in a deficiency of this vitamin.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to various symptoms and complications, including megaloblastic anemia, neurological issues, and gastrointestinal problems.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2465, 2466.

questions.text: A man comes in with a history of hematemesis involving 500 ml of blood. Spleen is detectable on inspection 5 cm below the left costal border. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Portal Hypertension
 
  • Portal hypertension: Increased pressure in the portal vein, which carries blood from the intestines to the liver.
  • When portal hypertension is present, it can lead to the development of varices (dilated veins) in the esophagus and stomach, which are prone to bleeding.
  • Hematemesis (vomiting of blood) is a common symptom in patients with portal hypertension and ruptured esophageal or gastric varices.
  • The detectable spleen below the left costal border is known as splenomegaly and is often associated with portal hypertension.

Causes of portal HTN :



Varices:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2629.

questions.solution:
component of counter current multiplier mechanisms are 1. Collecting duct 2. Thick ascending limb of loop of henley 3.Thin ascending limb of loop of henley. Vasa Recta acts as Counter current exchanger and helps in maintaining the counter-current mechanism.

questions.text: What is the most typical nephropathy linked to cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Membranous glomerulonephritis

Membranous glomerulonephritis is the most typical nephropathy linked to malignancy.

In 20–30% of cases, MGN is secondary and is associated with a malignancy (solid tumors of the breast, lung, colon), infection (hepatitis B, syphilis, malaria, schistosomiasis), rheumatologic disorders such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis, IgG4 diseases, or drug exposure.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: What medication is used to prevent acute mountain sickness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Acetazolamide

Acetazolamide can provide symptomatic relief in patients with high-altitude illness or mountain sickness in which there is Weakness, dizziness, insomnia, headache, and nausea in mountain travelers who rapidly ascend above 3000 meters.
 
  • Acetazolamide can improve breathing and lessen the effects of mountain sickness by reducing CSF production and by lowering the pH of the CSF and brain.
  • Furthermore helpful in the management of sleep apnea is this modest metabolic central and CSF acidosis.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 633.

choices.text: Urine protein levels range from 30 mg/d to 300 mg/d
It is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity in diabetic patients
It is the earliest marker of diabetic nephropathy
It is detected by routine dipstick method

questions.text: Which of the following medications is incorrect about microalbuminuria?
questions.solution:
• Microalbuminuria cannot  be detected using routine dipstick tests as they are insensitive to low levels of albumin in urine.
 
  • Routine dipstick methods typically detect higher concentrations of protein, and may not be sensitive enough to detect microalbuminuria, but some specialized dipstick tests or laboratory tests may be able to detect.
 
  • Microalbuminuria is beneath detection by urinary dipstick protein analysis. Any detectable albuminuria on dipstick is called overt proteinuria and when detected at the highest level on the strip is consistent with Nephrotic range proteinuria.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2282.

choices.text: 5 mg/dL, and his serum albumin level was 2.5 gm/L.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old child was seen with frothy urine, oliguria, and edema. He hasn't previously received any complaints like this. His urine was examined and revealed 3+ proteinuria, no RBCs or WBCs, and no casts. His blood creatinine level was 0.5 mg/dL, and his serum albumin level was 2.5 gm/L.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A 10-year old child presents with edema, oliguria and frothy urine with no past history of similar complaints. On examination, urine is positive for 3+ proteinuria, no RBCs/WBCs and no casts, with serum albumin 2.5 glL and serum creatinine 0.5 mg/ dL, the most likely diagnosis is minimal change disease.
  • Main features of Nephrotic syndrome- Massive proteinuria, Hypoalbuminemia, Edema and Hyperlipidemia.
  • Most common cause of Nephrotic syndrome in children- Minimal Change Disease.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 472

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effect of efferent arteriolar constriction?
questions.solution:
• Increased proteins that escape filtration in glomerular capillaries as a result of efferent arteriole constriction cause an increase in oncotic pressure (not a decrease in oncotic pressure) in glomerular and peritubular capillaries.

Reference-: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no 341

questions.text: An older male patient complained of eyesight blurriness. Cotton wool patches were seen on the retina during a fundus examination, and a systemic test revealed diminished peripheral sensations and decreased urine production. What result did the subsequent kidney biopsy reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesion.

Above clinical scenario is Common finding in case of Diabetic Retinopathy with Cotton wool spot with involvement of kidney microvasculature. 

  • In view of Diabetic nephropathy these 3 lesions are encountered: (1) glomerular lesions; (2) renal vascular lesions, principally arteriolosclerosis; and (3) pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis.
  • The most important glomerular lesions are capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and nodular glomerulosclerosis.

* [Extra Edge]: Nodular Glomerulosclerosis or Kimmelstiel-Wilson Disease

  • In this disease the glomerular lesions take the form of ovoid or spherical, often laminated, PAS-positive nodules of matrix situated in the periphery of the glomerulus.
  • They lie within the mesangial core of the glomerular lobules and may be surrounded by patent peripheral capillary loops or loops that are markedly dilated.
  • The nodules often show features of mesangiolysis, defined by disruption of anchoring interactions between the capillaries and the mesangial stalks. The loss of these support structures may lead to the formation of capillary microaneurysms.
     
* Audio Explanation:
 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 1111.

choices.text: Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle

questions.text: What part of the body does the loop diuretic furosemide act on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle
 
  • Furosemide acts on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle and inhibits Na+K+Cl- symporters thus increasing the Renal blood flow.
  • The major site of action is the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle (TAL), therefore, called loop diuretics.
  • Furosemide inhibits Na+- K+-2Cl¯ cotransport. A minor component of action on PT has also been demonstrated. It is secreted in PT by organic anion transport and reaches TAL where it acts from luminal side of the membrane.
  • The corticomedullary osmotic gradient is abolished and positive as well as negative free water clearance is blocked. K+ excretion is increased mainly due to high Na+ load reaching DT.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 606.

questions.text: What does this crystal from a urine analysis stand for?
questions.solution:
Calcium oxalate crystals have a distinctive 'X' mark and are square in shape. They are typically described as “Envelope shaped” stones.
  • Struvite stones resemble the lid of a coffin.
  • Uric acid crystals can form rosettes and are frequently needle-shaped.
  • Hexagonal crystals make up cystine.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2370.

questions.text: A child with nephrotic syndrome develops acute kidney injury (AKI) following an episode of diarrhoea. The serum creatinine is 4.5 mg/dL. Which of the following is least likely to explain the AKI in this setting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4 - Steroid-induced diabetes
 
  • AKI in Nephrotic Syndrome is multifactorial in origin. It is most often secondary to hypovolemia, nephrotoxic medications, and infections.
  • In the above case, diarrhoeal disease leading to water depletion/hypovolemia (option 2) is the likely cause of AKI. 
  • Excess Furosemide (option 1) leads to diuresis and is usually given to Nephrotic syndrome patients for edema control but since it leads to diuresis and water loss (hypovolemia) - it can also lead to the development of AKI. 
  • Renal vein thrombosis (option 3)- can occur in patients with nephrotic syndrome due to the loss of antithrombin III (ATIII) in the urine, which in turn leads to an increase in hyper-coagulability and can also be an important cause of AKI in a child with Nephrotic Syndrome. 
  • Steroid-induced diabetes is the least likely reason for the development of AKI in Nephrotic Syndrome since Diabetes leads to "Chronic" nephropathy, and very rarely would cause "Acute kidney injury". Development of Diabetes in a child with Nephrotic syndrome secondary to steroid intake too would take time and would NOT be an acute event

Reference - Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2769-2771,2742

questions.text: The graph that follows shows the maximum renal tubular transit for glucose excretion in a diabetic patient. In a patient with a blood sugar level of 200 mg/dL and a glomerular filtration rate of 90 mL/min, what will the urine glucose level be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  30 mg/min
 

We have to find the total amount of glucose excreated (urine glucose)

  • Excretion = Total filtered glucose – Total reabsorbed glucose

  • Total filtered glucose = GFR x plasma concentration

  • Total reabsorbed glucose = transport maximum

Urine glucose = (90 ml/min x 2mg/ml) – 150 mg/min

=180 mg/min – 150 mg/min

=30 mg/min


Reference:Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no 346

questions.text: A 43-year-old man who had been experiencing 4 days of frothy urine arrived with facial puffiness. There may have been an acute renal damage. Direct immunofluorescence and electron microscopy images from a kidney biopsy are presented below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Membranous glomerulopathy
 
  • Membranous glomerulopathy is the most likely diagnosis. The images show immune complex deposits along the glomerular basement membrane, which is characteristic of membranous glomerulopathy.
  • Membranous glomerulopathy is an autoimmune kidney disease where the immune system mistakenly attacks and damages the glomerular basement membrane.
  • This leads to thickening of the membrane and impaired kidney function.
  • The presence of immune complex deposits can be confirmed through immunofluorescence staining.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: Which part of the nephron is affected by Vasopressin antagonist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Medullary collecting duct
 
  • Vasopressin antagonists act on Medullary collecting duct of nephron.
  • By inhibiting vasopressin receptors, they decrease binding of vasopressin to its target site thereby decreasing adenylyl cyclase activity and reduced intracellular cAMP. Decreased cAMP prevents the fusion of aquaporin 2 containing vesicles with plasma membrane, leading to increased urinary water excretion and decrease in urine osmolality.
  • Examples are- Conivaptan (acts on V1 and V2 receptors and given intravenously) and tolvaptan (V2 selective given orally)

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 644.

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: A CKD patient complains of vomiting. His ABG reports are as follows: pH = 7.40, pCO2 = 40, HCO3 = 23, Na = 145, chloride = 100. The findings point to:
questions.solution:
High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

The clinical history is crucial in this case even though the ABG appears to be entirely normal.
  • Patients with CKD typically exhibit significant ion gap metabolic acidosis. In light of it, the patient has started to vomit (which is the state of alkalosis). The ABG in this condition has returned to normal due to both opposing illnesses.
  • The patient therefore has severe anion gap metabolic acidosis together with metabolic alkalosis.

The likely diagnosis is high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) alongside metabolic alkalosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:'
  • Step 1:The pH of 7.4 is within the normal range.  
  • Step 2: The plasma bicarbonate level is 23 mEq/L, which is also normal. At this point, we can exclude options A and C, as this clinical situation does not indicate a straightforward acid-base disorder.  
  • Step 3: Calculating the anion gap:  

Anion gap = [Na+] - ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])  
= 145 - (100 + 23)  
= 22 mEq/L  

A high anion gap confirms the presence of an acid-base disorder, ruling out option A. A high anion gap suggests metabolic acidosis. However, the normal bicarbonate levels indicate that metabolic alkalosis is also present in this patient.

This can be further validated by calculating the delta gap:  
 
  • Delta gap = (AAG - HCO3-)  
  • In this case, Delta gap = (22 - 10) - (24 - 23) = 11 mEq/L.  
  • A delta gap of +6 suggests that metabolic alkalosis exists alongside HAGMA.
  • If the delta gap is significantly positive (> +6), it indicates metabolic alkalosis due to a greater rise in the anion gap compared to the fall in bicarbonate. Conversely, if the delta gap is significantly negative (<6), hyperchloremic acidosis is typically present, as the rise in the anion gap is less than the fall in bicarbonate.

Alternatively, we can use the delta ratio:  
  • Delta ratio = Increase in Anion Gap / Decrease in HCO3-.  
  • This ratio is useful when assessing high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) to determine if it is a 'pure' HAGMA or if there is coexisting normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) or metabolic alkalosis.  

Delta ratio values:  

1-2 indicates HAGMA,  
1 indicates NAGMA + HAGMA,  
2 indicates HAGMA + metabolic alkalosis.  

In this case, the delta ratio is 12/1 = 12. Thus, the acid-base disorder in this scenario is HAGMA with metabolic alkalosis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presents with a painless lump on the right side of the abdomen detected incidentally on bathing by parents. Ultrasound revealed it to be a solid mass. On examination, his right arm and leg were found to be longer. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• The right arm and leg were found to be longer in the child pointing towards hemihypertrophy. 
  • Hemihypertrophy is a known syndromic association (seen in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is associated with an increased risk of having Wilms Tumor. 
  • Wilms tumor is also known as Nephroblastoma - hence the correct answer is option (2).
  • Wilms tumor is the most common renal malignancy in children, usually presenting between ages 2 to 5 years. It often manifests as a painless abdominal mass and may be discovered incidentally or during a routine examination - similar to the given clinical scenario in the question. 


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2681-2684

questions.text: Assuming that no proteins were filtered, calculate net filtration with the following data: PGC = 42 mm Hg (Hydrostatic pressure of the glomerular capillaries) PiGC= 16 mm Hg (Oncotic pressure of the plasma in glomerular capillaries) PBC = 12 mm Hg (Hydrostatic pressure In Bowman's space) Assume that no proteins were filtered:
questions.solution:
The net filtration pressure is 14mm of Hg.
There are four pressures to consider: two hydrostatic pressures and two oncotic pressure. These are the Starling forces.
Hence, Net Filtration Pressure(NFP)=PGC-(piGC+ PBS)=42-(12+16)=14mmHg.

PGC-Hydrostatic pressure of the glomerulus.
PBS-Hydrostatic pressure In Bowman's space
piGC-Oncotic pressure of the plasma.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 666,667

questions.text:
The image below shows the immunofluorescence staining pattern from a kidney sample taken from a 35-year-old patient who was experiencing proteinuria.
What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Lupus nephritis

The most probable diagnosis is of Lupus nephritis.
 
  • Strong IgA, IgM, and C3 staining may be seen in the picture, although IgG positive staining is lesser.
  • All kinds of glomerulonephritis present in SLE, as well as positive IgA, IgM, C3, and IgG, are frequently observed (lupus nephritis). IgG and C3 positivity is present in PSGN and Goodpasture syndrome; IgM and C3 positivity is seen in FSGS.
  • It is called full house effect. 
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: In renal failure, which of the following thiazide diuretics is used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Metolazone
 
  • All Na+-Cl symport inhibitors are referred to by this term, which was given to them because the original inhibitors of this symport were benzothiadiazide derivatives.
  • Used to treat edema brought on by cardiac diseases (CHF), liver disease (hepatic cirrhosis), and kidney disease (nephrotic syndrome, chronic renal failure, and acute glomerulonephritis). 
  • When the GFR is less than 30–40 mL/min, metolazone and indapamide are beneficial.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 630.

questions.text: What is the best KDIGO criteria marker for distinguishing renal from pre-renal acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Urine Na  x serum creatinine /Serum Na x  Urine creatinine is the best marker in KDIGO criteria to differentiate renal from pre-renal acute kidney injury. This is the formula for fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa).

In AKI, there is abrupt loss of kidney function, resulting in retention of urea and other nitrogenous waste products and dysregulation of extracellular volume and electrolytes.

The term AKI has largely replaced acute renal failure (ARF).


Difference between Pre-renal and Intrinsic Renal AKI:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2303, 2305.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate in the neonatal ICU develops seizures. Which of the following would be the next best investigation for the child?
questions.solution:
• Cranial ultrasonography is particularly practical in case of premature neonates in order to assess various features including ventricular size, presence of fluid-filled lesions, and indications of either haemorrhagic or ischaemic damage, in addition to charting how conditions may evolve.
  • Transcranial USG can be done in neonates due to presence of fontanelles. 
  • It is advantageous in this respect as it can be conducted at the bedside, less time consuming and no hazard of radiation exposure. 



Reference: AIIMS NICU Protocols 2 nd Edition page no 78

choices.text: Inhibition of sodium reabsorption in medullary collecting duct

questions.text: Which of these is not an action of atrial natriuretic peptide?
questions.solution:
ANP results in mesangial relaxation causing sodium excretion. Hence, option (2) is an incorrect option. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 668,694,695

choices.text: Glomerular basement membrane is stained with PAS
Glomerular basement membrane acts as filtration barrier
Glomerular basement membrane is involved in charge dependent filtration

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about the glomerular basement membrane?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Type III collagen is present

Type IV collagen (not the type III collagen) is the main component of the basement membrane, together with laminin.

The underlying mesenchymal cells and the overlying epithelium both contribute to the synthesis of the basement membrane, resulting in a lamellar "chicken wire" mesh (although labeled as a membrane, it is quite porous).

Therefore, the two main components are laminin and amorphous non fibrillar type IV collagen.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 900.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with hepatic cirrhosis is admitted after presenting with severe ascites. Which of the following diuretics is best for mobilizing the edema fluid
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Eplerenone
 
  • In hepatic cirrhosis aldosterone is raised, therefore the doc is aldosterone antagonists like Spironolactone and Eplerenone. 
  • However, in severe cases furosemide is used in combination with aldosterone antagonists.
  • But according to the question the best diuretic best for mobilizing edema fluid among the given options remain, Eplerenone.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 635.

questions.text: Which is the most sensitive indicator of renal tubular function?
questions.solution:
Specific gravity of urine is the most sensitive marker of renal tubular function.

The ability of the kidneys to concentrate, specifically renal tubular function, is measured by urinary specific gravity. Better indices of general renal health and GFR are the serum creatinine levels and clearance.

The best indicator of glomerular function is the GFR.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2305, 2357.

questions.text: 7-year-old child with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome has developed corticosteroid toxicity and posterior subcapsular cataracts and uncontrolled hypertension. Which of the following is the best alternative for the treatment of the patient?
questions.solution:
• In patients with Frequent Relapsing Nephrotic Syndrome - Levamisole is the preferred steroid-sparing agent while MMF is the preferred agent in Steroid dependent Nephrotic syndrome
  • However, a 12-week course of Cyclophosphamide is preferred over Levamisole/MMF in patients with evidence of severe steroid toxicity (like the example given in question - cataracts and uncontrolled hypertension) or having compliance issues. Hence in the above question, option(2) is a better answer as compared to option (3).

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 476-477

questions.text: What does U stand for in the urea clearance formula, C = U V/P?
questions.solution:
Urinary concentration in mg/ml i.e., option ‘B’
Here
C = The substance's clearance
U = Urinary substance concentration in mg/ml
P = The substance's plasma concentration in mg/ml
V in formula stands for urine flow rate in ml/min

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 665

questions.text: Identify the most consistent feature of rapidly progressing glomerulonephritis (RPGN).
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Crescent formation

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is characterized by a rapid decline in the GFR (GFR) of at least 50% over a short period. The main histopathologic finding is an extensive glomerular crescent formation.

* [Extra Edge]: Cresent Glomerulopathy
  • Depending on the underlying cause, the glomeruli often show focal and segmental necrosis, and variably show diffuse or focal endothelial proliferation, and mesangial proliferation.
  • Segmental glomerular necrosis and distinctive crescents adjacent to glomerular segments uninvolved by inflammatory or proliferative changes is the feature most typical of pauci-immune RPGN.
  • Crescents are formed by proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells and by migration of monocytes and macrophages into the urinary space.
  • Neutrophils and lymphocytes may be present. The crescents may obliterate the urinary space and compress the glomerular tuft. Fibrin strands are frequently prominent between the cellular layers in the crescents


Fig: Cresent Glomerulonephritis

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 910.

questions.text: In which of the following situations is a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis not seen?
questions.solution:
Salicylate poisoning leads to high anion-gap metabolic acidosis.
 
  • Proximal renal tubular acidosis (RIA), pancreatitis and diarrhea lead to normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.
 
  • Salicylates have a direct effect on the respiratory center in the brain leading to hyperventilation.
 
  • The body responds to hyperventilation by having the kidneys produce more bicarbonate and excrete more potassium which leads to an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 361, 364.

choices.text: Reassure the parents and follow up after 6 months

questions.text: A 4 year old boy complains of wetting the bed. The youngster is calm during the day, and the issue only arises at night. The child's growth and development were typical. The urine specific gravity was normal. What should you do next?
questions.solution:
• Bed-wetting is considered normal till 5 years of age.
  • In a child with only night time bed wetting, when Urinalysis (to rule out infections) and Urine Osmolality (to rule out diabetes) are normal, only regular follow-up is required.
  • An anatomic abnormality requiring USG-KUB is unlikely. The decision on whether to start treatment should be guided by the degree of concern and motivation on the part of the child rather than the parents.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 499,500

questions.text: In the urea clearance formula, C = U V/P, U stands for:
questions.solution:
U denotes Urinary concentration of urea in mg/ml.

C= UV/P

In the given formula:

C = Clearance of the substance

U = Urinary concentration of the substance in mg/ml

P = Plasma concentration of the substance in mg/ml 

V = Volume of urine

Renal plasma clearance is the volume of plasma from which a substance is completely removed by the kidney in a given amount of time (usually minutes).

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 665

questions.text: A patient who underwent a kidney transplant is suffering with decreased urine production. The microscopic image from a urinalysis is displayed below. Identify the structure that has an arrow on it:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hyaline casts

The structure marked in the above diagram is a Hyaline cast.

It appears to be a Waxy cast, but Hyaline cast is the best response because it develops from a hyaline cast.

* [Extra Edge]: Hyaline Casts

  • Normal: Up to 5 casts/low-power field
  • Associations: Normal finding in concentrated urine, fever, exercise, diuretics, pyelonephritis, chronic renal disease
Online Reference:
Queremel Milani DA, Jialal I. Urinalysis. [Updated 2023 May 1]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557685/

questions.text: The acid base status of a patient reveals a pH=7.45, pO2=105mm and pCO2=30 mmHg, HCO3-: 20. The patient has partially compensated. Identify the disorder?
questions.solution:
Respiratory alkalosis is a condition in which the blood pH increases due to increased elimination of carbon dioxide from the body. It is caused by hyperventilation. When there is an increase in the amount of carbon dioxide eliminated, the pH of the blood will rise to 7.45 (a slight alkaline reading) and the PCO2 level will decrease to 30mmHg. The overall change is slightly alkaline, and the respiratory change is also alkaline. Therefore, the diagnosis is respiratory alkalosis.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl with no symptoms is discovered to have persistent hypertension. There is no noteworthy past, and a urine test results in normal results. Which among the following is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Option 2 is the correct option.
  • Renal parenchymal disease, is the most likely cause of persistent hypertension in a 7-year-old girl with no symptoms and normal urine test results.
  • Renal parenchymal disease refers to damage to the functional tissue of the kidneys, which can lead to hypertension. This type of kidney disease can be caused by a number of factors, including congenital abnormalities, infections, and autoimmune disorders.
  • Essential hypertension (option 1) is rare in children(unlike adults) and is usually diagnosed only after other causes of hypertension have been ruled out.
  • Polycystic kidney disease (option 3) is a genetic disorder that causes the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys, leading to kidney failure. However, this condition is rare in young children.
  • Coarctation of the aorta (option 4) is a narrowing of the aorta, which can cause high blood pressure in the arms and head and low blood pressure in the legs. However, this condition typically presents with other symptoms such as leg cramps, cold feet, and weak or absent pulses, which are not mentioned in the question stem.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2492

questions.text: All of the aforementioned factors increase GFR, except which one:
questions.solution:
In some disorders related to a blockage of the urinary tract, Bowman's capsule pressure may have an extremely increased level, leading to a decrease in glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This may be caused by the collection of substances like calcium oxide or uric acid, which form stones that block the flow of urine in the ureter, elevating the pressure inside Bowman's capsule, thereby reducing GFR and could eventually create hydronephrosis (swelling and enlargement of the kidney's pelvis and calyces). Unless the obstruction is freed, this could result in damage to, or even destruction of, the kidney.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 667

questions.text: A kidney specimen stained with FITC for IgG is shown below. What does this hint at?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Goodpasture’s syndrome

The immunofluorescence above is showing Linear IgG deposits along the glomerular basement membrane seen in  Goodpasture’s syndrome.

  • In Membranous glomerulonephritis , Granular IgG (Against GBM) deposits are seen.
  • In Buerger’s disease there is IgA deposition.
  • SLE may have a picture similar to Membranous Glomerulonephritis i.e. Granular IgG immune complexes deposits, but this is not characteristic.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: A little youngster has acute pyelonephritis. What is the most precise urinary finding?
questions.solution:
• WBC casts are specific urinary findings in acute pyelonephritis, a urinary tract infection that can affect the kidneys.
  • This type of cast is a collection of white blood cells (WBCs) that form within the renal tubules of the affected kidney. These casts indicate that the infection is not just affecting the bladder, but has spread to the kidneys and is causing inflammation.
  • They can be seen under a microscope and are often seen in cases of severe infection.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2304.

questions.text: A child is experiencing sporadic episodes of left flank pain. Ultrasonography shows a normal ureter and a dilated renal pelvis with cortical thinning. A 19% difference in kidney function was found. Among the following, which type of management is best:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Pyeloplasty 

The presentation of normal ureter and a dilated renal pelvis is suggestive of PUJ obstruction. Anderson Hynes pyeloplasty is the treatment of choice for it.

Nephrectomy is done if the function of the obstructed kidney is less than 10%.






 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 501

questions.text: Select the correct diluting segment of kidney.
questions.solution:
The Loop of Henle allows for water to be removed from the filtrate in the nephron by passing it through a hypertonic interstitium. The descending limb is permeable to water through aquaporin-I, while Na, K and Cl are cotransported out in the thick segment of the ascending limb, thus leading to fluid in the descending limb becoming hypertonic and ascending limb hypotonic. This results in approximately 20% of filtered water entering the distal tubule, with a TF/P of inulin of 5. The ascending limb vidly reabsorbs most of the ions, including sodium, potassium, and chloride, but is virtually impermeable to water and urea. For this reason, it is referred to as the diluting segment because it also dilutes the tubular fluid.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 674

questions.text: A kidney specimen that was removed is displayed below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Flea-bitten kidney of malignant hypertension
 
  • The image shows a kidney with multiple small hemorrhages, resembling a "flea-bitten" appearance.
  • This finding is characteristic of malignant hypertension, where severe hypertension causes damage to the renal blood vessels leading to hemorrhages.
* Other options:
 
  • Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis typically presents with glomerular changes such as glomerular hypercellularity and crescent formation, which are not observed in this image.
  • Chronic glomerulonephritis is characterized by chronic inflammation and fibrosis in the glomeruli, which is not seen in this image.
  • Amyloidosis would show amyloid deposits within the kidney, which are not evident in this image.

* [Extra Edge]: Nephritic syndromes


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2091.

questions.text: A patient has a three-day history of vomiting. Upon investigation, dehydration was discovered. After additional testing, it was discovered that the patient had elevated creatinine, a pH of 7.22, a pCO2 of 24 mm Hg, an HCO3 of 9 mEq, a Na+ of 138 mEq/L, and a K+ of 3.4 mEq/L. Decide which acid-base imbalance this patient has:
questions.solution:
On examining the values it appears to be a case of Metabolic acidosis
  • pH decreased (Normal= 7.35-7.45) = Acidosis
  • Normal=40–45 mm Hg. Here, pCO2 dropped. A lower pCO2 will attempt to raise pH. The mechanism must thus be a secondary compensatory one.
 
  • According to compensation formula for Metabolic alkalosis, Paco2 = [HCO3–] + 15.
  • Here in this question, PaCO2 value should be 9+15 = 24 (22-26) +- 2. It signifies there is full respiratory compensation.
  • Therefore, it is a case of Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.
 

As a result, the main factor contributing to the Acid-Base imbalance must be a drop in serum bicarbonate levels, or metabolic acidosis.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same
 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: A young girl enters the room dribbling urine continuously. She does, however, urinate normally. According to her parents, she had never been completely dry since birth. What diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Case of ectopic ureter as the patient has continuous dribbling of urine.
  • IVU can be used for investigation
  • Re-implantation of the ectopic ureter is the definitive treatment.
 

Reference:Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 2796, 2797, 2805-2807

choices.text: Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

questions.text: Except for the following components, all are responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the kidney:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb

The countercurrent flow of tubular fluid in the loop of Henle and the blood in the vasa recta creates a countercurrent exchange system. This system allows for the reabsorption of water and solutes from the tubular fluid while maintaining the concentration gradient in the renal medulla.
  • Thin Descending Limb: The thin descending limb is highly permeable to water but not to solutes
  • Thin Ascending Limb: At the bottom of the loop of Henle, the thin descending limb transitions into the thin ascending limb. The thin ascending limb is also permeable to water but does not actively transport solutes
  • Thick Ascending Limb: As the thin ascending limb continues to ascend towards the renal cortex, it transitions into the thick ascending limb. The thick ascending limb is impermeable to water but actively transports solutes such as sodium, chloride, and potassium out of the tubule into the interstitial fluid



 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 675,676,677

questions.text: Where are c-anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Wegener's Granulomatosis 
 
  • Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) are auto antibodies, mainly of the IgG type, which are targeted against antigens in the cytoplasm of neutrophil granulocytes and monocytes and detected through a blood test.
  • They are associated with systemic vasculitis, known as ANCA-associated vasculitis and the antigen specifically targeted is proteinase.
  • A c-ANCA positive test result can indicate Wegener's granulomatosis.
ANCA Memorizing trick:- 
PCM- p-ANCA- Churg's Strauss, Microscopic polyangitis 
c-ANCA- Wegener's 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 514.

questions.text: Determine the base deficit in a patient weighing 75 kg with a pH of 6.96, a pCO2 of 30, and an HCO3-- level of 6 mEq/L:
questions.solution:
The base deficit in the patient turns out to be around 500 mEq.

It can be calculated using:

Total bicarbonate deficit= 0.3 x weight (kg) x base deficit (Standard Base deficit)

Base deficit= 0.4 x Weight (in Kg) x [24- (Sr. bicarbonate)]

Here, BE= 0.4 x 75 x [24-6] = 540 m.eq which is approximately near 500 m.eq



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 360.

questions.text: A patient comes in with headache and nausea. Upon evaluation, it was discovered that his blood pressure was 180/110 and that his K+ level was 2mEq/l. His ABG results indicated that he had metabolic alkalosis. Which syndrome might be the cause of this ailment?
questions.solution:
• The give history shows development of metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia and hypertension which are suggestive of Liddle Syndrome (option 2).
  • It is due to the overactivity of epithelial Na+ Channel in the collecting tubule (due to gain of function mutations).
  • It is Autosomal Dominant in nature .
  • Due to gain of function mutations in ENa+C(sodium channel) - There is increased/excessive absorption of Na+ and H2O into circulation causing hypertension. To maintain the electro-neutrality in the tubule lumen due to excessive sodium absorption - there is excretion of K+ and and H+ into tubule(which then come in urine) resulting in hypokalaemia & metabolic alkalosis.

Other options
  • Gitelman and Bartter syndrome both have hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis but do not have high Blood pressure. Instead they have low blood pressure and present with failure to thrive. 
  • Gordon syndrome is pseudohypoaldosteronism- there is excessive activation of Na/Cl symporter in DCT leading to Excessive sodium absorption along with hypertension. This leads to less sodium being available for exchange with K+/H+ in collecting ducts leading to their retention and hence- hyperkalemia/metabolic acidosis. 
 



Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2970

questions.text: Proteoglycan present in Glomerular basement membrane is:
questions.solution:
The glomerular capillary membrane makes the filtration barrier that allows for the passage of certain substances from the blood into the glomerular filtrate. This membrane consists of three major layers: capillary endothelium, capillary basement membrane, and layer of epithelial cells surrounding the outer surface of the capillary basement membrane (podocytes). The capillary endothelium layer is freely permeable to everything in the blood except for red blood cells and platelets, up to a size of 4 nm in diameter. The capillary basement membrane contains proteins, such as laminin, type VI collagen, nidogen, and heparan sulfate proteoglycan (HSPG). These proteins form a meshwork which effectively prevents filtration of plasma proteins. The layer of podocytes surround the capillary basement membrane and have long foot-like processes with gaps in-between called slit pores, which are 25 nm wide. It is through these slit pores that the glomerular filtrate moves. The total area of glomerular capillary endothelium across which filtration occurs in humans is approximately 0.8m. This membrane is selective in how it permits materials through, allowing related to their size, charge, and other properties.



Reference :Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry 31st edition Page no 1474

questions.text: Edema, oliguria, and foamy urine are symptoms that a 10-year-old child exhibits. He has never before been subject to comparable complaints. Examining his urine revealed that it contained 3+ proteinuria, no RBCs or WBCs, and no casts. He had a blood albumin level of 2.5 g/L and a creatinine level of 0.5 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Minimal change disease
 
  • The symptoms and laboratory findings described in the question are characteristic of minimal change disease (MCD), which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.
  • MCD is characterized by diffuse effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy, which leads to increased permeability of the glomerular filtration barrier and proteinuria.

Fig: Minimal Change Disorder

* Other options:
  • IgA nephropathy is characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the glomeruli, typically presenting with hematuria.
  • Acute interstitial nephritis is an inflammatory condition involving the renal interstitium and is usually associated with drug hypersensitivity or infections.
  • Membranous nephropathy is characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to immune complex deposition.
* [Extra Edge]: Nephritic syndromes



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 914.

questions.text: A patient with lung cancer had a 16.4 mmol/L serum calcium level when they were first seen. What will be the initial management action be?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. IV fluids and furosemide

I.V. fluids and diuretics are the first-line treatments for managing hypercalcemia in an emergency.

Even though IV bisphosphonates are the preferred medication for treating malignant hypercalcemia, their activity doesn't begin for at least 3–4 days, thus they are useless in an urgent situation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3173, 3183.

questions.text: In chronic kidney disease, what is the acid-base abnormality?
questions.solution:
CKD causes Metabolic acidosis (option 2) by the following mechanisms - 

1. Decreased Excretion of Hydrogen Ions:
The kidneys are responsible for excreting excess H⁺ ions into the urine. In CKD, there is a reduction in the number of functioning nephrons, which decreases the kidney's capacity to excrete these ions. As a result, H⁺ accumulates in the bloodstream, leading to acidosis.

2. Impaired Bicarbonate Reabsorption:
Normally, the kidneys reabsorb bicarbonate from the urine. In CKD, the reabsorption capacity is impaired, leading to a decrease in serum bicarbonate levels. This results in a reduced buffering capacity for H⁺ ions in the blood.

3. Loss of Ammonium Excretion:
The kidneys also produce ammonium (NH₄⁺) as a means of excreting H⁺ ions. In CKD, the ability to synthesize and excrete ammonia is diminished, leading to less H⁺ excretion and further acid retention.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 83

questions.text: The Proteoglycan is located in the glomerular basement membrane. Select from the options the most appropriate one for the statement mentioned.
Which of the following is not included in markers of acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Micro RNA-122

  • MicroRNA-122 is not a marker of acute kidney injury.
  • Recent studies have shown that aberrant regulation of miR-122 is a key factor contributing to the development of HCC.

questions.text: 8 months after receiving a kidney transplant, an older man with nephropathy presents. Which of the following could be the cause of a viral infection?
questions.solution:
• BK polyoma virus is transmitted through respiratory fluids or urine, since infected individuals periodically excrete virus in the urine. It then disseminates to the kidneys and urinary tract where it persists for the life of the individual.
  • Typically, this is in the setting of kidney transplantation or multi-organ transplantation.
  • BK virus is a latent polyomavirus that lies dormant in the kidney and urothelial tract and can be activated in the setting of immunosuppression. Reactivation of BK, if left untreated, will lead to progressive fibrosis and loss of the graft within 1 year in most cases.
 
  • Presentation in these immunocompromised individuals is much more severe.
  • Clinical manifestations include renal dysfunction (seen by a progressive rise in serum creatinine), and an abnormal urinalysis revealing renal tubular cells and inflammatory cells (Decoy cells).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2330.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old child presents with a ballotable abdominal mass not crossing midline and h/o hematuria. Which among the following investigations should be carried out?
i. CT Abdomen
ii. CT Chest
iii. FNAC
iv. VMA assessment
questions.solution:
• Wilms tumor is the most likely diagnosis based on the child's examination and history(Ballotable mass + hematuria). Wilms tumor is the most common primary malignant renal tumor. 
  • Abdominal imaging studies such as CT of the abdomen are used to pinpoint the mass' intrarenal origin and distinguish it from abdominal masses such as neuroblastomas and adrenal masses. 
  • CT Chest is done to evaluate for metastatic lesions. (Lungs are the most common site of metastasis)
  • While typically imaging suffices for making a diagnosis - FNAC can be considered if the diagnosis is unclear. However, a biopsy is avoided as it upstages the disease. 
  • Urinary VMA is used for diagnosis of suspected Neuroblastoma - will not be sent in the case of suspected Wilms tumor as the mass is ballotable/not crossing the midline and CT Abdomen will further confirm the renal origin of the mass. (VMA is not sent in case of every abdominal mass - only if Neuroblastoma is suspected on imaging - it is sent)


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 609,610

questions.text: What results in the Impaired function of aquaporin?
questions.solution:
Diabetes insipidus is a disorder that results from impaired function of aquaporins, which are proteins that form channels in cell membranes and allow water to move in and out of cells. In diabetes insipidus, aquaporins are either missing or are malfunctioning, thus preventing the regulation of the amount of water that can enter cells. As a consequence, too much water enters cells which results in excessive urination and thirst. This is because the kidneys’ ability to reabsorb water is impaired, resulting in reduced concentration of solutes in the body and consequently, an excessive amount of water need to be urinated out of the body in order to keep the solute concentration balanced. Therefore, impaired function of aquaporins can lead to the development of diabetes insipidus due to their essential role in the regulation of water movement in and out of cells.


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 675

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic patient initially experiences brief vision occlusion for two to three days before experiencing an abrupt loss of vision. Which of the following tests would be most effective in assessing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Serum creatinine levels

Serum creatinine levels would be the best choice as DM can lead to both retinopathy and nephropathy.

Elevated ACE Levels Indicate Diabetic Nephropathy Progression or Companied Retina Impaired.

It has been widely accepted that ACR is a frequently used laboratory index to diagnose DN and distinguish early-stage (30 mg/g < ACR < 300mg/g) and advanced-stage (ACR > 300 mg/g) DN. Based on ACR levels, DN patients were divided into four subgroups of early-stage DN, early-stage DN combined with DR, advanced-stage DN, and advanced-stage DN patients DR.
New studies shows correlation with s homocysteine and DR.
Online Reference:
Huang K, Liang Y, Wang K, Ma Y, Wu J, Luo H, Yi B. Elevated ACE Levels Indicate Diabetic Nephropathy Progression or Companied Retina Impaired. Front Clin Diabetes Healthc. 2022 May 12;3:831128. doi: 10.3389/fcdhc.2022.831128. PMID: 36992775; PMCID: PMC10012155.

questions.text: In contrast-induced nephropathy, which of the following is a sign of renal impairment?
questions.solution:
Contrast nephropathy leads to a rise in serum creatinine within 24-48 hours, peak within 3-5 days, and resolution within 5-7 days.

Iodinated contrast agents, which are commonly used in cardiovascular and CT imaging, are a leading cause of AKI (Acute Kidney Injury). 

The risk of AKI, also known as "contrast nephropathy," is negligible in people with normal renal function, but it rises dramatically in people with chronic kidney disease, particularly diabetic nephropathy.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2300.

questions.text: The following is not part of the classical triad of the hemolytic uremic syndrome:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Neurological symptoms 

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome is a type of Thrombotic Microangiopathy commonly affecting children.
While neurological symptoms can occur in some cases of HUS, they are not a defining feature of the syndrome itself.
  • The most common cause is Shiga toxin producing E coli infection ( O157: H7)
  •  TRIAD of
  1. Thrombocytopenia
  2. Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia
  3. Acute kidney injury
  •  CLINICAL FEATURES include the above Triad & bloody diarrhea
  • INVESTIGATION :- Normal PT & APTT – helps to differentiate from DIC
  • TREATMENT:- Supportive care

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 487,488

questions.text: Renal cell cancer with a chromophobe form is connected to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Monosomy of 1 and Y (-1, -Y)
 
  • Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is associated with specific chromosomal losses, particularly monosomy of chromosomes 1 and Y (-1, -Y). Monosomy refers to the loss of one copy of a particular chromosome in a cell.
  • These genetic abnormalities are frequently detected in chromophobe renal cell carcinoma and can be helpful in its diagnosis.
  • Other renal cell carcinoma subtypes, such as clear cell carcinoma and papillary carcinoma, have distinct chromosomal alterations.
  • Chromophobe renal carcinoma is made up of pale eosinophilic cells, often with a perinuclear halo, arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels.
Other options: -
VHL - Clear cell cancer 
Trisomy 7/17- Papillary cell cancer 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 950.

questions.text: A patient's laboratory tests revealed pH = 7.3, HCO3- = 15 meq/l and pCO2 = 35 mm Hg. What is the probable primary acid base imbalance?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Metabolic acidosis

Normal range: PH= 7.35-7.45 , pCO2= 40-44mmHg , HCO3=22-28mmol/ml.

Here it is a state of acidosis, with low bicarbonate and low pCO2 which means something in the metabolism was causing acidosis which is now being compensated by CO2 washout by the body via lungs. So, its Metabolic acidosis.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

choices.text: Most common cause of Nephrotic Syndrome in children

questions.text: Which of the following statements about minimal change disease is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Remission is urine protein: creatinine ration>2
 
  • It is the most common cause of Nephrotic syndrome in children
  • Also known as Lipoid Nephrosis
  • CAUSES:- ( 4I)
-Idiopathic
-Infection
-Immunisation
-Immune stimulus
  • It has excellent response to steroids ( Prednisolone 60 mg/day )
  • Good prognosis
  • LIGHT MICROSCOPY- Normal glomerulus
  • IMMUNOFLUORESCENCE – Absent
  • ELECTRON MICROSCOPY -Effacement of podocytes
  • REMISSION –
-Complete remission :- Reduction in proteinuria to <300 mg/day, stable serum creatinine, and serum albumin >3.5 g/dL.
-Partial remission –  Reduction in proteinuria of >50 percent, with absolute values between 300 mg and 3.5 g/day.
