questions.text: Which of the following exhibits increased PCT concentration?
questions.solution:
In the first part of PCT,

Na is co-transported along with

i. Phosphate
ii. Glucose
iii. Amino acids

This causes an increase in Cl concentration in lumen in proximal PCT. 
   
In distal part of PCT, Cl reabsorption is by passive diffusion.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 669,670,671

questions.text: Electron microscopy is used to diagnose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Alport's syndrome
 
  • Electron microscopy is used to diagnose Alport's syndrome, a hereditary disorder affecting the glomerular basement membrane.
  • Alport's syndrome is characterized by the presence of thinning, splitting, and lamellation of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) when examined under an electron microscope.
  • These ultrastructural changes in the GBM result from mutations in genes encoding type IV collagen, a major component of the GBM.
  • The characteristic electron microscopy findings help differentiate Alport's syndrome from other forms of glomerulonephritis.
* [Extra Edge]: Electron microscopy of Alport syndrome

Early Alport or carriers of Alport show diffuse thinning of GBMs. In established Alport, there are irregular thin and thickened areas with splintered and irregular multi-laminated appearance of the lamina densa, with short stubs of fibrils at right angles to the GBM, irregular lucent areas interspersed with thickened areas of the lamina densa, resulting in a so-called basket-weave pattern. There are no immune complexes, and foot processes, particularly in sclerosed glomeruli, may show effacement.


Fig: lamellated and basket-weave appearance (electron microscopy)

* Vasculitis Types:



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 922.

questions.text: Which of the following kidney stones is caused by laxative abuse?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Ammonium urate
 
  • Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse. 
  • Loss of potassium and sodium in laxative abuse causes intracellular acidosis, which increases the production of ammonia in urine. Dehydration and sodium loss further exacerbate hypokalemia and reduces the urinary volume, resulting in hyperuricemia. Highly concentrated uric acid and ammonia promote the formation of ammonium urate stones. 
  • These are also associated with inflammatory bowel disease, chronic diarrhea, ileostomy, recurrent urinary tract infection and recurrent uric acid stone formation. 



Reference: Campbell Walsh Wein Urology, 12th edition, Page no 2032.

questions.text: When does the kidney reach adult GFR?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  1-2 year

The GFR of a newborn gradually increases after birth and attains the adult vale of GFR at the age of 1-2 years.
GFR again progressively starts decreasing after the age of 40 yrs.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 2715

questions.text: Which part is responsible for the formation of the macula densa?
questions.solution:
Macula densa is a part of Distal tubule.

Macula densa cells are strategically positioned in the distal tubule (part of juxtaglomerular apparatus) with their apical membrane exposed to the tubular fluid, whereas their basilar aspects are in contact with cells of the mesangium and the afferent arteriole. They sense the Na+ concentration and take part in Tubulo-glomerular feedback.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 662

questions.text: Which of these causes hypercoagulation in nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Loss of Antithrombin III
 
  • Nephrotic syndrome is associated with the loss of antithrombin III, a natural anticoagulant. Antithrombin III inhibits several coagulation factors, including thrombin (factor IIa) and factors IXa, Xa, XIa, and XIIa.
  • The urinary loss of antithrombin III in nephrotic syndrome contributes to a prothrombotic state, increasing the risk of hypercoagulability and thrombotic events.
  • Other changes in the coagulation system, such as decreased levels of protein C and protein S, can also contribute to the hypercoagulable state in nephrotic syndrome
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 911.

questions.text: What is the causes of hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Liddle syndrome

The other options are incorrect because:
  1. Bartter syndrome: Bartter syndrome is characterized by excessive renal sodium and chloride excretion, leading to volume depletion, potassium wasting, metabolic alkalosis, and secondary hyperaldosteronism. However, Bartter syndrome is not typically associated with hypertension.
  2. Gitelman syndrome: Gitelman syndrome also involves excessive renal excretion of sodium and chloride, resulting in volume depletion, potassium wasting, metabolic alkalosis, and secondary hyperaldosteronism. However, Gitelman syndrome is not commonly associated with hypertension.
  3. Renal tubular acidosis (RTA): While some forms of RTA can cause hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, they are not typically associated with hypertension. RTA involves impaired renal tubular acidification, leading to an inability to excrete acid and maintain normal acid-base balance.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 349, 350.

questions.text: A graph showing the filterability of dermatan through the kidney is shown, with 1 denoting complete filtration and 0 denoting no filtration. Choose A, B, or C appropriately.
questions.solution:
A = Polycationic
B = Neutral
C = Polyanionic

Since the Glomerular filtration membrane has a negative charge, it favors filtration of positively charged ions and inhibits the transport of anions. Therefore, A has the max filterability followed by B and C.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 667

choices.text: Defect in thick ascending limb of loop of henle

questions.text: Defect is present in Bartter syndrome in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Defect in thick ascending limb of loop of Henle
 
  • Bartter syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by defects in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle in the kidney.
  • The defect in Bartter syndrome leads to impaired reabsorption of sodium, chloride, and potassium, resulting in electrolyte imbalances and a salt-wasting phenotype.
  • This defect is primarily located in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, which plays a critical role in sodium reabsorption.
  • There are different types of Bartter syndrome, each associated with specific genetic mutations affecting various ion channels and transporters in the thick ascending limb.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2293.

questions.text: Plasma urea/ creatinine ratio of 20:1 may be seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Pre-renal failure
A plasma urea/creatinine ratio of 20:1 may be seen in pre-renal failure.

Pre-renal failure refers to a condition where there is reduced blood flow to the kidneys, leading to decreased filtration of waste products. This can be caused by factors such as dehydration, hypovolemia (low blood volume), or decreased cardiac output. In pre-renal failure, the kidneys try to conserve water and sodium, resulting in increased reabsorption of urea in the renal tubules and a higher urea/creatinine ratio.
 
  • Rhabdomyolysis (Option 1) is a condition characterized by the breakdown of muscle tissue, which can lead to an increase in creatinine levels, but the urea/creatinine ratio is typically not significantly elevated.
 
  • Ureteric calculi (Option 2) refers to kidney stones that have migrated into the ureter. While it can cause obstruction and kidney dysfunction, it does not typically result in a markedly elevated urea/creatinine ratio.
 
  • Chronic glomerulonephritis (Option 4) is a condition involving inflammation and damage to the glomeruli of the kidneys. It can lead to impaired renal function, but the urea/creatinine ratio may not be as high as in pre-renal failure. Please note that the plasma/urine creatinine ratio is useful in distinguishing between pre-renal and intrinsic renal causes of AKI. A ratio of less than 20:1 suggests pre-renal AKI, while a ratio greater than 20:1 is indicative of intrinsic renal disease.

​​​​​​​Difference between Pre-renal and Intrinsic Renal AKI:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2303.

choices.text: Urinary concentration of urea in mg/100 ml
Plasma concentration of urea in mg/ 100 ml

questions.text: U x X/P provides clearance. What does "U" stand for?
questions.solution:
The volume of plasma that is entirely cleared of a substance by the kidneys in a certain amount of time is known as the renal clearance of a substance.
• Cs- clearance rate of a substance (ml/min)
• Ps- plasma concentration of the substance (mg/ml)
• Us-urine concentration of that substance (mg/ml)
• V-urine flow rate (ml/min)
 \(\text{Clearance of }x~(C_x)=\frac{U_x.V}{P_x}\)



Reference:Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no 365

questions.text: Name the disease which is the pathognomonic of effacement of foot processes:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Minimal change disease

  • Minimal Change Disease (MCD) is a type of nephrotic syndrome, primarily seen in children aged 2 to 6 years, and is caused by disruptions in podocyte function.
  • It is typically suspected clinically, but diagnosed in an electron microscope, in which diffuse effacement of the foot processes of the podocytes is observed.
  • Light microscopy reveals an apparently normal glomerulus, while immunofluorescence shows no g or complement deposits.
  • MCD responds well to corticosteroids and is also known as Lipoid Nephrosis. In adults, it may be associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma.
* [Extra Edge]: effacement of foot processes
 
  • The principal lesion is in the visceral epithelial cells, which show a uniform and diffuse effacement of foot processes, these being reduced to a rim of cytoplasm with loss of recognizable intervening slit diaphragms.
  • This change, often incorrectly termed “fusion” of foot processes, actually represents simplification of the epithelial cell architecture with flattening, retraction, and swelling of foot processes.
  • Foot process effacement is also present in other proteinuric states (e.g., membranous glomerulopathy, diabetic nephropathy); it is only when effacement is associated with normal glomeruli by light microscopy that the diagnosis of minimal change disease can be made.
  • The visceral epithelial changes are completely reversible after corticosteroid therapy, concomitant with remission of the proteinuria.

Fig: Ultrastructural characteristics of minimal change disease include effacement of foot processes

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 915.

questions.text: Pre-renal azotemia is not characterized by:
questions.solution:
Urinary sodium concentration > 40 meq/l is seen in Intrinsic renal AKI.


Difference between Pre-renal and Intrinsic Renal AKI:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2303, 2306.

questions.text: Except for which of the following, luminal concentrations in the kidney PCT will decrease?
questions.solution:
PCT is lined with cuboidal epithelium with a brush border. It increases the surface area for absorption. Almost all essential nutrients and 70-80 % of electrolytes and water are reabsorbed by PCT with small changes in luminal osmolarity. Hence urine is isotonic in the proximal convoluted tubule. 100% glucose, Amino acids absorbed but Cl- is not absorbed in PCT, hence it's concentration is not decreased in PCT. 


Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 369,370,371

choices.text: Microscopy shows fibrinoid necrosis in large arteries

questions.text: Pick the correct assumption about PAN:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 30% patients are HBSAg positive
 
  • Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by inflammation of small and medium-sized arteries.
  • This causes damage to the walls of those arteries and can lead to decreased blood flow, tissue necrosis, and organ damage.
  • PAN is not typically associated with ANCA (an autoantibody found in other vasculitides such as Wegener's granulomatosis), and approximately 30% of individuals with PAN can have HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen)-HBsAb (hepatitis B surface antibody) complexes.
  • Microscopically, PAN involves transmural inflammation and fibrous thickening, as well as segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation and fibrinoid necrosis. This occurs simultaneously in all stages of the disease.
  • Clinically, PAN is commonly found in individuals between the ages of 20 and 40. It can cause hypertension due to renal artery involvement, peripheral neuritis, abdominal pain, and bloody stools. Notably, PAN can also result in severe skin lesions and palpable nodes.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2810.

questions.text: Maltese cross in urine is seen in
questions.solution:
• The nephropathy of Fabry’s disease typically presents in the third decade as mild to moderate proteinuria, sometimes with microscopic hematuria or nephrotic syndrome. 
  • Urine examination in Fabry disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarised light showing a Maltese cross appearance.



NOTE: Maltese cross crystals are observed in urine in Fabry disease, nephrotic syndrome, and other conditions like short range shot gun wound and babesiosis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2345, 2346.

questions.text: An increase in central venous pressure causes the following effects:
questions.solution:
When the atria are stretched and the ECF volume is increased by the infusion of isotonic saline, ANP production is enhanced. The rate of ANP secretion is proportional to how much the atria are stretched by increases in central venous pressure. Stretching the ventricles causes an increase in BNP secretion. BNP secretion increases in direct proportion to how much stretched the ventricles are.
The increased ANP will then cause natriuresis

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 695

questions.text: An unconscious patient with a history of not eating for more than two days is brought to the emergency room. Which of the following tests will be positive for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) only iii
 
  • In the given question, patient presents with history of starvation for more than 2 days which can result in production of ketone bodies.
  • Test for ketone bodies is Rothera’s test.
  • Positive test gives a purple ring. Positive in case of acetone and acetoacetate. Negative in case of Beta hydroxy Butyrate.

1st image - Benedict test - shows glucose in urine, which is absent in starvation, 2ns image - Heat and acetic acid test for proteins. 

Online Reference: Comstock JP, Garber AJ. Ketonuria. In: Walker HK, Hall WD, Hurst JW, editors. Clinical Methods: The History, Physical, and Laboratory Examinations. 3rd edition. Boston: Butterworths; 1990. Chapter 140. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK247/

questions.text: A patient with renal failure and anemia comes. Serum Protein Electrophoresis is shown below. What's the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The large spike in the gamma region (M Spike) points toward a diagnosis of Multiple Myeloma.

Renal Failure and anemia are a part of end-organ damage (CRAB criteria of Multiple Myeloma).
In nephrotic syndrome, alpha-2 region spike is seen.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 868, 871.

questions.text: Renal Autoregulation does not occur because of:
questions.solution:
THE MYOGENIC AUTOREGULATION OF GFR AND RENAL BLOOD FLOW The ability of individual blood vessels to resist stretching under elevated arterial pressure helps to maintain a reasonably steady renal blood flow and GFR. Stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions from the extracellular fluid into the cells, causing them to contract. This contraction helps prevent excessive increases in renal blood flow and GFR by increasing vascular resistance when arterial pressure increases.

If there is decrease in GFR-> activation of RAAS pathway-> Angiotensin 2 helps in Na+ and water reabsorption increasing blood volume and mesangial cells contraction-> Increase in GFR 

Tubuloglomerular feedback also helps in maintaining auto-regulation of GFR

Therefore, option 2- Presympathetic nerves is the correct option. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 582

questions.text:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in- 
 A. HIV
 B. SLE
 C. Hepatitis B
 D. CLL
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) All of the above

MPGN is seen in all of the given conditions. MPGN is of two types:

Type 1: Primary MPGN (Idiopathic)
Type 2: Secondary MPGN arising in cases of:
  • i. SLE
  • ii. Endocarditis
  • iv. Infected ventriculoatrial shunts
  • v. Chronic visceral abscesses
  • vi. HIV, Hep B and C infection
  • vii. Schistosomiasis
  • viii. α1-Antitrypsin deficiency
  • ix. Malignant diseases (lymphoid tumors like CLL)
Note: In HIV, FSGS is more common but even MPGN can occur.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2341.

choices.text: High AG metabolic acidosis with metabolic Alkalosis
High AG metabolic acidosis with normal metabolic Alkalosis

questions.text: What is the  likely abnormality in a patient with renal failure who develops vomiting in ICU and ABG performed shows pH = 7.40. PaCO2 = 40, HCO3 = 24, Anion gap = 21?
questions.solution:
The likely metabolic abnormality in this patient is high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis. 
 
  • Patients with renal failure may have metabolic acidosis and associated vomiting in this patient may cause metabolic alkalosis. However, the parameters of arterial blood gas analysis appear to be normal. This disparity raises the suspicion of a mixed acid-base disorder. 
  • When metabolic acidosis and metabolic alkalosis coexist in the same patient, pH may be in the normal range. In such cases, the presence of an elevated anion gap denotes the presence of metabolic acidosis. 
  • AG is high, which points to high AG metabolic acidosis. 
  • In high anion gap metabolic acidosis, excess H+ ions are buffered by bicarbonate and the bicarbonate level falls. The fall in HCO3- is expected to be equal to the rise in anion gap. The difference between the rise in anion gap and the fall in HCO3- (delta gap) is zero in simple HAGMA. 
  • Associated vomiting in this patient results in loss of acid and hence the fall of bicarbonate level is less compared to the rise in the anion gap. A delta gap of more than +6 indicates the presence of additional metabolic alkalosis. 
    In this case, the delta gap is 10, which points to metabolic alkalosis in addition to high AG metabolic acidosis. 
  • Delta gap = (Actual anion gap - Normal anion gap) -(Normal bicarbonate - Actual bicarbonate) 
Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same
 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359-361.

questions.text: Which of these best describes the mechanism of 'vasopressin escape' in SIADH
questions.solution:
Vasopressin escape occurs due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 receptors. In SIADH, prolonged exposure to anti-diuretic hormone results in downregulation of aquaporin 2 receptors. This maintains euvolemic status of the body and doesn't lead to dilutional hyponatremia by preventing excessive reabsorption of water despite high levels of ADH. This phenomenon is known as vasopressin escape.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 688

questions.text: What is depicted in the below image concerning urinary crystals?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Struvite

The given image is of Struvite crystals (Coffin Lid shaped)
They are typically seen in UTI caused by urease-producing organisms (E.g. Proteus)

*[Extra Edge]:
  • Struvite stones, also known as infection stones or triple phosphate stones, form only when the upper urinary tract is infected with urease-producing bacteria such as Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella pneumoniae, or Providencia species.
  • Urease produced by these bacteria hydrolyzes urea and may elevate the urine pH to a supraphysiologic level (>8.0). Struvite stones may grow quickly and fill the renal pelvis (staghorn calculi).


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2373.

questions.text: Renal feed for CKD patients
questions.solution:
A low-volume diet is preferred to prevent toxic protein degradation byproduct accumulation, sodium and volume overload, hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia.
 
In order to reduce the patient's risk of malnutrition and wasting associated with ESRD, a high-calorie feed is preferred.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2313, 2317.

choices.text: Volume of serum in the kidney in 24 hours

questions.text: Which of the following does not have to be considered while determining creatine clearance?
questions.solution:
Volume of serum in kidney in 24 hours is not required for calculation of creatine clearance.
 
  • This clearance estimation based on UV/P formula
  • 24 hour urine is collected and then further creatinine concentration is measured.

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 667

questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Calcium oxalate

Calcium oxalate crystals are shown (Envelop Shaped)

questions.text:
Renopulmonary syndrome includes
a. Good pasture syndrome
b. Leptospira
c. Hantavirus
d. Wegener's granulomatosis
questions.solution:
All of the given options produce renopulmonary symptoms. 

Pulmonary renal syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition defined as the combination of diffuse alveolar haemorrhage (DAH) and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).
 
  • Leptospirosis: The classic presentation, often referred to as Weil’s syndrome, encompasses the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Patients die of septic shock with multiorgan failure and/or severe bleeding complications that most commonly involve the lungs (pulmonary hemorrhage).
  • Hantavirus infection: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome causes myocardial depression and increased pulmonary vascular permeability.
 

  • Differential diagnoses of pulmonary renal syndrome

    ANCA-associated vasculitis Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)
    Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA)
    Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA)
    Anti-GBM disease Anti-GBM disease (Good Pasture syndrome)
    ANCA-negative vasculitis IgA disease
    Cryoglobulinaemia
    Drug-induced vasculitis Cocaine
    d-penicillamine
    Autoimmune connective tissue disease Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
    Polymyositis
    Diabetes mellitus
    Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD)
    Systemic sclerosis



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 980, 1420.
Boyle, Niamh et al. “Pulmonary renal syndrome: a clinical review.” Breathe (Sheffield, England) vol. 18,4 (2022): 220208. doi:10.1183/20734735.0208-2022. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9973488/

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was taken to the emergency room with confusion and lethargy. His body temperature is 36.7°C, blood pressure is 86/58 mmHg, heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and respirations are 10 beats per minute. pCO2 is 49 mmHg, pH is 7.59, and pO2 is 85 mmHg. Which of the following conditions best describes his acid-base status?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Metabolic alkalosis

Method to calculate the acid base status is as follows
  1. We need 3 values to find out the answer. They are pH, pCO2 and HCO3
  2. The pCO2 value correlates with respiratory status
HCO3 value correlates with metabolic status
  1. Normal values are pH = 7.4     PCO2 = 40      HCO3 = 24

 
  1. Step 1 : pH <7.4 = acidosis
              pH >7.4 = alkalosis
  1. Step 2 : we have to find out if it is respiratory or metabolic
              If pCO2 indicates acidosis and pH indicates acidosis – Respiratory acidosis
              If pCO2 indicates alkalosis and pH indicates alkalosis – Respiratory alkalosis
              If HCO3 indicates acidosis and pH indicates acidosis – Metabolic acidosis
              If HCO3 indicates alkalosis and pH indicates alkalosis – Metabolic alkalosis

Another method is to remember ROME “RESPIRATORY OPPOSITE METABOLIC EQUAL



In this question pH is 7.59 which means alkalosis. pCO2 is 49 mmHg which indicates acidosis. Since the respiratory quotient is not correlating with alkalosis it seems to be a compensatory mechanism to overcome metabolic alkalosis.


In this question pH is 7.59 which means alkalosis. pCO2 is 49 mmHg which indicates acidosis. Since the respiratory quotient is not correlating with alkalosis it seems to be a compensatory mechanism to overcome metabolic alkalosis.

If we use the ROMS( Respiratory opposite Metabolic Same) mnemonic pH and pCO2 are both increasing which indicates metabolic alkalosis.



 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 705,635

questions.text: The mother says that her 10-year-old son is leaking frothy urine and has generalized edema. The child has 238 mg/dl of serum cholesterol. On analyzing urine: Protein is 3+. Which medical diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Nephrotic syndrome
 
  • Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by oedema, low serum albumin levels, and proteinuria in the nephrotic range along with hypercholesteremia (as given in the clinical stem of the question). 
  • Nephrotic-range proteinuria is defined as the presence of 2 grams of protein per gram of urine creatinine on a single spot urine collection or the loss of 3 grams or more of protein from the body every day.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 911.

questions.text: The lab reports of a patient given below pH=7.2 HCO3- =10 mEq/L PCO2 = 35 mm Hg This exemplifies which of the following disorder
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Metabolic acidosis.
  • In this case: pH = 7.2 (Normal: 7.35-7.45, below 7.35 is considered acidic), blood is too acidic HCO3- (bicarbonate) = 10 mEq/L (Normal range: 22-26 mEq/L).
  • The bicarbonate level is also low, which is another sign of metabolic acidosis.
  • PaCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) = 35 mm Hg (normal range: 35-45 mm Hg), The PaCO2 is normal, which means that the respiratory system is not contributing to the acidosis.
Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man needed dialysis, so he went to the hospital. An arterial blood sample was collected for testing prior to sending him for dialysis.
Which of the laboratory results listed below indicates compensated metabolic acidosis?
1. Low PCO2, normal bicarbonate and, high pH
2. Low PCO2, low bicarbonate, low pH
3. High PCO2, high bicarbonate and, low pH
4. High PCO2, low bicarbonate and High PH
questions.solution:
With or without a compensatory drop in bicarbonate (HCO3), respiratory alkalosis is characterised by a primary fall in carbon dioxide partial pressure (Pco2); pH may be high or close to normal. An increase in respiratory volume or rate (hyperventilation), or both, is the cause. Acute or chronic respiratory alkalosis is possible.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same



 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 705,706,635

questions.text: In idiopathic steroid resistance nephrotic syndrome (SRNS), what is the most frequent gene deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) NPHS-2
 
  • The most common gene defect in idiopathic steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS) is NPHS-2 (which codes for podocin) Mutations in NPHS2 result in steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome. Affected children usually show pathologic features of FSGS.
  • A distinctive pattern of autosomal recessive FSGS results from mutations in the NPHS2 gene, which maps to chromosome 1q25–q31 and encodes the protein product podocin. Podocin has also been localized to the slit diaphragm. Mutations in NPHS2 result in a syndrome of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome of childhood onset.
  • Mutations in the gene encoding the podocyte actin-binding protein α-actinin 4 underlie some cases of autosomal dominant FSGS, which can be insidious in onset but has a high rate of progression to renal insufficiency

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 916.

questions.text: A patient with deafness, hematuria and CKD. Light microscopy of urine is normal. Maternal Uncle has similar disease. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Alport syndrome presents with triad of deafness (SNHL), hematuria, and anterior lenticonus. It also lead to Chronic Kidney disease.
 
  • Classically, patients with Alport’s syndrome develop hematuria, thinning and splitting of the GBMs, and mild proteinuria (<1–2 g/24 h), which appears late in the course, followed by chronic glomerulosclerosis leading to renal failure in association with sensorineural deafness.
  • Some patients develop lenticonus of the anterior lens capsule, “dot and fleck” retinopathy, and rarely, leiomyomatosis.
  • Approximately 85% of patients with Alport’s syndrome have an X-linked inheritance of mutationsin the α5(IV) collagen chain on chromosome Xq22–24.

Other options: 
 
  • Thin basement membrane disease does not include deafness or chronic kidney disease.
  • Goodpasture syndrome and PSGN are ruled out by conventional light microscopy.
  • Initially, kidney biopsy specimens examined through light microscopy may be normal in alport syndrome.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2346, 2347.

questions.text:
A young woman is discovered unconscious after taking an undetermined amount of sleeping pills at an undetermined hour.
The following results are obtained from an arterial blood sample: pH 7.10, HCO2 32 meq/liter, and pCO2 68 mmHg.
Which of the following statements best sums up this patient's acid-base condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Respiratory acidosis with partial renal compensation

Step 1 : pH is 7.10 which indicates acidosis
Step 2 : pCO2 is 68 mmHg I.e higher than normal  which means respiratory acidosis
Step 3 : HCO3 is raised suggesting metabolic compensation
Therefore the answer will be Respiratory acidosis with partial renal compensation.

In case of metabolic acidosis, Winters Formula is used to calculate the required pCO2 compensation
Winters formula predicted PaCO2 = 1.5 x [HCO3-] + 8

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 635,636

questions.text:
A individual with reflux nephropathy, as determined by radiology, develops proteinuria of the nephritic range. Which of the following would most likely
describe the patient's histology findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
 
  • Most likely histologic findings in the patient with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy and nephritic range proteinuria is focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.
  • The cause of nephrotic syndrome is characterized by the presence of focal (only some glomeruli are affected) and segmental (only a part of the glomerulus is affected) sclerosis of the glomeruli.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 915.

questions.text: Tachypnea and mental confusion was found in a man aged 55, with ph = 7.0 and blood glucose 350 mg/dl. Name the acid base from the following
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Metabolic acidosis

The given information points to metabolic acidosis based on the following factors:
  1. Tachypnea: Refers to rapid breathing and is a compensatory mechanism to eliminate excess CO2 (acid) from the body in response to acidosis.
  2. Mental confusion: Acidosis can lead to central nervous system (CNS) depression, resulting in symptoms like confusion.

pH 7.0 (Normal: 7.35-7.45) is low indicating acidosis. Blood glucose = 350 mg/dl: Elevated blood glucose levels can lead to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is a type of metabolic acidosis commonly seen in uncontrolled diabetes.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359-361.

choices.text: The oncotic pressure of the fluid leaving the capillaries is less than that of fluid entering it
Glucose concentration in the capillaries is the same as that in glomerular filtrate
Constriction of afferent arteriole decrease the blood flow to the glomerulas
Hematocrit of the fluid leaving the capillaries is more than that of the fluid entering it

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding glomerular capillaries is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: The oncotic pressure of the fluid leaving the capillaries is less than that of fluid entering it

Option 1 : the oncotic pressure of fluid leaving the capillaries is more than that of fluid entering as last amino acids and proteins are not filtered through that glomerular membrane but plasma is freely filtered. Thus the oncotic pressure increases
Option 2 : the glucose concentration in the capillaries is same as that in the glomerular filtrate as glucose is freely filtered through the membrane via the fenestrated endothelium and the negatively charged membrane.
Option 3 : Constriction of Afferent arteriole will lead to reduced blood flow in the glomerular capillaries leading to decreased GFR. Constriction of efferent arteriole on the other hand leads to increased contact time of blood with the bowman’s capsule and thus increased GFR
Option 4 : hematocrit is the ratio of volume of RBCs to the volume of blood. the hematocrit of the fluid leaving the glomerular capillaries is generally the same as or slightly higher than that of the fluid entering it. This occurs because the glomerular capillaries primarily filter small molecules, ions, and water, while larger molecules such as red blood cells are not usually filtered. Consequently, the concentration of red blood cells and the hematocrit remain relatively constant throughout the process of filtration in the glomerulus.


 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 665-669

questions.text: Fibrinoid necrosis and an onion peel appearance are both found in a kidney specimen. The most likely pathology will be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis

Most probable pathology in specimen of kidney with fibrinoid necrosis and onion peel appearance is hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.
    • Fibrinoid necrosis and
    • Onion peel appearance is characteristic of hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.


Fig: Hyperplastic arteriolitis (onion-skin lesion)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 938.

questions.text: A 51-year-old patient arrived at the clinic complaining of hematuria. He was found to have normal blood pressure and pedal edema. Investigations showed the patient had a creatinine level of 9 mg% and no glycosuria. The electron microscopy is shown below. Which of the following investigations should be carried out in order to determine the cause of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Anti GBM Antibodies
 

  • Anti-GBM antibodies specifically targets the alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen found in the glomerular basement membrane (GBM).
  • In Goodpasture disease, these antibodies cause inflammation in the lungs and kidneys, resulting in a condition known as Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN). This can lead to pulmonary hemorrhage in the lungs, as well as to a particular appearance of the kidneys which is called “flea bitten kidneys” upon physical examination.
 
  • Under a microscope, cells called crescents are found in the kidney tissue. Immunofluorescence shows linear patterns of GBM fluorescence for IgG and complement, and electron microscopy reveals ruptures in the GBM.
 
  • Treatment typically involves a combination of plasmapheresis and immunosuppression.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2338, 2339.

choices.text: Volume of serum passing through the kidney in 24 hour

questions.text: What measurement of creatinine clearance is not necessary?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Volume of serum passing through the kidney in 24 hour

Creatinine clearance = GFR + tubular secretion
Thus, volume of serum passing through kidney is not a very accurate marker and not used in clinical practice, as tubular secretion of creatinine also needs to be taken in account.
All the other 3 markers are used routinely to determine the renal function.

Some other markers used for estimation of GFR are-




 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 666,667

questions.text: What is the most critical manifestation of CKD?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia is is the most critical manifestation of Chronic kidney disease.
  • It may lead to life threatening cardiac arrythmia and Diastolic arrest.
  • K+ >5.0 mEq/L
  • Acute reduction is required at levels >7.0 mEq/L
  • ECG - Tall peaked T waves

TREATMENT:
 
i. IV Calcium - most rapid and effective way to antagonize myocardial toxic effect
ii. IV Insulin
iii. Beta2 adrenergic agonist
iv. Hemodialysis if hyperkalemia is persistent or severe




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2313, 2316.

questions.text: The following cannot cause the renal pathology is given in the figure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Diabetes mellitus
 
  • Flea-bitten appearance of the kidney refers to multiple petechial hemorrhages on the renal surface.
  • Conditions associated with this pathology:
    • Hemolytic uremic syndrome: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury due to platelet aggregation and microthrombi formation in renal microvasculature.
    • Malignant hypertension: Severe hypertension leading to arteriolar damage and fibrinoid necrosis in renal arterioles.
    • Infective endocarditis: Infection of heart valves leading to embolic infarctions in the kidney.
  • Diabetes mellitus does not typically cause the flea-bitten appearance of the kidney.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 923.

questions.text: The type of urinary cast that is positive in urine in a patient of renal parenchymal disease:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fine granular cast
 
  • Urinary casts are cylindrical structures formed within the renal tubules and are composed of different materials.
  • In renal parenchymal disease, such as glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis, the casts seen in the urine can provide diagnostic clues.
  • Fine granular casts are composed of finely granular material and can be seen in various conditions, including renal parenchymal disease.
* Other options:
  • Coarse granular casts are formed by the precipitation of cellular debris and are typically seen in renal tubular injury.
  • Hyaline casts are transparent and composed of protein and can be found in both normal and pathological conditions.
  • Epithelial casts contain desquamated renal tubular epithelial cells and can indicate severe tubular injury.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2304.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with dull agonising back discomfort and sterile pyuria. A radiograph is displayed. What cause is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Often seen on plain radiography, a putty kidney is a pattern of renal calcification linked to renal TB.
  • The calcification, which represents calcified caseous tissue, is typically very uniform and ground glass-like.
  • A lobar pattern of calcification, in which dense calcific rims outline the margin of deformed renal lobes, must be distinguished from putty calcification.
  • When it comes to autonephrectomy, lobar calcification is an end-stage look.
  • A patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, with the given x-ray showing diffuse alveolar calcification in the right renal region point towards a diagnosis of a putty kidney. 
  • The putty kidney is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB), specifically renal TB. The given image shows a homogenous and ground-glass-like calcification of the kidney appearing like putty.
  • It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is thus always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB. 
  • Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with a tuberculin test, or at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine are examined for acid-fast bacilli. They are stained with a Ziehl-Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured. 
  • CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications.
CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB and its manifestations, which are as follows: 

Early:
• Papillary necrosis
Progressive:
• Multifocal strictures
• Generalized or focal hydronephrosis
• Mural thickening and enhancement
• Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma
End-stage:
• Progressive hydronephrosis
• Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney - putty kidney 

 
  • Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin. Partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery is often done. 



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1045, 1046.
Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 748.

questions.text: Which section of the renal tubule reabsorbs the most water when there are high levels of ADH present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Proximal tubule
 
  • Vasopressin or Anti Diuretic Hormone is secreted by Hypothalamus and is stored in Posterior Pituitary.
  • It is released from Posterior Pituitary in response to increase in plasma osmolarity and decrease in blood volume.
  • It acts on V2 receptors present in the Principal cells of the Collecting Ducts which leads to increased insertion of Aquaporin receptors. This leads to water reabsorption
  • However though ADH mainly acts on the Collecting Ducts still maximum reabsorption occurs in the Proximal Convoluted Tubule
  • Option 1, Proximal Tubule, is correct. When there are high levels of ADH (Antidiuretic hormone) present, the permeability of the walls of the collecting ducts and distal convoluted tubules to water increases.
  • However, the majority of water reabsorption occurs in the proximal tubule, which is the first segment of the renal tubule.
  • The proximal tubule is responsible for reabsorbing approximately 65% of the filtered water, along with ions, glucose, amino acids, and other solutes.
  • This occurs through both active and passive transport mechanisms, including the use of transport proteins and ion channels.
  • Therefore, in the presence of high levels of ADH, the proximal tubule would still be responsible for reabsorbing the majority of the filtered water, even though the collecting ducts and distal convoluted tubules have become more permeable to water.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 673

questions.text: Which of these is least likely associated with Dense deposit renal disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Lipodystrophy
 
  • Dense deposit renal disease (also known as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type II) is a rare form of kidney disease characterized by the deposition of abnormal material in the glomerular basement membrane.
  • Dense deposit renal disease is most commonly associated with complement dysregulation.
  • Conditions associated with Dense deposit renal disease:
    • HBV infection: Hepatitis B virus infection can trigger immune complex deposition and complement activation, leading to Dense deposit renal disease.
    • SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus): Autoimmune disease characterized by immune complex formation and glomerular involvement.
    • Cryoglobulinemia: Presence of cryoglobulins (abnormal proteins) in the blood, which can deposit in the kidneys.
  • Lipodystrophy is a disorder characterized by the loss of adipose tissue and is not typically associated with Dense deposit renal disease.
  • Out of the given options, Lipodystrophy is least likely associated with Dense deposit renal disease. Lipodystrophy is a rare disorder that affects the body's ability to produce and store fat. It is not typically associated with kidney disease, including Dense deposit disease. 
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2341.

choices.text: A rare complication of rapid and aggressive sodium correction

questions.text: An elderly woman experienced uncontrollable vomiting for seven days, along with fluid loss in the stools, decreased food intake, and sensorium changes. She is sent to the hospital, where fluid loss is treated with quick fluids and hyponatremia is treated with electrolyte correction. The patient began to experience quadriplegia and mutism during the course of treatment. What is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical features and the history of the patient indicate that he may be suffering from Central Pontine Myelinolysis (CPM), a disorder due to sudden and rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia, also known as Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome (ODS).
 
  • CPM is the result of a decrease in the amount of salt in the cells surrounding the brainstem, leading to damage of the myelin sheath, which is the protective covering of the nerve cells in the brain.
 
  • Symptoms of CPM include visual disturbances, paralysis, dysphagia, and speech disturbances.
 
  • Treatment includes prompt replacement of fluids and electrolytes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 344.

questions.text: Where in the tubule would a patient with severe central diabetes insipidus have the lowest tubular fluid osmolality?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: D
 
  • Vasopressin or Anti Diuretic Hormone is secreted by Hypothalamus and is stored in Posterior Pituitary.
  • It is released from Posterior Pituitary in response to increase in plasma osmolarity and decrease in blood volume.
  • It acts on V2 receptors present in the Principal cells of the Collecting Ducts which leads to increased insertion of Aquaporin receptors. This leads to water reabsorption

In Central diabetes Insipidus there is deficiency of Anti Diuretic Hormone. This decreases the water reabsorption in the collecting ducts, thereby decreasing the tubular fluid osmolarity in the collecting ducts.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 673,65,327

choices.text: Obliteration & fusion of foot processes of podocytes

questions.text: Light microscopy finding in membranous glomerulonephritis-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Diffuse capillary wall thickening
 
  • Membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN) is a type of glomerular disease characterized by the immune complex deposition in the glomerular basement membrane (GBM).
  • On light microscopy, membranous glomerulonephritis is characterized by Uniform thickening of the basement membrane along the peripheral capillary loops is seen by light microscopy on renal biopsy; this thickening needs to be distinguished from that seen in diabetes and amyloidosis.
  • The subepithelial spikes appear as irregular, finger-like projections extending into the capillary lumen when viewed under electron microscopy.
  • These spikes are formed by the accumulation of immune complexes, predominantly IgG and complement C3, along the outer aspect of the GBM.
  • These spikes can cause thickening and distortion of the GBM, leading to impaired filtration and the development of nephrotic syndrome.

Fig: The light microscopic appearance of membranous nephropathy in which the capillary loops are thickened and prominent, but the cellularity is not expected to be increased.

* Other options:
 
  • Obliteration and fusion of foot processes of podocytes are characteristic findings in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).
  • Subepithelial Spikes are seen in MGN but in Electron Microscopy.
  • Subendothelial hump is observed in post-infectious glomerulonephritis (PIGN).


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 2343.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a complication of massive blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia is NOT a complication of massive blood transfusion.

Following are the complications of massive transfusion:
  • Decreased body temperature
  • Acidosis
  • Coagulopathy
  • Raised K+
  • Decreased Mg2+ and Ca2+
  • Air embolism
  • Citrate toxicity


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 22.

questions.text: Regardless of the GFR value, a fixed portion of the filtered load is absorbed in the proximal tubule. What causes this?
questions.solution:
The correct option for the given question is 1. Tubuloglomerular feedback.
  • Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) is a mechanism that regulates the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) by controlling the diameter of the afferent arteriole. The TGF mechanism involves the detection of changes in sodium chloride concentration in the macula densa cells of the juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA) located in the distal convoluted tubule.
  • When the GFR increases, the flow of filtrate through the tubules also increases, and the concentration of sodium chloride in the macula densa cells increases. This triggers the release of vasoconstrictor chemicals, such as adenosine and thromboxane, which constrict the afferent arteriole, reducing the GFR.
  • Conversely, when the GFR decreases, the concentration of sodium chloride in the macula densa cells decreases, and this triggers the release of vasodilator chemicals, such as nitric oxide, which dilate the afferent arteriole, increasing the GFR.
  • However, regardless of the GFR value, a fixed portion of the filtered load is absorbed in the proximal tubule. This is due to the fact that the proximal tubule has a high capacity for reabsorption and can reabsorb up to 65% of the filtered load. 
     

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 672

questions.text: What is the most common cause of chronic pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Chronic reflux disease
 
  • Chronic pyelonephritis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the renal parenchyma and renal pelvis, usually caused by recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).
  • The most common cause of chronic pyelonephritis is chronic reflux disease, also known as vesicoureteral reflux.
  • In vesicoureteral reflux, there is abnormal retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters and kidneys during micturition.
  • This condition predisposes the kidneys to recurrent UTIs, which can lead to chronic inflammation and scarring of the renal tissue.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 930.

questions.text: A woman complains of having abdominal pain. The CECT reveals bilateral papillary necrosis. Which of the following tests should not be performed to find out what caused her papillary necrosis?
questions.solution:
Urine acidification test is mainly done to diagnose RTA (Renal tubular acidosis), NOT the cause of papillary necrosis.

• Though TB is not a major cause but it can cause papillary necrosis, diagnosed by urine RT-PCR.
• Bacterial culture is done for UTI.
• Sickle cell disease can be diagnosed by Sickling test.

Common causes of Renal Papillary Necrosis:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2282, 2348, 2362.

choices.text: Basement membrane carries a net negative charge
Myoglobin is filtered more readily than albumin

questions.text: Which of the following statements about glomerular filtration is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Negatively charged molecules are filtered readily
 
  • Glomerular Filtration Barrier is composed
    • Fenestrated Capillary Endothelium
    • Basement Membrane – Composed of Type IV collagen, Heparan sulphate
    • Visceral Epithelial Layer consisting of Podocyte foot process
  • Basement membrane composed of Heparan Sulphate which is negatively charged and hence prevents the entry of negatively charged molecules like albumin
  • Fenestrated Capillary Endothelium prevents entry of molecules more than 100 nm in size ; slit diaphragm prevents entry of particles size more than 50 nm. Therefore Low molecular weight molecules filter easily.
  • Molecular weight of Myoglobin ( 16 kilo DA)  is much less compared to molecular weight of albumin (64kDA). Therefore Myoglobin is filtered much easily compared to Albumin.
 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 667,668

questions.text: What is a patient's urine analysis most likely to show if they have hematuria and hypercalciuria?
questions.solution:
• Urine analysis of a patient with hematuria and hypercalciuria is most likely to reveal isomorphic RBCs.
  • Hypercalciuria is a cause of non-glomerular hematuria.
  • RBCs from a non-glomerular source more closely resemble peripheral blood on microscopy, with isomorphic RBCs and absence of casts.
​​​​​​​





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2280, 2304.

questions.text: Which of the renal tubule is a normal Functioning Kidney will reabsorb most water in a dehydrated patient with very high levels of ADH
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Proximal tubule
 
  • Vasopressin or Anti Diuretic Hormone is secreted by Hypothalamus and is stored in Posterior Pituitary.
  • It is released from Posterior Pituitary in response to increase in plasma osmolarity and decrease in blood volume.
  • It acts on V2 receptors present in the Principal cells of the Collecting Ducts which leads to increased insertion of Aquaporin receptors à This leads to water reabsorption
However though ADH mainly acts on the Collecting Ducts still maximum reabsorption occurs in the Proximal Convoluted Tubule.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 686

questions.text: What is the least likely scenario in which peripheral eosinophilia and renal failure could occur?
questions.solution:
Peripheral eosinophilia with renal failure is least likely in Polyarteritis nodosa.


Causes of Eosinophiluria: (>1% of urinary Leukocytes as Eosinophils)-
 
  1. Acute interstitial nephritis
  2. Acute rejection of renal allograft
  3. Acute glomerulonephritis (RPGN, PSGN)
  4. Chronic pyelonephritis
  5. Cholesterol embolization of kidney (atheroembolic renal failure)
  6. Bladder cancer
  7. Obstructive uropathy



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2279, 2281, 2304.

questions.text: Which of the following fruit juices can help prevent UTI if consumed on a regular basis?
questions.solution:
Regular drinking of cranberry juice can prevent UTI.
 
  • Cranberry juice is traditionally used for prophylaxis and treatment of UTI.
  • Cranberry juice contains proanthocyanidins that block adherence of pathogens to uroepithelial cells in vitro.
  • Non-antimicrobial prevention is increasingly being studied. Lactobacillus probiotics are one appealing approach to UTI prevention, but there is a paucity of data to support this strategy. Similarly, studies of cranberry products for UTI prevention have produced mixed results.


Reference: Jepson, R G et al. “Cranberries for treating urinary tract infections.” The Cochrane database of systematic reviews vol. 1998,2 (2000): CD001322. doi:10.1002/14651858.CD001322. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7025796/

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1078.

questions.text: A Hepatitis C patient has hematuria, proteinuria, and hypocomplementemia (2 g/day). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis in this case is MPGN.

Type 1 MPGN has following features:
    • ￲presence of subendothelial deposits of immune complexes associated with activation of the classical complement pathway.
    • ￲persistent hepatitis C
    • ￲exhibits hypo-complimentemia with proteinuria and hematuria.￲



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2336, 2340, 2341.

questions.text: Which of the following is not indicated in a patient with cystinuria and multiple renal stones?
questions.solution:
All are indicated in a patient with cystinuria with multiple renal stones except cysteamine.

Treatment modality of patient with cystinuria with multiple renal stones:
    • ￲increase in urine volume (increase fluid intake)
    • ￲alkalinization of urine
    • ￲penicillamine
    • ￲tiopronin￲



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3274.

questions.text: Which of the following advice is not given top a 35 years old female patient with recurrent renal stone?
questions.solution:
Advice not given to a 35 year old female patient with recurrent renal stone is restricted calcium intake.

Including a source of calcium at every meal may help reduce the formation of oxalate stones because calcium binds to oxalate in food and stops it from being absorbed by the body.

Increased sodium intake has shown to increase renal stones therefore decreasing sodium intake is advised. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2365, 2372.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man has anterior lenticonus and ESRD now. His maternal uncle also died of a similar illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is Alport's syndrome.

This given clinical picture is a typical clinical picture of Alport's syndrome

Triad seen in Alport's syndrome:
  1. ￲hereditary nephritis
  2. ￲sensorineural deafness
  3. ￲ocular abnormalities(anterior lenticonus)￲
 
  • Classically, patients with Alport’s syndrome develop hematuria, thinning and splitting of the GBMs, and mild proteinuria (<1–2 g/24 h), which appears late in the course, followed by chronic glomerulosclerosis leading to renal failure in association with sensorineural deafness.
  • Some patients develop lenticonus of the anterior lens capsule, “dot and fleck” retinopathy, and rarely, leiomyomatosis.
  • Approximately 85% of patients with Alport’s syndrome have an X-linked inheritance of mutationsin the α5(IV) collagen chain on chromosome Xq22–24.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2346, 2347.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the Metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joints and is a known case of chronic renal failure. This is due to the accumulation of :
questions.solution:
This is due to accumulation of uric acid.

Gout is a disorder of purine metabolism characterized by hyperuricemia, ￲deposition of monosodium urate-monohydrate crystals in joints and peri-articular tissues ￲recurrent attacks of acute synovitis.￲



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2279, 2863.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about type 1 renal tubular acidosis?
questions.solution:
All are true about type-1 renal tubular acidosis except 3. sodium bicarbonate requirement > 4mg/day

Treatment modality of type-1 RTA:
 
  • ￲Early initiation of alkali replacement at doses equivalent to 1-3 mmol/kg per day of bicarbonate in divided doses will usually correct the acidosis, hypokalemia, and hypocitraturia, maintaining growth and preventing bone disease in early-onset dRTA.
  • ￲Citrate is generally tolerated better than sodium bicarbonate and can be given as the potassium or sodium salt. depending on the severity of hypokalemia.￲



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2291-2294.

questions.text: A male adolescent appears with hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis, metabolic alkalosis, and hypokalemia. He has normal blood pressure. It is highly likely that:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Bartter Syndrome
 
  • The case involves a male adolescent with hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis, metabolic alkalosis, and hypokalemia.
  • These symptoms, along with normal blood pressure, are highly suggestive of Bartter Syndrome.
  • Bartter Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder affecting kidney salt reabsorption, leading to potassium, chloride, and sodium loss in the urine, resulting in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2286, 2287, 2293.

questions.text: In dialysis patients, what trace element is linked to the risk of osteomalacia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Aluminium
 
  • In dialysis patients, there is a risk of developing osteomalacia.
  • Osteomalacia is a softening of the bones that can cause pain, weakness, and fractures. It is caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, which is needed for the bones to absorb calcium.
  • Aluminium toxicity is linked to the development of osteomalacia in dialysis patients.
  • Excess aluminium accumulation can occur in these patients due to the use of aluminium-containing phosphate binders or exposure to aluminium in the dialysis process.
  • Prolonged exposure to high levels of aluminium in the dialysis fluid can lead to the accumulation of aluminium in the bones, causing osteomalacia



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2307, 2308.

questions.text: All of the following are caused by primary adrenal insufficiency, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Elevated plasma volume 
 
  • Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), aldosterone (mineralocorticoid), and sex hormones. The most common cause of Addison's disease is autoimmune adrenalitis. 
  • The key symptoms include:
         A. Increased urine output
         B. Weight loss with edema,
         C. Decreased urine osmolarity
  • There is decreased retention of sodium and water in the body, which leads to a decrease in plasma volume

Clinical features of Addison’s disease:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2971, 2972.

questions.text: Anuria in clinical practice is defined as:
questions.solution:
• Anuria is a medical condition in which the body produces little or no urine.
  • In clinical practice, anuria is defined as a urine output of less than 50 ml per day.
  • Anuria is a serious condition that can lead to the buildup of toxins in the body and can be caused by a variety of factors such as kidney failure, dehydration, and certain medications.
  • Oliguria is defined as <400 mL/24 h.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2279, 2302.

questions.text: Which of the following best defines Microscopic Hematuria as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 3 or More RBC/HPF
 
  • Microscopic hematuria : Presence of RBCs in the urine, visible only under a microscope.
  • It is defined as the presence of 3 or more RBCs per high-power field (HPF) on microscopic examination of the urine.
  • Microscopic hematuria is a common finding and can be caused by various conditions like urinary tract infections, kidney stones, and kidney disease.
  • In contrast, gross hematuria refers to visible blood in the urine.

Other options:
 
  • Macroscopic hematuria: Presence of 5 or more RBCs/HPF.
  • Severe hematuria: 25 or more RBCs/HPF and 50 or more RBCs/HPF.



Reference: Bolenz, Christian et al. “The Investigation of Hematuria.” Deutsches Arzteblatt international vol. 115,48 (2018): 801-807. doi:10.3238/arztebl.2018.0801. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6365675/

questions.text: Distal renal tubular acidosis is associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Calcium stones 
 
  • The clinical features of RTA-1 or distal RTA include diarrhea and renal stones with metabolic acidosis, alkaline urine, hypokalemia, positive urine anion gap, and hypercalciuria.
  • RTA-1 occurs due to defective urinary acidification in the cortical collecting tubule due to ineffective H+ ion secretion by the alpha-intercalated cells. This leads to the formation of alkaline urine. The decreased H+ secretion also leads to inadequate HCO3- regeneration in the alpha-intercalated cells thus leading to metabolic acidosis.
 
  • In this condition, calcium phosphate and oxalate stones are formed in the distal convoluting tubules(DCT).
  • Acidemia leads to hypercalcemia and then hypercalciuria. There is also hypocitraturia as acidemia induces increased cell citrate utilization. Normally, citrate in the urine binds to calcium and increases its solubility. In the absence of citrate in the urine, calcium begins to precipitate. This leads to nephrocalcinosis and calcium phosphate and oxalate stones.
     






Reference: Brenner and Rector's The Kidney, 10th edition, Page no 2384.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th edition, Page no 2172.

questions.text: An exception to low Renin Hypertension is seen in all of the following ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Renovascular hypertension 
 
  • Renal artery stenosis (RAS) is the narrowing of one or both renal arteries, causing high blood pressure, but not low renin levels.
  • Renovascular Hypertension is the exception to the typical pattern of low Renin Hypertension.
  • Renovascular hypertension is high blood pressure caused by narrowed or blocked renal arteries supplying blood to the kidneys.
  • The reduced blood flow triggers the kidneys to produce more renin, resulting in elevated renin levels.
  • In contrast to other conditions associated with low renin levels, Renovascular Hypertension presents with high renin levels due to the narrowed renal arteries.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2088, 2089.

questions.text: Which of the following is an exception to Dent's disease characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct​ Option is 4: Distal Renal Tubule defect ​​​​​​
 
  • Dent's disease is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by inactivating mutation in CLN5, a chloride transpoter expressed in endosomes of the proximal tubule (Dent disease 1) or OCRL gene mutation (Dent disease 2).
  • Seen more commonly in males.
 
The clinical diagnosis of Dent's disease is based on the presence of all three of the following criteria:
 
  1. LMW proteinuria (elevation of urinary excretion of β2-microglobulin, Clara cell protein and/or RBP by at least 5-fold above the upper limit of normality)
  2. Hypercalciuria (> 4 mg/kg in a 24 h-hour collection or > 0.25 mg Ca2+ per mg creatinine on a spot sample)
  3. At least one of the following: nephrocalcinosis, kidney stones, hematuria, hypophosphataemia, or renal insufficiency


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2292, 2293.

questions.text: The cause of Dialysis disequilibrium is-
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Reverse Urea effect 
 
  • Dialysis disequilibrium is a condition seen in dialysis patients due to rapid changes in urea and other solute levels in the blood during dialysis.
  • The most common cause of dialysis disequilibrium is the "reverse urea effect",where blood urea levels drop too quickly.
  • Rapid drop in blood urea creates concentration gradient, driving water into brain cells, causing cerebral edema (brain swelling).
  • Symptoms of dialysis disequilibrium include headache, nausea, vomiting, and confusion.
 
  • When DDS is suspected, strong consideration should be given to discontinuing the dialysis treatment.
  • Management of DDS is supportive, as with any other patient with acute neurologic deterioration and suspected raised intracranial pressure and cerebral edema. Maintain the airway and consider hyperventilation.
  • In addition, the cerebral edema can be treated by increasing plasma osmolality with mannitol or hypertonic saline to reduce the osmotic gradient between the blood and brain

Other options:
  • Hypertension, aluminium toxicity, and amyloid deposition are potential complications of dialysis but are not responsible for causing dialysis disequilibrium.


Reference: Mistry, Kirtida. “Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome prevention and management.” International journal of nephrology and renovascular disease vol. 12 69-77. 30 Apr. 2019, doi:10.2147/IJNRD.S165925. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6503314/

questions.text: A 30-year-old man arrives with hypertension and widespread edema. A urine examination reveals microscopic hematuria and sub nephrotic proteinuria (2 gm).He has anti-hepatitis C antibodies and his serum complement levels have dropped. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cryoglobulinemia

Clinical features of chronic hepatitis C are similar to those described above for chronic hepatitis B. Generally, fatigue is the most common symptom; jaundice is rare. Immune complex–mediated extrahepatic complications of chronic hepatitis C are less common than in chronic hepatitis B (despite the fact that assays for immune complexes are often positive in patients with chronic hepatitis C), with the exception of essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, which is linked to cutaneous vasculitis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis as well as lymphoproliferative disorders such as B-cell lymphoma and unexplained monoclonal gammopathy.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2334-2336; 2604

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman arrives with hypertension, skin ulceration, and generalized edema. A urine examination reveals microscopic hematuria and sub nephrotic proteinuria (2 gm). She tests positive for hepatitis C and has lower serum complement levels. It is highly likely that:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Essential Mixed Cryoglobulinemia
 
  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mixed cryoglobulinemia, which is strongly associated with hepatitis C.
  • Cryoglobulinemia means the presence of cryoglobulins (immunoglobulins that precipitate at temperatures less than 37°C) in the serum.
  • Deposition of these immune complexes leads to cutaneous vasculitis (skin ulcers, purpura), arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis.
  • The presence of a measurable amount of cryoglobulin (cryocrit) with low C4 complement levels is the laboratory hallmark of cryoglobulinemia.
  • Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN) and Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can also cause glomerulonephritis, but they are not typically associated with cryoglobulinemia or hepatitis C infection


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2334-2336; 2604

choices.text: Failure to acidify urine to a pH<5
Associated with increased risk of urinary stones

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Type I Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Associated with Hyperkalemia
 
  • RTA type I (distal RTA) is seen in autoimmune diseases like Sjogren's syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, medullary sponge kidney disease, cirrhosis, drugs like amphotericin B, lithium, etc.
  • The patients develop hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis with alkaline urine (urinary pH >5.5). 
  • Type I RTA is associated with an increased risk of urinary stones due to the precipitation of certain minerals in the urine .The increased risk of urinary stones is related to the alkalinization of urine.
  • Treatment for Type I RTA involves alkali replacement as bicarbonate to help correct the metabolic acidosis

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 351 .

choices.text: Serotoxin has no role in the pathogenesis

questions.text: What is the least accurate statement concerning hemolytic uremic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Serotoxin has no role in the pathogenesis 
 
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) : Triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.
  • The most common cause of HUS is infection with Shiga toxin-producing E.coli (STEC), often following ingestion of contaminated food, particularly undercooked ground beef or raw vegetables.
  • Shiga toxin from STEC damages blood vessel endothelial cells, causing microthrombi and organ damage, especially in the kidneys (HUS pathogenesis).
Other options:
  • A. HUS is commonly associated with a preceding infection, often hemorrhagic colitis caused by STEC.
  • B. HUS is often self-limited, meaning it tends to resolve on its own in many cases, especially in children. However, some cases can be severe and require medical intervention.
  • C. Fever is usually mild or absent in HUS, and it is not a prominent symptom.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2285, 2286, 2348.

questions.text: Except for ________, all of the following conditions are linked to type 1 cryoglobulinemia.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Strongly Positive Rheumatoid factor
 
  • Type 1 cryoglobulinemia is specifically linked to monoclonal gammopathies, including monoclonal IgM paraprotein (Option B).
  • Hyperviscosity (Option A) can occur due to increased levels of cryoglobulins in the blood, leading to blood flow issues.
  • In type 1 cryoglobulinemia, complement levels (Option C) are typically normal, unlike in type 2 and type 3 cryoglobulinemia, where complement levels are reduced.
  • Rheumatoid factor is an antibody that is produced in people with rheumatoid arthritis. However, it is not typically associated with type 1 cryoglobulinemia.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2340,2341 .
